(Code 1975, § 1-11; Code 1995, § 1-12) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipalities, O.S. title 11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Seal described. 
    The seal of the city shall be a pictorial quadrant displaying symbols for the City of Yukon, the State of Oklahoma, the Chisholm Trail and the Czech Capital, all of which shall be surrounded by the words "Seal of the City of Yukon, Oklahoma" and the date 1891. Such seal shall be circular and not more than two inches in diameter. 

(Code 1975, § 2-173; Code 1995, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-2. - Flag described. 
    The flag of the city shall be rectangular in shape with a blue stripe across the top, a large white field in the center with the outline of the state printed in blue and the name "YUKON" printed in large red letters diagonally across the state with blue numerals "1891" in the panhandle part of the state and the words "Vitame Vas" in blue in the lower right-hand corner of the state, and a red stripe across the bottom of the flag. 

(Code 1975, § 2-175; Code 1995, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-3. - Retention of flag. 
    The flag shall be kept in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 2-176; Code 1995, § 2-4) 
Sec. 2-4. - Membership of city in municipal league. 
    The city is hereby authorized to procure the services of the Oklahoma Municipal League and to have membership therein and to appropriate funds to pay for such services and membership. 
(Code 1975, § 2-6; Code 1995, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-5. - Membership in ACOG. 
    The city is hereby authorized to have membership in the Association of Central Oklahoma Governments (ACOG). 
(Code 1975, § 2-7; Code 1995, § 2-6) 
Secs. 2-6-2-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-29. - Meetings-Place. 
    Every meeting of the city council shall be held in the council chamber unless the mayor or the council members designate another place in the city for the holding of special meetings; provided that any adjourned meeting may be held at any other place within the city designated by the council. 
(Code 1975, § 2-1; Code 1995, § 2-31) 
Sec. 2-30. - Same-Time of regular meetings. 
    The city council shall hold a regular meeting on the first and third Tuesdays of every month, the time of day of such meetings to be set by the council at least two weeks prior to the meeting date; provided that if such a Tuesday falls on a holiday, the regular meeting shall be held at that time on the next day which is not a holiday. The city council may change the date for any specific regular meeting, by vote, at least two weeks in advance of such regular meeting date. 
(Code 1975, § 2-2; Code 1995, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-31. - Rules of order. 
    Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, 11th Edition, is adopted for use by the city council and all commissions and committees of the city and shall control the procedures of the city council and such commissions and committees. 
(Code 1995, § 1-13; Ord. No. 1068, § 1, 10-17-2000) 
Secs. 2-32-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-51. - Provision of bonds to perform duties. 
(a)  Before entering upon their official duties, the following personnel of the city government shall provide bonds for the faithful performance of their official duties, payable to the city, with a surety company authorized to operate within the state, in the amounts respectively indicated after their titles: 
(1)  City manager: ..... $10,000.00 
(2)  City clerk: .....  25,000.00 
(3)  City treasurer: .....  50,000.00 
(b)  The city council, by motion or resolution, may require other officers and employees in such positions as it may designate to be bonded by individual or blanket bonds. 
(c)  The city shall pay the premiums on bonds provided by this section. 
(Code 1975, § 2-5; Code 1995, § 2-56) 
Secs. 2-52-2-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CLERK 

Sec. 2-76. - General powers and duties. 
    The city clerk shall be an officer of the city. The city clerk shall have the powers, duties and functions as may be prescribed by the Charter, by applicable state law, this Code, or by ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 2-50; Code 1995, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-77. - Destruction of certain city records. 
(a)  General authority to dispose documents, records. The city clerk is hereby authorized each year to destroy or otherwise dispose of the following papers, documents and records after the expiration of the following periods of time: 
(1)  One year. Parking citations after the date of issuance; 
(2)  Two years. Municipal court warrants, water, sewer, garbage and utility receipts and statements, which have been previously audited; inspection records relating to water meters and sewer inspections; miscellaneous petitions and letters addressed to the city council on matters other than pertaining to the items hereinafter set forth; utility billing ledger or register; utility cash receipts ledger or register; utility accounts receivable ledger or register; and fire run contracts; 
(3)  Five years. Successful and unsuccessful bids for the purchase or furnishing of equipment, material and improvements; inspection records except as provided for in subsection (2) of this section; claims that have been denied; license applications; bonds; special, primary and general election payrolls; election tabulations and returns; withholding statements; garnishment records; traffic tickets and receipts; bond receipts and fine receipts; information and complaints; court dockets; paid general obligation and revenue bonds; paid street improvement, sewer and sidewalk district bonds; warrants; claims; checks; vouchers; purchase orders; and payrolls; 
(4)  Ten years. Inventories; appropriation ledgers; sidewalk assessment records, except payment records; cash receipt books or registers for the general fund, the street and alley fund, any bond fund or sinking fund and all other trust funds that have been audited; and 
(5)  Fifteen years. Sewer and street improvement district records, except payment records. 
(b)  Testing laboratory results, inspection records. This section shall not be construed to authorize or allow the destruction of any testing laboratory results or the inspection records of public improvements of the city. 
(c)  Records involving pending litigation retained. None of the records, papers or documents mentioned in subsection (a) of this section and pertaining to pending litigation shall be disposed of until such litigation is finally terminated. 
(Code 1975, § 2-51; Code 1995, § 2-82) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 11 O.S. § 22-131; authority to have records photographed or reproduced on film or stored on optical disc, 11 O.S. § 22-132; Records Management Act, 67 O.S. § 201 et seq.; Oklahoma Open Records Act, 51 O.S. § 24A.1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-78-2-97. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ATTORNEY AND DEPARTMENT OF LAW 

Sec. 2-98. - Department of law established. 
    There is established a department of law. 
(Code 1975, § 2-65; Code 1995, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-99. - Powers and duties. 
    The city attorney shall be the chief legal advisor of the city council and all officers, departments and agencies of the city government in matters relating to their official powers and duties. He shall represent the city in proceedings in the courts. He shall perform all services incident to his position which may be required by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 2-66; Code 1995, § 2-107(a)) 
Secs. 2-100-2-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-127-2-151. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS 

Sec. 2-152. - Police department established;duties. 
(a)  There shall be a police department. All police officers shall be officers of the city. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police department to apprehend, arrest and bring to justice all violators of the ordinances of the city; to suppress all riots, affrays, and unlawful assemblies which may come to their knowledge, and generally to keep peace; to serve all warrants, writs, executions, and other processes properly directed and delivered to them; to apprehend and arrest persons violating federal or state law as provided by law, and to turn them over to proper authority; and in all respects to perform all duties pertaining to the offices of police officers. The police department shall have charge of and operate the city jail. 
(Code 1975, § 2-77; Code 1995, § 2-166) 
State Law reference- Collective bargaining for police officers, 11 O.S. § 51-101 et seq. 
Sec. 2-153. - Fire department established; duties. 
(a)  There shall be a fire department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the fire department, among others, to extinguish fires; to rescue persons endangered by fires; to resuscitate, and to administer first aid to, persons injured in or about burning structures, or elsewhere in case of an emergency; to promote fire prevention; and unless otherwise provided, to enforce all ordinances relating to fires, fire prevention, and safety of persons from fire in theaters, stores, and other public buildings. 
(Code 1975, § 2-78; Code 1995, § 2-167) 
Sec. 2-154. - Dispatch telephone service established; additional personnel. 
(a)  There shall be a 24-hour dispatch telephone service for both the fire department and the police department which shall be maintained by the police department personnel, subject to administrative directives from the city manager. 
(b)  The police department and/or the fire department shall have such additional personnel, either paid or voluntary, as the council may authorize. 
(Code 1975, § 2-79; Code 1995, § 2-168) 
Secs. 2-155-2-176. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEVELOPMENT SERVICES DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-177. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a development services department. 
(Code 1975, § 2-89; Code 1995, § 2-181) 
Sec. 2-178. - Duties. 
    The development services department under the supervision of the director of development services, or his designee, shall: 
(1)  Inspect the construction, alteration or remodeling of buildings and structures, the installation of electrical wiring and of plumbing, and those electrical, gas, air conditioning, refrigeration, heating and plumbing fixtures and facilities installed within the city. 
(2)  Specifically enforce the provisions of chapter 6, chapter 10, chapter 204, chapter 18, chapter 34, chapter 207, chapter 210, chapter 201, chapter 213, section 90-3, chapter 94, chapter 118, and appendixes A and B to this Code. 
(3)  Promulgate and enforce such rules, regulations and procedures for the efficient administration of those duties required by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 2-90; Code 1995, § 2-182; Ord. No. 1113, § 1, 2-18-2003) 
Sec. 2-179. - Powers of code compliance inspector. 
    Inspectors of the development services department are hereby vested with the power and authority, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Order the stopping of construction of any building or structure, or the alteration, repair or wrecking thereof, if such is being done in a careless or reckless manner, or in violation of the provision of this Code. 
(2)  Call upon the police and fire departments in enforcing violations of this Code for violations committed in the presence of the inspector. 
(3)  Order the disconnection of all gas connections to those residences or businesses which the inspector determines have dangerous gas fittings, and such gas shall remain disconnected until such time as violations on dangerous fittings have been remedied. 
(4)  Order the discontinuance of water service to any building, structure, or premises being built, used or occupied in violation of this Code, and such water service shall remain discontinued until such time as the violations have been remedied to the satisfaction of the inspector. 
(5)  Order the disconnection of electric service where improper or defective wiring exists or where electrical construction or equipment has been installed without a required permit. 
(6)  Enter upon or enter in any building, structure or premises at all reasonable times so as to inspect all electrical wiring, electrical equipment, plumbing, air conditioning systems, heating systems, or refrigeration systems which are now or may hereafter be installed, or to ascertain the sanitary condition, damage or structural soundness of that building, structure or premises. 
(7)  Recommend that the council declare a nuisance or request the removal of any building, wall or other structure, which is upon, adjoining or near any street, avenue, alley or public ground, which has become dangerous or insecure or liable to collapse from inherent structural weakness or decay, or from fire damage, or for any other reason becomes a menace to life or property. 
(8)  Revoke any permit where it is found that there has been a misrepresentation of facts or a violation of this Code. 
(9)  Require any owner or agent who is constructing with reinforced concrete or structural steel, to supply a non-city inspector satisfactory to the department of community development; such inspector is to continually oversee all work during that construction. 
(10)  Order the vacation of any habitation which is unfit for occupancy due to damage, decay, dilapidation, unsanitary or unsafe conditions which create a serious health or safety hazard to the occupants or to the public. 
(11)  Order the closing of any streets and the rerouting of traffic when the city has contracted with any person for the improvement of such street, for that period of time necessary to permit the proper completion of that improvement. 
(12)  Issue citations for violations of zoning ordinances upon direction of the director of community development or his designee, the director of public works, city engineer, development coordinator, or any agent of any of these officials. 
(Code 1995, § 2-183; Ord. No. 1113, § 2, 2-18-2003) 
Sec. 2-180. - Director to serve as zoning administrator. 
    The director of development services shall serve as the zoning administrator, unless the city manager designates someone else to serve in such capacity. 
(Code 1975, § 2-91; Code 1995, § 2-184; Ord. No. 1113, § 3, 2-18-2003) 
Secs. 2-181-2-198. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE 

Sec. 2-199. - Debt limitations. 
(a)  Neither the city nor the Yukon Municipal Authority shall incur any indebtedness, in any manner, or for any purpose, to an amount exceeding, in any year, the income and revenue provided for such year without the assent of three-fifths of the voters thereof, voting at an election, to be held for that purpose, nor, in cases requiring such assent, shall any indebtedness be allowed to be incurred to an amount, including existing indebtedness, in the aggregate exceeding five percent of the valuation of the taxable property therein, to be ascertained from the last assessment for state and county purposes previous to the incurring of such indebtedness. 
(b)  The following bonds and indebtedness are conclusively determined to be within and not to exceed the limitations of Section 2-137(a), or any debt limitations of the Code of Ordinances or the Charter of the city, and any conflicting provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the city are modified to the extent necessary to fully validate the following: 
(1)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax and Utility System Revenue and Refunding Bonds, Series 2012 in the aggregate principal amount of $6,500,000.00. 
(2)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax and Utility System Revenue and Refunding Bonds, Series 2013 in the aggregate principal amount of $8,500,000.00. 
(3)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax Revenue Note, Series 2015A in the aggregate principal amount of $9,520,000.00. 
(4)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax Revenue Note, Series 2015B in the aggregate principal amount of $5,805,000.00. 
(5)  Yukon Municipal Authority 2017 Revenue Note in the aggregate principal amount of $380,000.00. 
(6)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax Revenue Note, Series 2017 in the aggregate principal amount of $10,000,000.00. 
(7)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax Revenue Note, Series 2017B in the aggregate principal amount of $5,840,000.00. 
(8)  Yukon Municipal Authority 2018 Revenue Note in the aggregate principal amount of $825,000.00. 
(9)  Yukon Municipal Authority Sales Tax Revenue Note, Series 2018 in the aggregate principal amount of $5,675,000.00. 
(10)  Yukon Municipal Authority 2018A Revenue Note in the aggregate principal amount of $800,000.00. 
(Code 1975, § 2-18; Code 1995, § 2-137; Ord. No. 1084, § 1, 7-17-2001; Ord. No. 1092, § 1, 12-3-2001; Ord. No. 1101, § 1, 7-2-2002; Ord. No. 1104, § 1, 12-17-2002; Ord. No. 1134, § 1, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 11-16-2004; Ord. No. 1163, § 1, 1-3-2005; Ord. No. 1186, § 1, 11-15-2005; Ord. No. 1201, § 1, 1-16-2007; Ord. No. 1205, § 1, 3-20-2007; Ord. No. 1217, § 1, 1-15-2008; Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 10-6-2008; Ord. No. 1246, § 1, 11-3-2009; Ord. No. 1249, § 1, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 1260, § 1, 11-2-2010; Ord. No. 1261, § 1, 11-24-2010; Ord. No. 1270, § 1, 10-18-2011; Ord. No. 1277, § 1, 6-19-2012; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 10-16-2012; Ord. No. 1302, § 1, 10-21-2014; Ord. No. 1310, § 1, 2-10-2015; Ord. No. 1324, § 1, 9-3-2015; Ord. No. 1327, § 1, 10-20-2015; Ord. No. 1341, § 1, 10-18-2016; Ord. No. 1343, § 1, 4-18-2017; Ord. No. 1346, § 1, 7-18-2017; Ord. No. 1349 , § 1, 10-17-2017; Ord. No. 1360 , § 1, 5-15-2018; Ord. No. 1361 , § 1, 8-7-2018; Ord. No. 1377 , § 1, 11-6-2018) 
Sec. 2-200. - Compliance and operation in accordance with Municipal Budget Act. 
(a)  Election. The city elects to comply with and operate in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Municipal Budget Act (11 O.S. § 17-201 et seq.). 
(b)  Authorization to meet requirements. The chief executive officer, as defined by the Act, is hereby authorized to take such actions as are necessary to meet the requirements of the Act. 
(Code 1975, § 2-13; Code 1995, § 2-131) 
Sec. 2-201. - Review of invoices by department heads. 
    All invoices presented to the city for payment shall be reviewed by the appropriate department head. The department head shall examine each invoice and all supporting documentation to determine whether the claims should be paid, and shall make a recommendation to the city manager concerning payment. 
(Code 1975, § 2-13.1; Code 1995, § 2-132) 
Sec. 2-202. - Approval of invoice by city council upon recommendation by city manager. 
    The city manager, or his designee, shall make a recommendation to the city council concerning payment of each claim. The city council may approve a claim without reviewing the invoice and supporting documentation based on the recommendation of the department head and the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1975, § 2-15; Code 1995, § 2-133) 
Sec. 2-203. - Service charge on returned checks; deposit and disbursement of funds. 
(a)  There shall be a $30.00 service charge on all checks returned unpaid to the city. 
(b)  The city treasurer shall deposit daily all funds received for the city in such depositories as are designated by the city council. He shall disburse such funds in the manner provided by applicable law or ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 2-53; Code 1995, § 2-134; Ord. No. 1002, § 1, 9-17-2002) 
Sec. 2-204. - Security for deposits. 
    The deposits of the city shall be secured by the Security for Local Public Deposits Act, 62 O.S. § 517.1 et seq., and the provisions of such sections are hereby adopted in this section insofar as they are applicable to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-54; Code 1995, § 2-135) 
Sec. 2-205. - Authorization to develop internal control structures. 
    The city manager and all department heads shall develop additional internal control structures to provide reasonable assurance against unauthorized or illegal payment of invoices. 
(Code 1975, § 2-16; Code 1995, § 2-136) 
Sec. 2-206. - Fee to defray costs of collecting delinquent fines, fees, court costs, and mandatory state fees. 
    In accordance with 11 O.S. § 22-138, there is hereby imposed an additional fee for an amount as determined by the city for the collection of delinquent fines, fees, court costs, and other mandatory state fees due the City of Yukon that have been referred to a private agency for collection. 
(Ord. No. 1321, § 1, 7-17-2015) 
Secs. 2-207-2-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PURCHASES AND SALES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-236-2-263. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASES 

Sec. 2-264. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractual services means services performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city, and may include the use of equipment or the furnishing of commodities in connection with such services under express or implied contract. The term "contractual services" shall include travel; freight; express; parcel post; postage; telephone; telegraph; utilities; rents; printing and binding; repairs, alterations and maintenance of buildings, equipment, streets, bridges and other physical facilities of the city; and other services performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 2-19; Code 1995, § 2-216) 
Sec. 2-265. - By whom made. 
    All purchases of supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government shall be made by the city manager or by other city personnel in accordance with purchase authorizations issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 2-20; Code 1995, § 2-217) 
Sec. 2-266. - When council approval required. 
    Every contract for or purchase of supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services for more than $25,000.00 shall require the prior approval of the city council, and under no circumstances shall such contract or purchase be made without first obtaining the approval of the council, except in the case of a bona fide emergency. 
(Code 1975, § 2-21; Code 1995, § 2-218; Ord. No. 1042, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 1218, § 1, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 2-267. - General procedure. 
(a)  All contractual services and expenditures for other services performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city, the estimated cost of which is $25,000.00 or more, shall be purchased by competitive bidding procedures. 
(b)  All contractual services and expenditures for other services performed for the city by persons not in the employment of the city, the estimated cost of which is less than $25,000.00, shall be made by open market procedures. 
(Code 1975, § 2-22; Code 1995, § 2-219; Ord. No. 949, 6-4-1996; Ord. No. 1042, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 1218, § 1, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 2-268. - Purchasing program. 
    A purchasing program is established in concert with the desire to provide a cost-effective and efficient government, to ensure that the city purchases without prejudice, and to obtain the maximum value for each dollar of expenditure in accordance with established quality standards. 
(Code 1975, § 2-23; Code 1995, § 2-220) 
Sec. 2-269. - Purchasing agent. 
(a)  The city manager, or his designee, shall be the city's purchasing agent, hereafter referred to as "the agent." 
(b)  The agent is authorized to purchase or contract for all supplies, services and equipment needed by the city in accordance with policies and procedures prescribed by the city council and such rules and regulations as the city manager shall adopt for the internal management and operation of the purchasing function. 
(c)  The agent shall be responsible for: 
(1)  Procuring products and contracts of the highest quality and at the least expense. 
(2)  Endeavoring to obtain as full and open competition as possible. 
(3)  Establishing rules and regulations as necessary for the purchasing operation. 
(4)  Making every reasonable and financially sound attempt to solicit bids and quotations, and purchase supplies, services and equipment from vendors located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(5)  Prescribing and maintaining such forms needed to implement this division. 
(6)  Maintaining documentation on all purchasing activities. 
(7)  Exploiting the possibilities of buying in bulk so as to take full advantage of discounts. 
(8)  Procuring all federal tax exemptions to which the city is entitled. 
(9)  Declaring vendors as ineligible in accordance with the provisions of section 2-273. 
(Code 1975, § 2-24; Code 1995, § 2-221) 
Sec. 2-270. - Purchasing procedures. 
(a)  Except as provided in this division, no city officer or employee shall order the purchase of supplies, services, or equipment or make any contract within the purview of this division other than through the agent. Any purchase order or contract, other than valid emergency purchases made in accordance with this division, that are contrary to the provisions of this purchasing program shall not be approved by the agent, nor shall the city be bound to pay for such purchases or contracts. 
(b)  A purchase requisition must be submitted to the agent prior to the execution of any contract. 
(c)  A purchase requisition must be submitted to the agent prior to any purchase of noncontractual supplies, services and equipment, unless: 
(1)  The purchase of an item is made under an approved blanket purchase order (BPO). 
(2)  The purchase of an item is made with petty cash funds, provided that the purchase does not exceed a total of $25.00 and a blanket purchase order for the desired vendor does not exist. 
(d)  Upon receiving a requisition, the agent shall comply with the following procedures: 
(1)  Reject or amend any purchase requisition that is not consistent with the provisions of this division or in the best interests of the city. 
(2)  If the purchase of supplies or materials is less than $2,000.00, no special action is required. 
(3)  If the purchase of supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services is $2,001.00 to $24,999.00, apply open market procedures. Three phone quotes are required. 
(4)  If the purchase of supplies, materials, equipment and contractual services is $25,000.00 or more, apply formal competitive bidding procedures. 
(e)  The agent may issue a BPO to purchase supplies, materials and equipment. There are two types of BPOs: 
(1)  An open BPO that is used to purchase supplies, materials and equipment of nominal value on an "as needed" basis from a vendor that is used frequently by the city. At the agent's discretion, an open order may be issued by the department, remain in effect for up to one year and in an amount determined by the agent. 
(2)  A closed BPO is used for contracts for goods and services that are awarded after a competitive bidding process. The length of the purchase order shall not exceed one year, unless specified by the contract. 
(Code 1975, § 2-25; Code 1995, § 2-222; Ord. No. 949, 6-4-1996; Ord. No. 1042, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 1218, § 1, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 2-271. - Open market procedures. 
(a)  All open market purchases shall, wherever possible, be based upon at least three price quotes. 
(b)  The agent shall solicit price quotes for open market purchases and select the lowest and best quoting vendors subject to those considerations in section 2-272(j)(1)-(7), inclusive, by any of the following three methods: 
(1)  By direct mail request to prospective vendors; 
(2)  By telephone; or 
(3)  By public notice posted on the bulletin board of the city hall. 
(c)  The agent shall keep a record of all open market orders and bids submitted in competition, and such records shall be open to public inspection at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1995, § 2-222.1; Ord. No. 949, 6-4-1996) 
Sec. 2-272. - Bid procedures. 
(a)  Unless noted as an exception below, any supply, service, equipment or contract that is valued at $25,000.00 or more shall be subject to this competitive bidding process: 
(1)  Supplies, materials, equipment or contracts purchased through an officially recognized state purchasing agency bid are exempt. (Items listed in a "state contract" are examples of this exemption.) The agent, however, may initiate a formal bidding process if he believes a cheaper price may be obtained. 
(2)  Emergency purchases may be made if less than $25,000.00, and when the purchase of supplies, materials or equipment are needed because a condition exists which would endanger the safety, health or welfare of the public and/or would cause extreme financial loss to the city. Purchases in excess of $25,000.00 may be authorized by the council at an emergency, special or regular meeting. 
(3)  Contractual services (gas, electricity, telephone, cable television and the like) purchased from a public utility at a price or rate determined by the state corporation commission or other government authority or by an approved franchise agreement with the city. 
(4)  The competitive bidding provisions of this division may not apply to professional services provided by, but not limited to, attorneys, engineers, certified public accountants, financial underwriters, insurance agents or carriers for the purchase of insurance or loss control services, planners or other professional services exempted by the council. 
(5)  The competitive bidding provisions of this division shall not apply to the hiring of temporary employees, including contracts with firms, businesses, or other entities to provide temporary employment services for the city; provided that the contract or temporary employment relationship can be terminated at the will of the city, and without advance notice to the supplier of the temporary employee services; and provided that the city shall obtain at least three quotes over the telephone from vendors who have previously provided the city with evidence of state-approved workers' compensation coverage indemnifying the city and the qualifying vendor with the lowest and best proposal. The city manager shall have the authority to enter into a contract on behalf of the city, provided that the provisions of this subsection are met. 
(b)  The agent shall ensure that the appropriate specifications and the request for bid package are prepared. The department requesting the purchase shall provide assistance to the agent necessary in the development of the specifications and bid package. 
(c)  Every bid process shall begin with a public notice which shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation and posted at city hall. 
(d)  The agent shall make a reasonable attempt to notify potentially interested vendors who are located within the city limits of the bid request. 
(e)  All bids shall be submitted to the agent in a sealed envelope or packet that shall be identified as "SEALED BID" on the outside of the container. When the bid is received, the receiving party shall indicate the time, date and his initials on the bid container. 
(f)  All bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notice by the agent, or designee, and a city employee acting as a witness. 
(g)  A tabulation of all bids received may be posted in the city hall for public inspection. 
(h)  The city shall have the authority to reject the bid package or any and all bids and any part or provision of a bid or the bid proposal when it is deemed to be in the best interest of the city. The city also reserves the right to waive any irregularity of the bidding process. Additionally, the city has the authority to direct the readvertisement or resolicitation of any bid. 
(i)  In the case of a tie, either bidder may be selected or the purchase may be divided among those tying, if it is advantageous to the city. 
(j)  It is the responsibility of the agent to review and investigate all bids received and to make a recommendation to the city regarding the award to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, the agent shall consider the following: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract to provide the services promptly or within the required time periods without delay or interference. 
(3)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. 
(4)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and/ordinances of the city. 
(5)  The financial resources and the ability of the bidder to perform or provide the service. 
(6)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or services. 
(7)  Whether a bidder is entitled to receive a local preference in accordance with section 2-274. 
(k)  In the event annual purchases of like goods (meters, asphalt, etc.) are expected to exceed the $2,000.00 or $25,000.00 threshold, the purchase shall be treated as subject to the $2,000.00 open market or $25,000.00 bid procedure requirements. 
(Code 1975, § 2-26; Code 1995, § 2-223; Ord. No. 949, 6-4-1996; Ord. No. 1042, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 1218, § 1, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 2-273. - Ineligible vendors. 
(a)  The agent is authorized to declare a vendor as ineligible to receive any business from the city if the agent determines that the vendor: 
(1)  Has previously provided poor service to the city. 
(2)  Has previously provided products of poor quality or undesirable features to the city. 
(3)  Is not financially able to provide the product or service. 
(4)  Charges more than the bid or estimate, plus any change orders or amendments. 
(5)  Cannot provide the product or service that the city's specifications require. 
(6)  Cannot meet or provide the conditions, credentials, or qualifications that the city's specifications require. 
(7)  Has a conflict of interest as stated in section 2-275. 
(b)  Ineligible vendors are banned from providing products, services and contracts to the city in accordance with the following timetable: 
Action Time Period First time declared ineligible 3 months Second time declared ineligible 6 months Third time declared ineligible 1 year Fourth time declared ineligible Permanently Conflict of interest Until 
conflict ends  
(c)  The council may permanently disqualify a vendor from providing products, services or contracts to the city if the council determines that such action would be in the best interest of the community. 
(d)  An ineligible or disqualified vendor may appeal to the council for a change in status. 
(Code 1975, § 2-27; Code 1995, § 2-224) 
Sec. 2-274. - American, Oklahoman, and Yukon preferences. 
(a)  The city shall make a reasonable attempt to ensure that every purchased product or service is manufactured or assembled in the United States of America. 
(b)  The city shall make a reasonable attempt to do business with state firms and purchase state-made products. 
(c)  The city shall make a reasonable and economical attempt to purchase supplies, services, and equipment or make contractual arrangements with firms located within the city. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to grant local preference status to businesses located within the city, and award a bid, authorize a contract or make a purchase with the firm if its bid, estimation or listed price is no more than five percent higher than the bid, estimation or listed price of the lowest vendor. 
(Code 1975, § 2-28; Code 1995, § 2-225) 
Sec. 2-275. - Conflicts of interest. 
(a)  Any purchase order or contract within the purview of this division in which the agent or any officer or employee of the city is financially interested, directly or indirectly, shall be void, except the council shall have the authority to waive compliance with this section when it finds such action to be in the best interests of the city. 
(b)  The agent and every council member, officer and employee of the city shall not directly or indirectly solicit any gift or accept or receive any gift, whether in the form of money, services, loans, promises or any other form, under circumstances in which it could reasonably be inferred that the gift was intended to influence them, or could be reasonably expected to influence them, in the performance of their official duties, or was intended as a reward for any official action on their part. 
(Code 1975, § 2-29; Code 1995, § 2-226) 
Sec. 2-276. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of this section, the purchasing agent may exempt from competitive bidding procedures a requisition for a sole source or sole brand acquisition. 
(1)  In order to make a sole source or sole brand acquisition, when the acquisition exceeds $2,000.00 and unless the acquisition is not otherwise exempted, the purchasing agent shall retain in the acquisition file an affidavit signed by the department director substantially in the following form: 
SOLE SOURCE OR SOLE BRAND 
ACQUISITION AFFIDAVIT 
    Department _____ 
    Supplier Name _____ 
    Supplier Address _____ 
    Supplier Telephone _____ 
    I hereby affirm that the acquisition pursuant to the provisions of the attached requisition or contract is very specialized or requires great expertise and to the best of my knowledge (name of supplier) is the only person or business entity which is singularly and peculiarly qualified to provide the acquisition, and if a product is the only brand/or product which is singularly and peculiarly unique, for the following reasons: 
____________________ 
    The following is a brief description of all efforts which were made to verify that the services or products to be purchased pursuant to the provisions of the attached requisition or contract qualify as a sole source or sole brand acquisition: 
____________________ 
    I understand that the signing of this affidavit knowing such information to be false may subject me to punishment for perjury. 
_____
Department Director  
STATE OF OKLAHOMA )  ) ss COUNTY OF CANADIAN )  
    Subscribed and sworn to before me this _____ day of _______, 20___. 
_____
Notary Public  
My commission expires: 
_____ 
(2)  Any person affirming the affidavit required by this subsection who knows the information to be false shall be deemed guilty of perjury and, upon conviction, punished pursuant to law. Upon conviction or upon entering a plea of nolo contendere pursuant to this subsection, the person shall immediately forfeit his position and shall be ineligible for appointment to or employment in the service of the city. 
(3)  Upon determination by the city manager that there are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this subsection has occurred, the manager shall send findings to the city attorney that support the determination. The city attorney shall review the findings and determine whether to investigate or prosecute the person. 
(4)  Prior to submitting a requisition for a sole source or sole brand acquisition for payment, the purchasing agent shall document reasons sole source or sole brand purchase is necessary and shall retain a written record for three years following the end of the fiscal year during which the sole source or sole brand acquisition was paid. 
(b)  It is the city's policy not to endorse or permit an employee's name, position or the city's name to be used and/or advertised as supporting or endorsing a product or vendor. 
(c)  The agent shall have the authority to require such bonds in cash or otherwise for such amount that he may deem sufficient to secure the execution and performance of a contract for furnishing goods or services for the best interests of the city. 
(d)  No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this division. 
(e)  It is the intent of the city that all provisions contained in this division shall be in addition to state-mandated procedures, and that nothing in this division shall affect the applicability of those statutes. 
(Code 1975, § 2-30; Code 1995, § 2-227; Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 7-6-2000) 
Secs. 2-277-2-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SALES OF SURPLUS SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 2-301. - General authority. 
    The city manager may sell or issue authorizations for the sale of surplus or obsolete supplies, materials and equipment, subject to the provisions of the Charter and this division. 
(Code 1975, § 2-34; Code 1995, § 2-241) 
Sec. 2-302. - When council action required. 
    No surplus or obsolete supplies, materials, or equipment of a value of more than $500.00 may be sold until the council shall have declared them obsolete or surplus. 
(Code 1975, § 2-35; Code 1995, § 2-242) 
Sec. 2-303. - General procedure. 
    Before the city manager sells any surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment, except as otherwise provided in section 2-304, he shall advertise them for sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city or give notice in such other manner as he deems necessary to adequately reach prospective buyers and give them an opportunity to make bids. All bids shall be sealed and shall be opened in public at a designated time and place, except when the sale is by auction. The city manager may repeatedly reject all bids and advertise or give notice again. He shall sell such supplies, materials or equipment to the highest responsible bidder for cash. In case of a tie, he may sell to either of the bidders tying, or may divide the sale among two or more tying bidders, always selling to the highest responsible bidder for cash. 
(Code 1975, § 2-36; Code 1995, § 2-243) 
Sec. 2-304. - When competitive bidding not required. 
    The city manager may sell the following without giving an opportunity for competitive bidding: 
(1)  Surplus or obsolete supplies, materials or equipment, the total value of which does not exceed $1,000.00 in a single transaction. 
(2)  Supplies, materials or equipment, when sold at a price, at least as great as that paid by the city for the same. 
(Code 1975, § 2-37; Code 1995, § 2-244) 
Secs. 2-305-2-326. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-327. - Appointment of members. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided, it shall be mandatory that new appointments by the city council to any commission or board of the city whose membership consists of four or more members which are appointed by the city council, be made so as to allow representation from each ward within the city, unless the nominating council member nominates an individual who does not reside in the same ward as the nominating council member as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(b)  If a member of any board or commission shall be absent from more than one half of all meetings of the board or commission, regular or special, held within any period of six consecutive months, he shall thereupon cease to be a member of the board or commission. The chairperson of the board or commission shall report to the mayor as to this absenteeism. 
(c)  Unless otherwise provided, a majority of all the duly appointed members of a board or commission shall constitute a quorum to do business. 
(d)  Unless otherwise provided, all commissions and boards shall consist of five members, one from each of the four wards of the city and one member at large. Each member shall be a resident of the city. To be appointed to a board or commission, an individual shall be nominated by the council member from his ward, or the council member at large, and approved by the city council; provided, however, the nominating council member may nominate an individual from another ward, if the nominating member believes that such action would be in the city's best interest. 
(e)  Each appointed member of a board or commission shall hold office for a term of three years, ending at 7:30 p.m. on the third Tuesday in June, or until his successor takes office; except that, in the first instance, the nomination of the Ward I and the nomination of the Ward II council members shall be appointed to serve until 7:30 p.m. on the third Tuesday in June, in 1994; the nomination of the at-large council member shall be appointed to serve until that time in 1995; and the nomination of the Ward III and the nomination of the Ward IV council members shall be appointed to serve until that time in 1996. The term of each member of a board or commission shall correspond with the term of the nominating council member. Vacancies occurring otherwise than through the expiration of a term shall be filled only for the unexpired term. 
(f)  A change in ward boundaries shall not disqualify a member of a board or commission from completing the term for which he was appointed. Removal of a member from one ward to another after his appointment shall disqualify him from office. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired terms in the same manner as original appointments. 
(Code 1975, § 2-9; Code 1995, § 2-266) 
Sec. 2-328. - Required vote for binding action. 
    Unless otherwise provided, a majority vote of all the duly appointed or elected members of a board, committee or commission shall be required to pass or approve an item that is before it. 
(Code 1995, § 2-267; Ord. No. 952, 7-2-1996) 
Secs. 2-329-2-359. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ACCESSIBILITY COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-360. - Created. 
    There is created the city accessibility commission. 
(Code 1975, § 2-221; Code 1995, § 2-276) 
Sec. 2-361. - Composition, appointment, term of members. 
    Each appointed member of the accessibility commission shall be nominated, confirmed and serve a term of office as provided in section 2-327. 
(Code 1975, § 2-222; Code 1995, § 2-277; Ord. No. 932, § 1, 12-5-1995) 
Sec. 2-362. - Vacancies. 
    If a vacancy shall occur in the membership of the city accessibility commission, such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in like manner as original appointments. 
(Code 1975, § 2-223; Code 1995, § 2-278) 
Sec. 2-363. - Removal of members. 
    The mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, may remove any member of the city accessibility commission at any time. 
(Code 1975, § 2-224; Code 1995, § 2-279) 
Sec. 2-364. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the city accessibility commission shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for any expenses incurred while carrying out the duties of the commission. 
(Code 1975, § 2-225; Code 1995, § 2-280) 
Sec. 2-365. - Meetings. 
    All meetings of the city accessibility commission shall be public. The commission's regular meetings shall be held each month, at a time and date to be set by the commission. 
(Code 1975, § 2-226; Code 1995, § 2-281) 
Sec. 2-366. - Organization. 
    There shall be a chairperson, vice-chairperson, and secretary of the city accessibility commission elected by the commission, and at its pleasure, removed. 
(Code 1975, § 2-227; Code 1995, § 2-282) 
Sec. 2-367. - Record of proceedings. 
    The city accessibility commission shall keep and preserve a true record of all its proceedings and official acts, and such record of proceedings shall be attested by the secretary. 
(Code 1975, § 2-229; Code 1995, § 2-283) 
Sec. 2-368. - Functions. 
    The city accessibility commission shall serve as an advisory commission to the city and the city council, and shall make recommendations concerning: 
(1)  Making city municipal facilities accessible to all those with physical disabilities; 
(2)  Encouraging and assisting the private sector to become accessible; 
(3)  The new development and implementation of a disability awareness campaign that projects a positive impression of individuals in the community who are disabled; and 
(4)  Act as an advisor on new commercial, office and industrial construction projects. 
(Code 1975, § 2-230; Code 1995, § 2-284) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES AND LOW-POINT BEER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, 37 O.S. § 502 et seq.; low-point beer, 37 O.S. § 163.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Permitting intoxicated persons in restaurants, places of recreation, etc. 
    No person operating a café, restaurant, club or any place of recreation shall permit any person to be drunk or intoxicated in such place of business. 
(Code 1975, § 3-19; Code 1995, § 6-17; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Secs. 6-2-6-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, 37 O.S. § 502 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-21. - Definitions. 
    All words, phrases and terms used in this article shall be interpreted and construed in conformity with the definitions of the same set forth in the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, O.S. § 37A-1-103, with the same force and effect as if set out at length herein, and such definitions are made a part of this section by reference. 
(Code 1975, § 3-1; Code 1995, § 6-1; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 6-22. - Unlawful manufacture, sale, possession, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, barter, sell, give away or otherwise furnish to another, or to receive or use any alcoholic beverage of any kind, except as permitted by law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or under his control, or to transport or in any manner convey from place to place within the city, any alcoholic beverage, except as permitted by law. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or aid or abet in keeping or maintaining a place where any alcoholic beverage is manufactured, sold, bartered, given away or otherwise furnished in violation of state law or the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 3-2; Code 1995, § 6-2; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 6-23. - Purchase only from licensed dealers. 
    No person shall buy any alcoholic beverages, either at retail or wholesale, from any person other than a licensed dealer under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1975, § 3-4; Code 1995, § 6-4; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 6-24. - Application for certificate; investigations; issuance of certificate of zoning and certificate of compliance; definitions. 
(a)  Every applicant for a certificate of compliance with the zoning, fire, health and safety codes of the city required by the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act (O.S. § 37A-1-101 et seq.) shall apply at the office of the city clerk by: 
(1)  Filing a written application on forms prescribed by that office; and 
(2)  Paying a verification and certification fee in the amount established by resolution at the time of filing. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of compliance, the city clerk shall cause an investigation to be made to determine whether the premises proposed for licensed operations complies with the provisions of the zoning ordinance and any health, fire, building and other safety codes applicable to it. 
(c)  The city clerk shall act on all such applications within 20 days of receipt thereof. 
(d)  Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in compliance with all applicable zoning ordinances, a certificate of zoning shall be issued to the alcoholic beverage laws enforcement (ABLE) commission. 
(e)  Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in compliance with all applicable fire, safety, and health codes, a certificate of compliance shall be issued to the ABLE commission. 
(f)  The above certificates of compliance shall be signed by the mayor. 
(Code 1975, § 3-33; Code 1995, § 6-45; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 523(B). 
Secs. 6-25-6-51. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PACKAGE STORES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1387 , adopted Feb. 19, 2019, repealed the former Div. 2, §§ 6-52-6-55, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1975, §§ 3-8-3-11; Code 1995, §§ 6-6-6-9. 

Sec. 6-52. - Sale of alcoholic beverages packaged with nonalcoholic promotional items. 
    A retailer may offer for sale and sell alcoholic beverages which are packaged or are to be packaged with nonalcoholic promotional items, if such packaging and all nonalcoholic promotional items are provided by the manufacturer or agent of the manufacturer at the expense of the manufacturer or agent of the manufacturer, regardless of where such packages are assembled. 
(Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 534(C). 
Sec. 6-53. - Operation of package stores prohibited during certain hours and on certain days. 
    No person holding a state package store license shall sell or keep the package store premises open for the purpose of selling any alcoholic beverages at any hour other than between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday; provided that no such sales shall be made, or package store premises be allowed to remain open for the purpose of making such sales on New Year's Day, Memorial Day, the Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day or Christmas Day. Package store licensees shall be permitted to sell, or keep package store premises open for the purpose of selling, alcoholic beverages on the day of any general, primary, runoff primary or special election whether on a national, state, county or city election, provided that the election day does not occur on any day on which such sales are otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 537(C)(3). 
Sec. 6-54. - Containers not to be opened or beverages consumed in package store. 
(a)  No person holding a state package store license shall suffer or permit any retail container to be opened or any alcoholic beverage to be consumed on his licensed premises. 
(b)  No person shall open a retail container or consume alcoholic beverages on the premises of a retail package store. 
(Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 537(A)(3), (C)(3). 
Secs. 6-55-6-83. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - UNDERAGE PERSONS 

Sec. 6-84. - Persons under 21; misrepresentation of age to induce persons to sell or serve alcoholic beverages; entering or attempting to enter package store or bar area; penalties; substance abuse prevention program. 
(a)  No person holding a state package store license shall permit any person under 21 years of age to enter into, remain within or loiter about his licensed premises. 
(b)  No person under 21 years of age shall enter into, remain within or loiter about a retail package store. 
(Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1387 , adopted Feb. 19, 2019, repealed the former § 6-84 and enacted a new § 6-84 as set out herein. The former § 6-84 pertained to minors not permitted in package stores and derived from Code 1975, § 3-12 and Code 1995, § 6-10. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. §§ 537(C)(7), 538(E). 
Sec. 6-85. - Minors not to be employed in selling or handling. 
    No licensee of the ABLE Commission shall employ any person under the age of 21 in the selling or handling of alcoholic beverages. Provided that a mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event or bottle club licensee may employ servers who are at least 18 years of age, except persons under 21 years of age, may not serve in designated bar or lounge areas, and a mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event or bottle club licensee may employ or hire musical bands who have musicians who are under 21 years of age if each such musician is either accompanied by a parent or legal guardian or has on their person, to be made available for inspection upon demand by any ABLE commission officer or law enforcement officer, a written, notarized affidavit from the parent or legal guardian giving the underage musician permission to perform in designated bar or lounge areas. 
(Code 1975, § 3-13; Code 1995, § 6-11; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 537(B)(2). 
Sec. 6-86. - Sale or delivery to minors. 
    No person shall knowingly sell, deliver or furnish alcoholic beverages to any person under 21 years of age. 
(Code 1975, § 3-14; Code 1995, § 6-12; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 537(A)(1). 
Sec. 6-87. - Misrepresentation of age for purpose of buying. 
    No person under 21 years of age shall misrepresent his age, in writing or by presenting false documentation of age, for the purpose of inducing any person to sell him alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 1975, § 3-15; Code 1995, § 6-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 538(E). 
Sec. 6-88. - Possession by minors in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to be in possession of any alcoholic beverage as defined by O.S. § 37A-1-103 while such person is upon any public street, alley, road or highway or in any public building or place. 
(Code 1975, § 3-16; Code 1995, § 6-14; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 10A O.S. § 2-8-222. 
Sec. 6-89. - Sale or delivery to intoxicated, insane or mentally deficient persons. 
    No person shall knowingly sell, deliver or furnish alcoholic beverages to an intoxicated person or to any person who has been adjudged insane or mentally deficient. 
(Code 1975, § 3-17; Code 1995, § 6-15; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 537(A)(2). 
Secs. 6-90-6-106. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - OCCUPATION TAX ON RETAILERS AND WHOLESALERS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to levy an occupation tax generally, 37 O.S. § 554.1; maximum fee, 37 O.S. § 518. 

Sec. 6-107. - Levied; amount. 
    There is hereby levied and assessed an annual occupation tax on every business or occupation relating to alcoholic beverages as specifically enumerated herein and in the amount established by resolution. 
(1)  Brewer. 
(2)  Distiller. 
(3)  Winemaker. 
(4)  Oklahoma winemaker. 
(5)  Rectifier. 
(6)  Wholesaler. 
(7)  Class B wholesaler. 
(8)  Retail package store. 
(9)  Mixed beverage. 
a.  Initial. 
b.  Renewal. 
(10)  Caterer. 
a.  Initial. 
b.  Renewal. 
(11)  Special event, per day. 
(12)  Beer and wine license. 
a.  Initial. 
b.  Renewal. 
    The annual occupational tax for the privilege of operating a business or occupation relating to alcoholic beverages as specifically enumerated above, within the city, shall not exceed the state license fee for such licenses. 
(Code 1975, § 3-30(a); Code 1995, § 6-41; Ord. No. 913, §§ 1, 2, 8-1-1995; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 6-108. - Fee for mixed beverage, bottle club. 
    The annual license fee for a mixed beverage or bottle club license for those service organizations or fraternal beneficiary societies which are exempt under Section 501(c)(19), (8) and (10) of the Internal Revenue Code shall be as established by resolution. 
(Code 1975, § 3-30(b); Code 1995, § 6-42) 
Sec. 6-109. - Payment required; penalty. 
(a)  Any state licensee originally entering upon any occupation herein listed shall pay the tax therefor at the office of the development services on or before the date upon which he enters such occupation. Such licensee shall provide a copy of his current state license before payment of an occupation tax will be accepted. Thereafter, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before April 1. 
(b)  The occupation tax subject to this division shall be prorated on a monthly basis for the year in which an occupation begins operations, but shall be nonrefundable. 
(c)  Upon payment of such occupation tax, the development services department shall issue a receipt to such state licensee, which such licensee shall post in a conspicuous place on the premises wherein he carries on his occupation. 
(d)  Any person who engages in any of the occupations taxed by this division without paying the occupation tax imposed therefor in advance of such operation is guilty of an offense against the city, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 3-31; Code 1995, § 6-43; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 6-110. - Annual report. 
    The development services department shall make an annual report to the ABLE commission, covering the fiscal year, showing the number and class of licensees subject to the occupation tax and the amount of money collected from said tax. 
(Code 1975, § 3-32; Code 1995, § 6-44; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
State Law reference- Annual report if an occupational tax levy required, 37 O.S. § 554.1. 
Sec. 6-111. - Failure to pay. 
    Any person who shall fail to pay the occupation tax levied by this division, when the same shall become due, shall be deemed guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in accordance with Section 1-7. Each day's failure to pay such tax shall be deemed and considered a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 3-34; Code 1995, § 6-46; Ord. No. 1387 , 2-19-2019) 
Secs. 6-112-6-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOW-POINT BEVERAGES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Low-point beer, 37 O.S. § 163.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-136. - Adoption by reference. 
    The definitions concerning intoxicating liquors contained in 37 O.S. § 163.2 are adopted by reference in this section as if fully set out herein. 
(Code 1975, § 3-95; Code 1995, § 6-66) 
Sec. 6-137. - Sale prohibited during certain hours on Sunday. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, dispense or serve for consumption on the premises beverages containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume and not more than 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. on Sunday and 12:00 noon on Sunday. 
(Code 1975, § 3-96; Code 1995, § 6-67) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions and authority of city to prohibit Sunday sales, 37 O.S. § 213. 
Sec. 6-138. - Sale of low-point beer for off-premises consumption prohibited during certain hours. 
    The sale of low-point beer, as defined in 37 O.S. § 163.2, for off-premises consumption is hereby prohibited between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the same day. 
(Code 1995, § 6-67.1; Ord. No. 921, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Sec. 6-139. - Sale to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give any low-point beer to any person under 21 years of age. 
(Code 1975, § 3-97; Code 1995, § 6-68; Ord. No. 922, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 241. 
Sec. 6-140. - Possession by minors in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to be in possession of any low-point beer while such minor is upon any public street, alley, road or highway or in any public building or place. 
(Code 1975, § 3-98; Code 1995, § 6-69; Ord. No. 923, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Sec. 6-141. - Permitting minors to loiter in sales premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining a place of business where low-point beer is sold for consumption on the premises to permit any minor to loiter in such place of business. 
(Code 1975, § 3-99; Code 1995, § 6-70; Ord. No. 924, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Sec. 6-142. - Permitting intoxicated persons to enter or loiter around sales premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining a place of business where low-point beer is sold for consumption on the premises to permit any intoxicated person to loaf or loiter or be in or about such place of business. 
(Code 1975, § 3-100; Code 1995, § 6-71; Ord. No. 925, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Sec. 6-143. - Sale on public easement, right-of-way, street, etc., prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any low-point beer from or on any public easement, right-of-way, street, road or highway within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 3-101; Code 1995, § 6-72; Ord. No. 926, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Secs. 6-144-6-169. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RETAILER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 6-170. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any retail dealer to sell, distribute or dispense any low-point beer within the city without having first obtained a license issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1975, § 3-106; Code 1995, § 6-86; Ord. No. 927, § 1, 11-21-1995) 
Sec. 6-171. - Application. 
    Application for a license required by this division shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 3-107; Code 1995, § 6-87) 
Sec. 6-172. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be as established by resolution. Such fee shall be paid to the city clerk at the time of issuance of the license. 
(Code 1975, § 3-108; Code 1995, § 6-88; Ord. No. 928, § 1, 11-21-1995; Ord. No. 985, 7-1-1997)

Sec. 6-173. - Issuance. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license applied for under this division upon payment of the required fee and a satisfactory showing that the applicant has obtained all state and county permits required by law and has, in all other respects, complied with the laws of the state and/ordinances of the city relating to the sale and distribution of low-point beer. 
(Code 1975, § 3-109; Code 1995, § 6-89) 
Sec. 6-174. - Not transferable. 
    No license issued under this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1975, § 3-110; Code 1995, § 6-90) 
Sec. 6-175. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall expire on April 30 next following the date of issuance. 
(Code 1975, § 3-111; Code 1995, § 6-91) 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POOL HALLS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Pool and billiards halls generally, 21 O.S. § 1102 et seq. 

Sec. 10-19. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Pool hall means a room, hall, place or building within the city in which any billiard or pool, or combination billiard and pool, tables are or may be kept or operated for hire. 
(Code 1975, § 4-11; Code 1995, § 10-26) 
Sec. 10-20. - License. 
    No person shall maintain or operate a pool hall within the city without first obtaining a license from the city clerk and paying therefor the sum established by resolution. The license shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance and shall be renewed upon paying the fees herein required from year to year. The license shall not be transferable and it may be revoked for violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 4-12; Code 1995, § 10-27) 
State Law reference- Public pool or billiard halls to be licensed by district court clerk, 21 O.S. § 1102; authority of city to levy license tax on such halls, 21 O.S. § 1104. 
Sec. 10-21. - Closure on Sunday, between 11:00 p.m. and daylight. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any pool hall to be open on Sunday or between 11:00 p.m. and daylight on any other day. 
(Code 1975, § 4-13; Code 1995, § 10-28) 
Sec. 10-22. - Prohibited conduct and conditions generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, maintain or permit in a pool hall any conduct or condition which annoys, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others. 
(Code 1975, § 4-15; Code 1995, § 10-29) 
Sec. 10-23. - Disorderly conduct; contests of strength or agility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any disorderly conduct or practice in a pool hall, or to engage or participate in any fight, boxing contest, wrestling match or other contest of physical strength or agility in a pool hall. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to create any loud noise that would disturb a reasonable person. 
(Code 1975, §§ 4-16, 4-17; Code 1995, §§ 10-30, 10-31) 
Sec. 10-24. - Immoral or indecent shows or exhibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or engage in any show or exhibition in a pool hall that is obscene under law. 
(Code 1975, § 4-18; Code 1995, § 10-32) 
Sec. 10-25. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble in any manner or to participate in any game of chance or lottery in a pool hall. 
(Code 1975, § 4-19; Code 1995, § 10-33) 
Sec. 10-26. - Selling, furnishing or drinking intoxicating liquor. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any intoxicating liquor in a pool hall. 
(Code 1975, § 4-20; Code 1995, § 10-34) 
Sec. 10-27. - Person in charge not to permit violations of article. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or other person in charge or control of any pool hall to knowingly permit any violations of this article in such hall. 
(Code 1975, § 4-21; Code 1995, § 10-35) 
Sec. 10-28. - Operation in violation of article a nuisance. 
    Any pool hall operated in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1975, § 4-22; Code 1995, § 10-36) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animals generally, 4 O.S. § 30.1 et seq.; injuries to animals, 21 O.S. § 1680 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandon means the act of placing an animal on public property or within a public building, unattended or uncared for, or on or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian, or tenant of the private property. An animal shall also be considered abandoned when it has been unattended and without adequate food, water, ventilation or shelter for a period in excess of 24 hours, regardless of where such animal may be found or kept. 
    Animal means any live, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, including, fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. 
    Animal control officer means any person employed or appointed by the city or county who is authorized to investigate and enforce violations relating to animal control or cruelty under the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Animal control office means the Yukon Animal Control Office. 
(2)  Animal control officer means any police officer or animal control officer in the Yukon Police Department. 
    Animal services means the organization or authority designated by the city to enforce animal control ordinances, provide temporary care for stray and surrendered animals and carry out other relevant animal-related governmental laws and programs. 
    Animal shelter means any facility designated or operated by the city, or its authorized agents, for the purpose of housing, impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this chapter or state law. 
    Animals ferae naturae means animals which are of a dangerous nature to mankind that are normally found in the wild, and shall not include domesticated animals. 
    At large means any animal, other than a dog, that is off the premises of the owner, while not under the supervision and control of the owner, or, in the case of dogs, any dog that is not at all times, whether on or off the premises of the owner, under the direct control of the owner. 
    Attack means the act by any animal of approaching a domestic animal or a person in such a manner that hostile contact with the other animal or person occurs, or if the act required a defensive action by any person to prevent bodily injury when such person is conducting himself peacefully and lawfully. Conduct of an animal, such as charging, growling, or chasing in a menacing fashion is considered an attack if a reasonable person believes such conduct threatens the safety and welfare of any person. 
    Auction means any place or facility where animals are regularly bought, sold, or traded, except for those facilities otherwise defined in this chapter. This definition does not apply to individual sale of animals by owners. 
    Baiting means to attack with violence, to provoke, or to harass an animal with one or more animals for the purpose of training an animal for, or to cause an animal to engage in fights with or among other animals. 
    Bite means that the skin has been penetrated by an animal's teeth or beak. 
    Citation means a written notice issued to a person by an officer stating that the officer has probable cause to believe that the person has committed an act or omission in violation of this chapter, and that the city court will hear the charge. 
    Commercial animal establishment means any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, riding school or stable, zoological park, circus or performing animal exhibition. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of Yukon Animal Control, or any law enforcement agency: 
(1)  Has aggressively bitten, attacked or endangered, or has inflicted severe injury on a human being or damaged property. 
(2)  Has more than once severely injured or killed a domestic animal while off the owner's property. 
(3)  Has been used primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting, or is a dog trained for dogfighting; or 
(4)  Has, when unprovoked, chased or approached a person upon the streets, sidewalks or any public grounds in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack; provided that such actions are attested to in a sworn statement by one or more persons and dutifully investigated by any of the above-referenced authorities. 
This definition shall not apply to dogs utilized by law enforcement officers in the performance of their duties. 
    Direct control means effective, immediate, continuous physical control of a dog at all times such as by means of a leash, lead, kennel, secure fence, or chain of such strength to restrain the dog and controlled by a responsible person capable of restraining the dog, or safe and secure restraint within a building or vehicle. If the controlling person is at all times fully and clearly within unobstructed sight and hearing of the dog, voice control shall be considered direct control when the dog is actually participating in certified training or in an official showing, obedience, or field event. Direct control shall not be required of dogs actually participating in a legal sport in an authorized area or of government police dogs. 
    Domestic animal means any animal whose natural habitat is with humans and is kept for pleasure or for utility, that has adapted to life in association with and to the use of human beings. 
    Ear tipping means straight-line cutting of the tip of the left or right ear of a cat while the cat is anesthetized and has been sterilized and given a rabies shot. A cat with a tipped ear is considered to be sterile and vaccinated against rabies. 
    Feral animal means any wild animal, whether it was born in the wild or reverted to a wild state due to abandonment or lack of domestication. 
    Fowl means poultry of any kind, including, but not limited to, chickens, pheasants, guineas, turkeys, peacocks, ducks and geese. 
    Humane officer means any person designated by the city or a law enforcement officer who is qualified to perform such duties under the laws of the state. 
    Impoundment means impoundment at a shelter or the taking or picking up and confining of an animal by an officer under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Kennel means any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs or cats; or any premises where more than three dogs or three cats over the age of six months are kept. 
    Legal responsibility means the owner as hereinafter defined shall be considered legally responsible for the actions of an animal and the care of an animal. In the absence of written proof of ownership, all adult members of the household shall be considered legally responsible. 
    Licensing authority means the City of Yukon. 
    Litter means the offspring produced at one birth by a mammal that normally bears several young during a delivery. 
    Livestock means all animals of the equine, bovine, ratite, or swine class. This includes goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle, ostriches, and other grazing animals. 
    Owner means any person, partnership, corporation, or other legal entity owning, keeping, or harboring one or more animals, or in the case of a person under the age of 18 years of age, that person's parent or legal guardian. An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for three consecutive days or more. The term "owner" may also mean a person legally competent to enter into a contract acquiring a dog or cat from a releasing agency. This definition shall not apply to any veterinary clinic or boarding kennel. 
    Performing animal exhibition means any display, spectacle, act or event, other than circuses, in which performing animals are used. 
    Pet means any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. 
    Pet grooming means a commercial establishment where animals are bathed, clipped, plucked or otherwise groomed. 
    Pet shop means any person, whether operated separately or in connection with another business enterprise, except for a licensed kennel, that buys, sells, or boards any species of animal. 
    Proper shelter for an outdoor animal shall include, but is not limited to, a permanent structure with four sides, a top and a bottom. The structure shall have a waterproof roof, be structurally sound, and shall be sufficiently insulated to protect the animal from the elements, with space to stand up, sit down, turn around and lie down in a normal posture. The structure and surrounding area needs to be free from trash or waste so as not to threaten the physical well-being of the animal. Examples of inadequate shelter include, but are not limited to, lean-tos, metal drums, cardboard boxes, abandoned vehicles, porches, decks, or material that does not provide sufficient protection from the elements. 
    Public nuisance means any animal which causes any harm and: 
(1)  Molests passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)  Unprovoked, attacks persons, other animals or fowl; 
(3)  Trespasses on school grounds; 
(4)  Is repeatedly at large; 
(5)  Damages or destroys private or public property; 
(6)  Barks, whines, or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely fashion, or emits any loud or offensive noise which offends adjoining residents; or 
(7)  Conduct by stray or feral cats that disturbs the peace by habitually and significantly destroying, desecrating or soiling property against the wishes of the owner of the property. 
    Releasing agency means any pound, shelter, or humane society organization, whether public or private. 
    Restraint means any animal secured by a leash or lead when off the owner's property. 
    Riding school or stable means any place which has available for hire, boarding and/or riding instructions, any horse, pony, donkey, mule, or burro. 
    Scratch means that the skin has been penetrated by an animal's claws, horn, or other appendage. 
    Spay means to remove the ovaries of a female dog or cat in order to render such animal unable to reproduce.
