Such rooms shall be fully enclosed, directly exhausted to the outside, and shall be under negative air pressure so that no smoke can escape when a door is opened and no air is recirculated to nonsmoking areas of the building. 
(d)  Restaurants shall be totally nonsmoking or may provide nonsmoking areas and designated smoking rooms. Food and beverage may be served in such designated smoking rooms which shall be in a location which is fully enclosed, directly exhausted to the outside, under negative air pressure so smoke cannot escape when a door is opened, and no air is recirculated to nonsmoking areas of the building. No exhaust from such room shall be located within 25 feet of any entrance, exit or air intake. Such room shall be subject to verification for compliance with the provisions of this subsection by the state department of health. 
(Code 1995, § 74-174; Ord. No. 1298, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 63 O.S. § 1-1522. 
Sec. 74-199. - Posting. 
(a)  The person who owns or operates a place where smoking or tobacco use is prohibited by law shall be responsible for posting a sign or decal, at least four inches by two inches in size, at each entrance to the building indicating that the place is smoke-free or tobacco-free. 
(b)  Responsibility for posting signs or decals shall be as follows: 
(1)  In privately owned facilities, the owner or lessee, if a lessee is in possession of the facilities, shall be responsible; 
(2)  In corporately owned facilities, the manager and/or supervisor of the facility involved shall be responsible; and 
(3)  In publicly owned facilities, the manager and/or supervisor of the facility shall be responsible. 
(Code 1995, § 74-175; Ord. No. 1298, § 1, 6-17-2014) 
Chapter 78 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to establish and maintain parks, playgrounds and other recreation facilities, 11 O.S. § 33-103; parks and recreation generally, 11 O.S. § 33-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Department of parks and recreation-Established. 
    There is hereby established a department of parks and recreation, the head of which shall be the director of parks and recreation. 
(Code 1975, § 16-1; Code 1995, § 78-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - Same-General duties. 
    The department of parks and recreation shall maintain and operate the community center and all parks, playgrounds, swimming pools and other recreational facilities and programs operated by the city, and shall perform such other duties as are prescribed by the city council or the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 16-2; Code 1995, § 78-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Park lakes-Swimming and wading prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim or wade in any lake or other body of water in a city park, except a swimming pool constructed and maintained for such purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 16-3; Code 1995, § 78-3) 
Sec. 78-4. - Same-Boats and rafts prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or place any boat, canoe or raft in or upon any lake or other body of water in any city park. 
(Code 1975, § 16-4; Code 1995, § 78-4) 
Sec. 78-5. - Park rules; penalty for violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to perform, engage in, conduct, or authorize any of the following activities in a city park or city facility, without the prior express written approval of the city: 
(1)  Disturb or harm any animal or fish, or disturb or destroy the nest of any bird, or disturb or destroy the den or nest or abode of any animal in any city park, provided, however, that fish may be taken for noncommercial purposes in accordance with state fishing laws. No person shall use a spear or bow and arrow in the course of such fishing activities; 
(2)  Injure, damage, destroy, disturb, or remove any flora (plants) or fauna (animals) in a city park, or disturb or remove any surface or subsurface materials; 
(3)  Deface, damage, destroy, disturb or remove any building, structure, sign, improvement, or facility in a city park; 
(4)  Solicit or sell any goods, wares, or merchandise of any nature whatsoever in a city park or facility, without the express written approval of the city; 
(5)  Build a fire, except in designated areas; 
(6)  Allow or permit an animal to enter or remain in a swimming pool, or the fenced area immediately around a swimming pool; 
(7)  Possess or carry a bow and/or arrow, an air or gas weapon, or other dangerous or deadly instrument; 
(8)  Enter or remain in any park or park facility in violation of the posted closing time; 
(9)  Operate a motor vehicle in any park area, except upon a parking lot or upon a roadway, clearly distinguished as such; 
(10)  Stop, stand/or park a vehicle in a park, except in parking lots or parking areas clearly marked as such; 
(11)  Stop, stand/or park a vehicle in a parking lot or parking area for a city park, except while utilizing the park or park facilities. In no event shall a parking lot or parking area for a park be utilized for private or residential parking; 
(12)  Ride, permit or allow a horse or other livestock to enter or remain in a city park; or 
(13)  Camp in any city park. 
(b)  Any person who violates any of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(c)  In addition to the punishment as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, any person who is found guilty of violating this section may be denied access to or the use of all park facilities and activities. 
(Code 1975, § 16-5; Code 1995, § 78-5) 
Secs. 78-6-78-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK BOARD 

Sec. 78-29. - Established; composition; appointment, terms and removal of members. 
(a)  The park board shall, from the effective date of the ordinance from which this section was derived, consist of five members nominated and confirmed as provided in section 2-327. Each appointed member of the park board shall serve a term of office as provided for in section 2-327. 
(b)  The city manager shall be an ex officio member of the park board, but shall have no vote. 
(c)  The mayor, with the approval of the city council, may remove a member at any time. 
(Code 1975, § 16-15; Code 1995, § 78-26) 
Sec. 78-30. - Members not compensated. 
    Members of the park board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1975, § 16-16; Code 1995, § 78-27) 
Sec. 78-31. - Election of officers. 
    Every year, at the time prescribed for the beginning of the term of a new member or members of the park board, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the park board shall elect a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a secretary. The secretary need not be a member of the board. 
(Code 1975, § 16-17; Code 1995, § 78-28) 
Sec. 78-32. - Meetings. 
    The park board shall determine the time and place of its regular meetings. The chairperson or any three members may call special meetings of the board. 
(Code 1975, § 16-18; Code 1995, § 78-29) 
Sec. 78-33. - Powers. 
(a)  The park board shall have power to make rules and regulations relating to the administration and operation of all parks, playgrounds, swimming pools and other recreational facilities and programs operated by the city, subject to the approval of the city council and any ordinances which the council may enact. 
(b)  The park board shall also have power to consider any matter relating to parks and other recreational facilities and programs, and to make proper recommendations thereon to the council, the city manager, the head of the administrative department in charge of such matters, or to others, as it deems appropriate. 
(Code 1975, § 16-19; Code 1995, § 78-30) 
Chapter 82 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Transient Merchant Licensing Act, 19 O.S. § 1601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Defined. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the term "solicitor" shall mean and include any person not having a fixed or established place of business in the city, and not representing any person, firm, partnership or corporation having a permanent established place of business in the city, who shall peddle, canvass or solicit from house to house, or upon any street or public place, for any money, goods, wares, merchandise, services, magazines, periodicals or other things of value. 
(Code 1995, § 82-1; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-2. - Exemptions from chapter. 
    This chapter shall not apply to persons selling personal property at wholesale to dealers in such property, nor to the sale or delivery of newspapers, nor to persons who offer for sale or sell, or who peddle and sell from house to house, vegetables, butter, eggs and farm products produced and raised on lands owned or controlled by them. 
(Code 1995, § 82-4; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-3. - Hours of permitted soliciting; hours for application. 
    No solicitor, whether registered under this chapter or not, shall take orders for or sell any goods, wares, merchandise, services, magazines, periodicals or other things of value except during the hours from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Applications for a solicitor's registration card shall be made only between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(Code 1995, § 82-2; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-4. - Orders to be in duplicate, etc. 
    All orders taken by solicitors wherein payment or deposit is made in advance of delivery shall be in writing in duplicate, stating the terms thereof, and the amount paid in advance. One copy shall be given to the purchaser. 
(Code 1995, § 82-3; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-5. - Soliciting in roadway and public right-of-way prohibited; exceptions. 
    Soliciting in roadways and public rights-of-way is prohibited, provided, however, the city police department may issue a special permit for soliciting in roadways and public rights-of-way upon written application, and further provided that proper safety devices and measures be implemented as directed in the special permit. 
(Code 1995, § 82-5; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Secs. 82-6-82-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGISTRATION CARD 

Sec. 82-29. - Required. 
    No solicitor shall peddle, canvass or solicit for money or peddle, canvass, solicit or sell any goods, wares, merchandise, services, magazines, periodicals or other things of value within the city without having first applied for and obtained a solicitor's registration card, for that purpose, from the police chief or his designee. The registration card must be kept on the person of the solicitor, on display and visible at all times. 
(Code 1995, § 82-15; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-30. - Application; applicant's photograph and fingerprints. 
    An applicant for a solicitor's registration card under the terms of this article shall be required to: 
(1)  Complete a registration form provided by the police department, which shall show the name of the person, firm or corporation on whose behalf the applicant proposes to solicit; the address of said person, firm or corporation; the kind of products, merchandise or service to be solicited; and any other pertinent facts as required to provide the police department with sufficient information to investigate the application. 
(2)  File a photograph and fingerprints with the police department. 
(3)  No license shall be issued under this article to any person under the age of 16 years except those persons and/organizations exempted under subsection 82-59(1). 
(4)  No license shall be issued less than three business days after a complete application is received. 
(Code 1995, § 82-16; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-31. - Applicant's bond. 
    Every applicant for a registration card required by this article, who shall require, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery of any goods, wares, or merchandise, shall file a surety bond, in the amount of $500.00, conditioned upon making final delivery of the goods ordered in accordance with the terms of such order, or failing therein, that the advance payment be refunded. Any person aggrieved by the action of the solicitor shall have a right of action on the bond for the recovery of the money or damages, or both. Such bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of 60 days after the expiration of any registration card issued under this article, unless sooner released by the city manager. 
(Code 1995, § 82-17; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-32. - Fee. 
(a)  A registration fee is hereby levied for the purpose of defraying the cost of registration on each person applying for registration with the police department as a solicitor. Such fee shall be as established by resolution. 
(b)  Any veteran who qualifies under 72 O.S. § 5 and those persons representing charitable associations or groups which have tax-exempt status shall be exempt from the payment of any registration fee under this section. 
(Code 1995, § 82-18; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-33. - Issuance or denial. 
    The police chief or his designee is hereby authorized to issue a solicitor's registration card in all proper cases and when the applicant has complied with this article. Registration may be denied any applicant for a solicitor's registration card, if he is not of good moral character; if he has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or has such criminal charges pending; or if the proposed sales proposition shall include some element of trickery, fraud or deceit, in which case in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare, the applicant shall not be registered. Any person aggrieved by the action of the police chief or his designee may appeal to the city council, and may appeal from the city council to the district court of the county in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1995, § 82-19; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-34. - Revocation. 
    Upon good cause, any registration card issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked. Revocation may be based upon the following, among other causes: 
(1)  Information received after the permit is issued; 
(2)  Violation of any federal, state or municipal law, rule or regulation; or 
(3)  Complaints by citizens. 
(Code 1995, § 82-20; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Secs. 82-35-82-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ENTERING POSTED PREMISES 

Sec. 82-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context otherwise requires. 
    Peddlers means any persons who go from house to house, place to place, or street to street, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise, or offering or exposing the same for sale, or making sales or delivering articles to the purchasers. 
    Solicitors means any persons who go from house to house, place to place, or street to street, soliciting anything of value, sales or taking orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise (including magazines, books, periodicals, realty, or tangible or intangible personal property of any nature, including insurance) and such orders for future delivery or for service to be performed in the future, irrespective of such persons having, carrying or exposing for sale a sample of the subject of such order, and irrespective of such persons collecting or not collecting advance payments on such orders. 
(Code 1995, § 82-25; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-58. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1995, § 82-28; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-59. - Exemptions. 
    Persons exempt from the provisions of this article are: 
(1)  Those persons representing charitable associations or groups which have tax-exempt status. 
(2)  Those peddlers or solicitors invited on the premises by the owner or occupant. 
(Code 1995, § 82-27; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Sec. 82-60. - Invitation required to enter on posted premises. 
    No peddler or solicitor shall enter on any premises or attempt to peddle or solicit where the owner or occupant of such premises has indicated his desire not to be contacted for sales or solicitations by the placing of a "No Solicitors" sign on the premises, and such entrance or attempt to peddle or solicit shall constitute a trespass upon private property. 
(Code 1995, § 82-26; Ord. No. 1250, § 1, 2-2-2010) 
Chapter 86 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 86-1-86-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIREFIGHTER AND POLICE OFFICER RETIREMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Firefighter retirement, 11 O.S. § 49-100.1 et seq.; police retirement, 11 O.S. § 50-101 et seq. 

Sec. 86-19. - To be operated in accordance with state law. 
    The police pension and retirement system and the Firemen's Relief and Pension Fund shall be operated in accordance with state law relating to the fund, and pensions and other benefits shall be paid as provided by state law. 
(Code 1975, § 17-12; Code 1995, § 86-26) 
Sec. 86-20. - Board of trustees, Firemen's Fund. 
    There is hereby created a board of trustees of the Firemen's Relief and Pension Fund of the city, with membership, organization, powers, duties and functions as prescribed by 11 O.S. § 49-103 et seq., and as may be provided by any later laws passed by the legislature relating to such board. 
(Code 1975, § 17-11; Code 1995, § 86-27) 
Chapter 90 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Solid Waste Management Act, 27A O.S. § 2-10-101 et seq.; municipal solid waste management systems, 27A O.S. § 2-10-901 et seq. 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Rubbish means solid and/ordinary waste, other than garbage, accumulated by family residents, including glass and broken wire, discarded clothing, trash, tin cans, bottles, papers and tree limbs, and grass and weed cuttings properly contained or bundled as prescribed in this chapter. 
    Solid waste means all putrescible and nonputrescible refuse in solid or semisolid form including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, ashes or incinerator residue, street refuse, dead animals, demolition wastes, construction wastes, solid or semisolid commercial and industrial wastes including explosives, biomedical wastes, chemical wastes, herbicide and pesticide wastes. The term "solid waste" shall not include: 
(1)  Scrap materials which are source separated for collection and processing as industrial raw materials, except when contained in the waste collected by or in behalf of a solid waste management system; or 
(2)  Used motor oil, which shall not be considered to be a solid waste, but shall be considered a deleterious substance, if the used motor oil is recycled for energy reclamation and is ultimately destroyed when recycled. 
(Code 1975, § 10-1; Code 1995, § 98-1) 
Sec. 90-2. - Duty to request and use city's collection service. 
    To assist in maintaining the general sanitation and health of the city, it shall be the duty of every person occupying or having control of the occupancy of any premises located on a regularly established solid waste route to notify the city clerk at the beginning of such occupancy and request, accept and use the solid waste pickup and collection service; provided, however, that failure of any owner, rental agent or occupant of such premises to make such request shall not prevent or in any way impair or impede the department of public works from adding the address of such premises to the proper collection route records and providing such service and otherwise enforcing by appropriate action the regulatory measures prescribed in this chapter and causing the fees or charges therefor to be paid. 
(Code 1975, § 10-2; Code 1995, § 98-2) 
Sec. 90-3. - Private hauling of garbage and rubbish prohibited; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person not under contract with the city to haul any solid waste over the city streets; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to preclude a person from removing rubbish from his own premises, at his own expense, and hauling the same over city streets, provided it is done in a neat and sanitary manner. 
(b)  In addition to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, any private commercial hauler of solid waste may provide disposal services and may haul solid waste over city streets for commercial or other miscellaneous establishments utilizing or requiring garbage service for the disposal of more than 300 cubic yards of solid waste per month; provided, however: 
(1)  That any business hauling or disposing of solid waste pursuant to this section shall be required to pay to the city a business or occupational license tax in the amount of $100.00 per year, per pickup location. This tax shall be governed by the provisions of chapter 18. 
(2)  That the commercial or other miscellaneous user request in writing that it be allowed to use the services of a private hauler. 
(Code 1975, § 10-3; Code 1995, § 98-3; Ord. No. 1243, § 1, 7-7-2009; Ord. No. 1251, § 1, 2-2-2010; Ord. No. 1288, § 1, 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 90-4. - Littering prohibited; general container requirements. 
(a)  No person shall throw, sweep, deposit or place any solid waste in any alley, street or other public place within the city, nor shall any person deposit or place it upon private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the limits of the city, unless the same is enclosed in a suitable container. 
(b)  Containers referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be 90-gallon plastic carts or one-, two-, or three-yard dumpsters on wheels. Such carts or dumpsters, and the grounds immediately around the same will be kept in a safe and sanitary condition at all times. 
(c)  One plastic cart will be furnished to each residence and to each small business establishment having a low enough volume of solid waste that it can be accommodated in one 90-gallon cart. 
(d)  Any resident or business establishment may purchase additional carts at the cost of such carts to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 10-4; Code 1995, § 98-4) 
State Law reference- Littering prohibited, 21 O.S. §§ 1753.3, 1761.1. 
Sec. 90-5. - Placement of carts for collection. 
(a)  By 6:00 a.m. on the day of pickup, the 90-gallon plastic carts shall be placed in the street right-of-way adjacent to the curb or edge of the street surface whereby collectors can obtain same without going on to private property. The business establishments providing carts or dumpsters may place carts or dumpsters in the rear of the establishment near the alley right-of-way, providing availability of alley access is maintained. 
(b)  Carts shall be removed from the street right-of-way and returned to a location behind the front building line of the residence within 24 hours after the cart has been emptied by the collectors. Residents will be furnished once a week pickup. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5; Code 1995, § 98-5) 
Sec. 90-6. - Responsibility for repair of carts. 
    The city shall be responsible for all normal wear and tear upon carts provided for by this chapter, but any damage done through neglect or omission of the resident shall be repaired by the city and the cost of such repair shall be added to the next bill. Failure of the resident to promptly pay for such repair shall give the city the right to terminate water and solid waste service to the resident. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5.1; Code 1995, § 98-6) 
Sec. 90-7. - Vandalism or damage to carts; punishment. 
    The vandalism or damage done to a cart by a party not the resident (third party) is declared to be a misdemeanor punishable in the municipal court and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5.2; Code 1995, § 98-7) 
Sec. 90-8. - Return of carts upon termination of service; replacement of carts with dumpster. 
(a)  Upon a resident or businessman terminating his solid waste service, the resident or businessman will account for the cart provided by the city and return the same in good and working condition, normal wear and tear excepted, and the failure to return such cart shall result in the total value of the cart being charged against the resident or businessman on his final bill. 
(b)  Any businessman who has purchased additional carts and wishes to purchase a dumpster to replace the carts may trade in the carts upon purchase of a dumpster. Allowance for value of carts shall be based on condition of the carts as determined by the sanitation superintendent. In no case will such value exceed the original cost of the carts. 
(c)  Repair and maintenance of dumpsters. The owner of a dumpster who is also a utility customer of the city may request, in writing, that the city be responsible for the repair, maintenance, cleaning, painting and rehabilitation of the dumpster upon terms and conditions as determined by the director of public works. The city may accept or reject the request. If the request is accepted, services shall be provided at least quarter annually and more often if necessary. The cost of the service shall be determined by the director of public works each fiscal year. The cost of the service shall be included in the owner's utility bill. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5.3; Code 1995, § 98-8; Ord. No. 1245, § 1, 10-6-2009) 
Sec. 90-9. - Placement of substances deleterious to carts prohibited. 
    No substances which are deleterious to the plastic cart shall be placed in them and if such cart is damaged by a substance placed therein, the expense of repair will be charged to the resident in accordance with section 90-6. 
(Code 1975, § 10-5.4; Code 1995, § 98-9) 
Sec. 90-10. - Preparation of limbs, grass cuttings, etc., for collection. 
(a)  Tree limbs and cuttings will be picked up by the city or its contractors if tied in bundles in lengths not to exceed four feet and not to exceed 50 pounds in weight and placed at the curb, alley or regular pickup station. Grass and weed cuttings shall be placed in the cart or in plastic bags, placed at the curb, alley or regular pickup station and picked up, if not over 50 pounds in weight. 
(b)  Plastic, metal or paper containers other than carts or dumpsters will not be emptied and returned to the curb, alley or regular pickup station. 
(c)  Ashes may be picked up if put in tied bags and placed in carts or dumpsters 24 hours prior to regular pickup day. 
(Code 1975, § 10-6; Code 1995, § 98-10) 
Sec. 90-11. - Collection charges. 
(a)  The sanitary department is hereby authorized to inspect the premises, collect and remove solid waste from the owner or occupant of any premises in the city. 
(b)  There are hereby levied the following charges to be collected from the owner occupying any premises, or occupant, or one in possession or control of the premises located on an established route within the city, for the removal and disposition of solid waste, to be paid monthly to the city clerk; the same to be paid by the 15th day of the month following the month for which the service was rendered: 
(1)  For each single-family residence, $18.79 per month; provided, however, that each single-family residence using 3,000 gallons of water or less per billing period shall pay $5.46 per month for each living unit in such dwelling or trailer park. 
(2)  Multiple dwellings and trailer parks using dumpsters approved by the city manager for the deposit of solid waste shall pay $17.44 per month for each living unit in such dwelling or trailer park. 
(3)  Multiple dwellings and trailer parks not using dumpsters approved by the city manager for the deposit of solid waste shall pay $18.79 per month for each living unit in such dwelling or trailer park. 
(4)  There shall be minimum charge of $18.79 for all residential, commercial and other miscellaneous establishments unless specifically provided for herein. 
(5)  Commercial and other miscellaneous establishments shall pay at the following rates:

(Code 1975, § 10-7; Code 1995, § 98-11; Ord. No. 1018, § 1, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 1118, § 1, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 1212, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 1278, § 1, 10-21-2012; Ord. No. 1368 , § 1, 10-16-2018; Ord. No. 1372 , § 1, 11-6-2018) 
Sec. 90-12. - Deferred payment. 
    A deferred utility payment plan shall be made available to all customers with an outstanding delinquent balance in water, sewer and sanitation services; such plan shall not be made available more than two times in any calendar year between January 1 and December 31. A fee of $10.00 will be added to the customer's bill for the first-time failure to pay any deferred utility payment pursuant to the agreed plan. An additional fee of $20.00 will be added pursuant to the agreed plan for each subsequent failure to pay. 
(Code 1975, § 26-9(c); Code 1995, § 98-12; Ord. No. 1182, § 1, 11-1-2005) 
State Law reference- Authority to collect charges for collection and disposal of solid waste, 27A O.S. § 2-10-901(B). 
Sec. 90-13. - County solid waste fee. 
    Beginning on September 1, 1990, the city shall collect a monthly county solid waste fee in the amount of $0.25 from each customer of the city's solid waste disposal service. The fee shall be listed on the city's water, sewer and solid waste bill each month and shall be in addition to the normal solid waste collection fee. 
(Code 1975, § 10-7.1; Code 1995, § 98-13; Ord. No. 933, 1-2-1996) 
Sec. 90-14. - Disposal generally. 
(a)  All disposal of solid waste shall be by an approved method of incineration or by sanitary landfill and cover, such method and sites to be approved by the city council and the state department of health. 
(b)  Pursuant to the agreement with the City of Oklahoma City, household hazardous waste (HHW) may be delivered by the customer to the Oklahoma City HHW collection facility at Southwest 15th Street and Portland Avenue. Customers must provide proof of Yukon residency in the form of a valid driver's license and current Yukon utility statement. Charges for the disposal of HHW are as follows and will be billed by Oklahoma City to the City of Yukon, which will bill the customer through the standard utility billing process. All nonliquid HHW products will be converted through the use of an equivalent rate unit (ERU) measurement scale: 
< = 7.5 gallons 0.5 ERU $ 39.50 > 7.5 gallons to 15 gallons 1.0 ERU $79.00 > 15 gallons to 22.5 gallons 1.5 ERU $118.50 > 22.5 gallons 2.0 ERU $158.00  
Note: Minimum charge per vehicle per arrival = 0.5 ERU. Maximum charge per vehicle per arrival = 2.0 ERU. 
(Code 1975, § 10-8; Code 1995, § 98-14; Ord. No. 1204, § 1, 2-6-2007) 
Sec. 90-15. - Burying prohibited. 
    No solid waste shall be buried within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 10-9; Code 1995, § 98-15) 
Sec. 90-16. - Dumping prohibited. 
    No solid waste shall be dumped within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 10-10; Code 1995, § 98-16) 
Sec. 90-17. - Garbage disposal units required for dwellings. 
    Every kitchen facility in a residential building or dwelling unit constructed after October 20, 1970, and located within an area served by the city's garbage collection service shall be equipped with a proper and efficient kitchen garbage disposal unit to grind up food wastes and wash the same into the city sewerage system, or into a septic tank if the dwelling is not serviced by the city sewerage system. The building inspector shall enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 10-11; Code 1995, § 98-17) 
Sec. 90-18. - Maintenance of compost piles or pits. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the maintenance of compost piles or pits for the storage and disposition of vegetable matter consisting of grass cuttings, leaves and items of like nature, so long as such piles or pits are maintained in a satisfactory and sanitary manner and do not become a public nuisance by causing the emission therefrom of obnoxious odors. 
(Code 1975, § 10-12; Code 1995, § 98-18) 
Sec. 90-19. - Use of city transfer stations. 
(a)  Availability. Subject to the provisions of this section, the transfer station of the city shall be available for the disposal of household and yard trash and rubbish by persons residing within the city one time each calendar month at no charge. The amount of household, yard trash and rubbish is limited to no larger than a level pickup bed. All other haulers will be charged at the following rates and abide by the following restrictions: 
(1)  Items contained within a passenger automobile or within the level bed of a pickup truck, $10.00. 
(2)  Items contained within a 12-foot trailer, $25.00. (The charge set forth in subsection (1) of this section shall apply if the vehicle transporting the trailer also contains items for disposal.) 
(3)  Items contained within a trailer more than 12 feet and less than 18 feet in length, $45.00. 
(4)  Trailer charges will only apply to trailers with sides not exceeding one foot in height. 
(5)  All items that fall outside the listed parameters will be assessed at a rate of $8.50 per cubic yard. 
(6)  Tires will be accepted at a rate of $5.00 per tire for 16.5-inch and below, $10.00 for 17-inch to 19.5-inch, and $15.00 for 20-inch to 25-inch. Nothing larger than 25-inch tires will be accepted. No agricultural or off road tires will be accepted. 
(7)  Disclosed batteries will be accepted at a rate of $5.00 per battery. 
(8)  Liquids and radioactive, volatile, highly flammable, explosive or toxic materials will not be accepted. 
(b)  Proof of residency required for the once a month disposal at no charge. A resident may use the transfer station by presenting his driver's license and his current month Yukon municipal utility bill. The driver's license must match the address on the utility bill. Only household trash or rubbish may be disposed. No construction materials or commercial waste will be accepted. At all other times, regular rates and restrictions of the transfer station will be charged. 
(c)  When open. The transfer station will be open to the public for trash disposal from October 1 to March 31, Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. and the first Saturday of each month, 8:00 a.m. through 2:00 p.m. From April 1 to September 30, the transfer station will be open Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and Sunday, 1:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. 
(d)  Annual adjustment of rates. The transfer station rates will be adjusted annually based on the consumer price index for all urban consumers (CPI-U) for the southern region city average as published by the U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of Labor Statistics and rounded up to the nearest $0.25. The CPI-U shall be as of the month of February of each and every year. The adjustment shall be effective July 1 of each year. 
(e)  Rules and procedures. Rules and procedures for the operation and management of the transfer station, with regards to the public, will be established and maintained by the state environmental management authority. Applicable rules will be posted on-site for the public. 
(Code 1975, § 10-13; Code 1995, § 98-19; Ord. No. 1059, § 1, 7-6-2000; Ord. No. 1064, § 1, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1083, § 1, 7-17-2001; Ord. No. 1085, § 1, 8-7-2001; Ord. No. 1223, § 1, 5-6-2008) 
Sec. 90-20. - Collection deposit. 
    Any person using the solid waste service of the city who has not made a deposit with the city clerk for water or sewage services shall deposit the sum of $40.00 as a solid waste collection deposit. 
(Code 1975, § 10-14; Code 1995, § 98-20) 
Sec. 90-21. - Special deposit fund; application to bill; refund. 
    At the time of making application for solid waste service with the city, the applicant shall deposit with the city clerk the sum of $40.00. Such deposit will be carried in a special fund, and unless applied to the payment of a solid waste collection bill or any other sum due the city, shall be refunded by the city clerk to the depositor when the service is cancelled and discontinued. 
(Code 1975, § 10-15; Code 1995, § 98-21) 
Sec. 90-22. - Solid waste disposal facilities not owned, operated or managed by the City of Yukon. 
    Solid waste disposal facilities not owned, operated or managed by the City of Yukon shall be operated and managed to comply with the following standards: 
(1)  All operations conducted in connection with the facility shall occur within an area enclosed by walls and doors constructed in such a manner so as not to produce or emit noise, vibration, smoke, dust or other particulate matter, odors, glare, toxic or noxious matter, heat, fire or explosive hazards. 
(2)  No solid waste, garbage or refuse shall be kept or maintained on the premises overnight. 
(3)  No hazardous materials shall be accepted by the facility except in strict compliance with local, state and federal laws, rules and regulations pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1995, § 98-22; Ord. No. 1079, § 1, 5-15-2001) 
Sec. 90-23. - Rural collection of solid waste. 
(a)  All residents that live within the city limits of the City of Yukon and are designated as rural residents shall be entitled to once a week pickup of solid waste. 
(b)  All rural residents desiring to utilize the above service shall deposit with the city clerk a sum of $40.00. Such deposit shall be carried in a special fund, and unless applied to the payment of a solid waste collection bill or any other sum due the city shall be refunded by the city clerk to the depositor when the service is canceled or discontinued. 
(c)  Rural area residents are hereby charged the fee of $30.05 per month and any other fee imposed by ordinance, state or federal law, for collection services, to be paid by the 15th day of the month following the month for which the service was rendered. Late notices will be mailed to customers who have delinquent accounts on the 18th day of the month, or nearest business day, advising customers that they have until the 25th day of the month to pay their delinquent amount, plus a late fee. Customers who fail to pay by the 25th will be given notice to pay by a specified time and date. Failure to pay by the posted time will result in their solid waste collection service being terminated. The customer's garbage cart will be picked up if the bill remains unpaid, after service has been terminated. In case of extreme hardship, the parties responsible for paying the account may enter into a written agreement to pay the bill at a later date. If payment is not received when agreed, a notice will be served to the customer requesting payment by a specified time and date. If payment is not received, service will be terminated. 
(d)  Each rural resident desiring to utilize the above service will be provided one plastic cart. An additional card may be provided upon request. 
(e)  The cart should be placed at the road for pickup by 6:00 a.m. on the day of collection. Carts not set out by the designated time will be picked up on the next scheduled pick up day. 
(f)  Residents utilizing this service shall be entitled to dispose of solid waste delivered to the transfer station under the terms and conditions set forth in Section 90-19. 
(g)  Rural customers whose service is terminated for nonpayment are subject to applicable fees established in Section 114-68. 
(h)  An additional fee of $10.00 will be added to the customer's bill if their solid waste cart has been picked up by the city for the first service termination due to nonpayment. A $20.00 fee will be charged for each subsequent time the cart is removed thereafter. 
(i)  An additional fee of $25.00 will be added to the customer's bill if their solid waste dumpster is removed or secured from further use for the first time after service is terminated. A $50.00 fee will be added to the customer's bill for each subsequent time thereafter. 
(Code 1995, § 98-23; Ord. No. 1086, 8-7-2001; Ord. No. 1183, § 1, 11-1-2005; Ord. No. 1213, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 1369 , § 1, 10-16-2018) 
Chapter 94 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Obstructions and use for business purposes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon or permit to be placed upon the sidewalks, parkways, streets and alleys of the city any goods, wares, articles or merchandise or any other obstruction, and leave the same thereon, or to use the same as a place to carry on a business or trade, without first obtaining permission in writing from the city manager so to do, unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or obstruct the sidewalks of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with pedestrian traffic thereon, or to use or obstruct the streets and alleys of the city in any manner so as to interfere unduly with lawful traffic and parking thereon, without first obtaining permission in writing from the city manager so to do. 
(c)  Permission by the city manager to obstruct a street or sidewalk or carry on a business or trade upon a street or sidewalk as authorized by this section shall be by permit, and shall be granted on a temporary basis only for a period of time not to exceed three consecutive days for any individual permit. No person shall be granted more than four permits per calendar year, unless approved by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 22-8; Code 1995, § 102-2) 
Sec. 94-2. - Use for play. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play on the sidewalks or upon the main-traveled portion of the streets and alleys of the city, except as may be authorized by ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 22-9; Code 1995, § 102-3) 
Sec. 94-3. - Drainage of fluid, mud, etc., onto streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of a filling station or other place of business, or any agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow water, grease or other fluid to flow or drain into, upon, over or across any sidewalk, parking, street, alley or other public way. 
(b)  No automobile or other vehicle shall be washed at any place within the city where the water, dirt, mud or other substances removed therefrom by or during the washing thereof shall drain into or upon any street or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 22-10; Code 1995, § 102-4) 
Sec. 94-4. - Owners or occupants of abutting property not to permit sidewalks to become hazardous. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of property abutting upon a sidewalk or sidewalk area to permit the sidewalk or sidewalk area adjacent to the property to become a hazard to persons using the sidewalk or sidewalk area. 
(Code 1975, § 22-11; Code 1995, § 102-5) 
Sec. 94-5. - Duty of owners and occupants of abutting property to trim trees and shrubbery. 
(a)  The owner of any premises abutting on any street of this city shall trim all trees and shrubbery growing in the parking area or between the sidewalks and the roadway of such street, and all trees and shrubbery growing on any part of the premises adjacent to the sidewalks or any street or alley, in such manner that the boughs or limbs thereof shall not obstruct free and convenient passage and travel along the streets, sidewalks and alleys. When such premises are occupied by some person other than the owner, such occupant shall trim the trees and shrubbery in the same manner as hereinbefore required of the owner. Such trees and shrubbery shall be trimmed so that the lowest branches or foliage shall not be lower than ten feet above the roadway of a street or alley, nor lower than eight feet above the sidewalk. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant who shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim trees and shrubbery as provided in this section, after receiving five days' notice from the director of public works to do so, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. Every day that the owner or occupant shall fail, refuse or neglect to trim such trees or shrubbery, after the expiration of the five days' notice, shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 22-12; Code 1995, § 102-6) 
Sec. 94-6. - Obstructing drainage ditches along streets or alleys. 
    All persons are hereby prohibited from placing any obstruction in drainage ditches or drains along the streets and alleys of the city, and are prohibited from doing any act which will obstruct the flow of water along such ditches or drains. 
(Code 1975, § 22-13; Code 1995, § 102-7) 
Sec. 94-7. - Permit for street banners and street clocks. 
    No person shall erect or maintain over, across or above any public street, alley or other public place, any sign or banner for any purpose whatsoever, or install or maintain any street clock, without first obtaining permission in writing from the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 22-7; Code 1995, § 102-8) 
Sec. 94-8. - Paving contractor's bond. 
    All paving contractors and contractors who make storm sewer and drainage improvements and all appurtenances thereto shall be required to furnish a three-year maintenance bond to the city, or such additional bond as the city council may require. The first year of such bond shall be 100 percent coverage; the second year shall be a minimum of 25 percent coverage; and the final year shall be a minimum of 15 percent coverage. 
(Code 1975, § 22-3; Code 1995, § 102-9) 
Sec. 94-9. - Installation of water services prior to paving. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pave, or cause to be paved, any street, avenue, alley or other public way within the corporate limits of the city with Portland cement concrete, asphaltic concrete or any other permanent paving material, without first having installed in and under the street the necessary copper water services to serve each of the lots or building sites adjacent to the street or way. Such water services shall be installed in accordance with good engineering practices, and shall be approved by the city manager, the director of public works or such other officer or employee of the city as the city manager shall designate. 
(Code 1975, § 22-4; Code 1995, § 102-10) 
Secs. 94-10-94-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMITS 

Sec. 94-37. - Construction or installation of sidewalk, wall, curb on street. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct or install a sidewalk, retaining wall, curb and gutter, culvert, drain pipe, driveway approach or other structure on any street or other public area in the city shall submit a written application for a permit to the director of public works. The application shall include or be accompanied by plans and specifications or a description of the proposed structure adequate to enable the city officials to understand the proposal. 
(b)  The director of public works shall issue a permit applied for under this section, if he thinks that the proposed construction or installation meets proper standards, is justified and will not unduly endanger the public welfare. If the director refuses a permit, the applicant may appeal, within one month, to the council, and the director shall issue the permit if the council approves the application. The council's decision shall be final. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or install any structure on a street or other public area without a permit as required in this section, or to construct or install a structure thereon except as indicated by the plans and specifications or description submitted, or as approved by the council or the director of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 22-5; Code 1995, § 102-31) 
Sec. 94-38. - Street excavations. 
(a)  Any person desiring to make an opening or excavation in a public street, sidewalk or other public area of the city is required to make written application for a permit to do so to the director of public works. The application shall include or be accompanied by plans and specifications or a description of the proposed opening or excavation adequate to enable the city officials to understand the proposal. The director of public works shall issue a permit if he thinks the request reasonable and justified under the circumstances. If the director of public works refuses a permit, the applicant may appeal, within one month, to the council, and the director of public works shall issue the permit if the council approves the application. The council's decision shall be final. 
(b)  Before a permit is issued under this section, the applicant shall deposit with the city clerk an amount of money estimated by the director of public works or the council to be adequate to compensate the city for restoring the street, sidewalk or other area properly, if the applicant fails to do so promptly. If the applicant restores the street, sidewalk or area promptly and properly, the amount deposited shall be returned to him; if not, the city shall retain as much of the amount deposited as is adequate to compensate the city for making the restoration. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make an opening or excavation in a street, sidewalk or other public area without a permit as required herein; or to make such an opening or excavation except as indicated by the plans and specifications or description submitted, or as approved by the council or the director of public works. 
(Code 1975, § 22-6; Code 1995, § 102-32) 
Sec. 94-39. - Curb cuts. 
(a)  Any person desiring to cut or remove a curbing is required to make written application for a permit submitting therewith the payment of $50.00 as application fee, to the city inspector. 
(b)  The city inspector shall issue a permit applied for under this section, if the proposed curb cut meets proper standards, is justified and will not unduly endanger the public welfare. If the inspector refuses a permit, the applicant may appeal within 30 days to the council, and the inspector shall issue a permit if the council approves the application. The council's decision shall be final. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cut or remove curbing without a permit as required in this section or by not having paid the required fee of $50.00. 
(d)  The cutting and removal of curbing and all other parts of the work in connection therewith shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the city inspector and shall be done in compliance with the specifications prescribed by the inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 102-33; Ord. No. 956, 9-3-1996) 
Secs. 94-40-94-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 94-67. - Adoption of standard easement layouts for installation of underground utilities. 
(a)  Conformity with standards. After November 21, 1978, all underground utilities shall be installed in conformity with the standards adopted herein. If the city engineer determines such installation is not in conformity with these standards, he shall halt further installation until such installation conforms to these standards. 
(b)  Standards on file. The standards adopted herein shall be on file in the office of the city engineer for examination by the public. 
(c)  Twenty-foot residential easement layout. The standard 20-foot residential utility easement layout, on file in the office of the city engineer, is incorporated into this article with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(d)  Perimeter residential easement layout. The standard perimeter residential utility easement layout, on file in the office of the city engineer, is incorporated into this article with the same force and effect as if fully set out in this subsection. 
(e)  Exemption. The specifications set forth in the aforementioned easement layouts shall not apply to cross-over easements between houses. 
(f)  Deviations. Property which is zoned commercial or industrial shall have any deviation from this section approved by the city engineer. 
(g)  Violation, penalty. Violation of this section is punishable as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 22-20; Code 1995, § 102-56) 
Sec. 94-68. - Application required prior to certain excavations or openings. 
    All persons or companies taking easements and/or laying pipelines or underground lines of any kind within the city, other than municipal or subdivision gas, electric, telephone, water and sewer lines, shall make written application to the building inspector prior to making any street or road opening or excavation. 
(Code 1975, § 22-21; Code 1995, § 102-57) 
Sec. 94-69. - Contents of application. 
    The application shall contain or have attached an easement reflecting the complete legal description and location of the line, so that it may be placed upon a map for future reference; the size of the line; a description of any substance to be carried by such line; the pressure of such line; the length of time the line will be used; and such additional information as required by the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 22-22; Code 1995, § 102-58) 
Sec. 94-70. - Fee for registration of underground lines. 
    A fee for registering each underground line is hereby set in the sum established by resolution and such fee is for the purpose of administratively handling the request and maintaining a record of such lines for future land use planning and for purposes of safeguarding the lines within such easement from encroachment by other users. Such fee shall not apply to franchise holders or utility companies paying a gross receipts fee to the city, but shall apply to their subcontractors. 
(Code 1975, § 22-23; Code 1995, § 102-59) 
Sec. 94-71. - Application required prior to tearing up or tunneling under rights-of-way, etc. 
    Any person desiring to tear up, tunnel under or open the pavement, curbing or road surface on any street, alley or driveway within the street right-of-way or public ground within the corporate limits of the city shall make written application to the building inspector for permission to do so before making any opening or excavation. The application and permit shall not apply to emergency work which is necessary for the health, welfare or safety of the residents of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 22-24; Code 1995, § 102-60) 
Sec. 94-72. - Contents of application. 
    The application under this article shall state dimensions, exact locations and additional information that the building inspector may require and shall be made on a form to be supplied by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 22-25; Code 1995, § 102-61) 
Sec. 94-73. - Fee for cutting, opening and tunneling. 
(a)  A fee for cutting, opening or tunneling a public right-of-way shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(b)  Such fee is for the purpose of administratively handling the request and assuring a proper backfill. Such fee shall not apply to franchise holders or utility companies paying a gross receipts fee to the city but shall apply to their subcontractors. 
(Code 1975, § 22-26; Code 1995, § 102-62; Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 6-18-2013) 
Sec. 94-74. - Backfilling of cuts or excavations. 
    In all cases the cut or excavation must be backfilled to grade immediately and if not permanently repaired, temporarily patched. The permanent repair will be made at such time as the excavation backfill is stable. All work will be done in accordance with the established street standards of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 22-27; Code 1995, § 102-63) 
Sec. 94-75. - Bond required. 
(a)  Each applicant is required to file with the building inspector a two-year bond in the amount established by resolution. 
(b)  Such bond shall be executed by a surety company authorized to transact business in the state and approved by the city council. The conditions of the bond shall provide that the principal shall pay promptly all charges or fees levied by city ordinance, and further that the principal will properly maintain for a period of two years all repair and backfill of any trenches excavated by the principal across or along any street in the city. The bond shall be further conditioned that if the principal shall fail to correct any and all settling in a manner satisfactory to the building inspector, then the building inspector shall have the settlement corrected in a proper manner at the expense of the principal. The bond shall be further conditioned that the principal shall indemnify and save the city harmless from any and all loss, costs, damage, expenses, action or cause of action, or liability of any kind, including reasonable attorney's fees, which the city may suffer or be required to pay or which may accrue against it or be recovered from the city by reason of loss, damage or injury incurred by any person by reason of any cutting, altering or excavating on any street in the city by the principal, his agents, servants or employees, or by reason of the neglect, failure or refusal of the principal, his agents, servants or employees to erect, place and maintain proper safety devices, crossing signals or barricades about such work during the process of constructing or repair. This bond shall not apply to franchise holders or utility companies paying a gross receipts fee to the city but shall apply to their subcontractors. 
(Code 1975, § 22-28; Code 1995, § 102-64; Ord. No. 1285, § 1, 1-2-2013) 
Sec. 94-76. - Relationship to existing provisions. 
    Section 94-39 shall govern curb cuts which do not involve opening or tunneling the road surface, and this article shall not apply to such activities. 
(Code 1975, § 22-29; Code 1995, § 102-65) 
Secs. 94-77-94-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 94-96. - Conformity required, modifications. 
    The construction, maintenance and testing of all paving within the city shall be in accordance with specifications prescribed by the city engineer, approved by the city council, and on file in the office of the city clerk. In addition, the following minimum standards are established for improving existing rural and urban streets. Whenever the application of the following minimum standards cannot be achieved, modifications of same shall be made only upon the certificate and approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2(a); Code 1995, § 102-86) 
Sec. 94-97. - Standard specifications for construction. 
(a)  There are hereby adopted by reference, as if fully set forth herein, sections 101-109, 201-241, 301-317, 401-425, 501-529, 601-642, 701-740, 801-880, 900-946, and 1000-1060 of the City of Yukon Standard Specifications for Construction, a copy of which shall be kept by the city clerk for sale or other distribution to the public. 
(b)  Interpretation of these specifications will be done in such a manner as to allow the contractor to control this project to the greatest degree possible in producing an end result product which is in all respects acceptable. These specifications should not, however, be interpreted in a manner which allows a contractor to produce an unacceptable product or endanger the public. An acceptable end result product is the essence of the contract. Only projects and substantial conformance to the plans and specifications will be accepted by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 102-86.5; Ord. No. 908, 5-2-1995) 
Sec. 94-98. - Local rural streets. 
    Rural streets are those streets outside the urbanized area shown in the city's comprehensive plan. Rural streets shall meet the minimum paving standards described below: 
(1)  The street shall have a double bituminous surface with a width of 24 feet. 
(2)  There shall be a minimum five-foot shoulder on each side of the street. 
(3)  The maximum slope allowed away from the shoulder shall be 3:1 with a minimum 18-inch bar ditch on each side. 
(4)  Under the double bituminous surface, there shall be a five-inch stabilized aggregate base. 
(5)  Under the aggregate base, there shall be at least a six-inch compacted subgrade. 
(6)  The pavement edge shall be striped on both sides. 
(7)  All base and subgrade areas shall be compacted to a minimum 95 percent Standard Proctor Density compaction. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2(b); Code 1995, § 102-87) 
Sec. 94-99. - Rural residential streets-Asphaltic concrete paving. 
    Rural residential streets are those streets located in rural subdivisions that are not located in the urbanized area as shown in the city's comprehensive plan. Rural residential streets are required to be paved with asphaltic concrete paving meeting the minimum paving standards described below: 
(1)  The street shall have a surface width of not less than 26 feet. 
(2)  There shall be a minimum 4-foot shoulder on each side of the street that is constructed of six inches of ODOT type "A" aggregate base. 
(3)  The maximum slope allowed away from the shoulder shall be 3:1 with a minimum 18-inch bar ditch on each side. Required bar ditches shall have sufficient capacity to manage and contain stormwater drainage. Drainage culverts shall be provided with sufficient capacity to convey stormwater runoff. The size of each drainage culvert shall be shown on the preliminary plat. 
(4)  Portland cement concrete header curbs shall be provided that are 12 inches wide and six inches in height above the eight-inch subgrade modification that extends four feet past the outside header curbs. The ODOT type "A" aggregate base shall have a geotechnical study performed by the owner/engineer to confirm what is required for the subgrade modification. 
(5)  Under the eight-inch subgrade modification base there shall be at least a six-inch compacted subgrade of 95 percent standard proctor density. 
(6)  The distance from the inside base of the header curbs shall be 24 feet. 
(7)  The top layer of asphaltic concrete shall consist of two inches of type B asphaltic concrete (PG 64-22 OK) and shall have a parabolic crown of 21/2 inches. 
(8)  Under type B asphaltic concrete there shall be four inches of type A asphaltic concrete (PG 64-22 OK). 
(9)  Between type A and type B asphaltic concrete there shall be a tack coat. 
(10)  Twelve-inch header curb shall have a number four reinforcing steel (GR 60) at 18 inches, center to center. Install expansion joints with number four by two-foot, six inches smooth dowel at 90-foot intervals with contraction joints at 15-foot intervals. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2(c); Code 1995, § 102-88; Ord. No. 1322, § 2, 7-21-2015) 
Sec. 94-100. - Same-Concrete paving. 
    Urban concrete streets shall meet the minimum paving standards described as follows: 
(1)  Portland cement concrete curbs shall be provided that are 12 inches above the two-inch sand cushion. 
(2)  The top of the curbs shall be six inches in width. The distance from the inside base of the curbs to the outside edge shall be eight inches. 
(3)  The distance from the inside base of the curbs shall be 26 feet. 
(4)  The distance from the outside edge of the curbs shall be 27 feet, four inches. 
(5)  The distance from the inside base of the curbs to the top of the curbs shall be six inches. 
(6)  The paving thickness for the street shall be six inches. 
(7)  There shall be a two-inch sand cushion under the concrete paving. This sand cushion shall extend ten inches beyond the outside edge of the curbs. 
(8)  The street shall have a parabolic crown of 21/2 inches. 
(9)  There shall be a construction joint in the center of the street. In this construction joint, there shall be one-half-inch-diameter tie bars which are 30 inches on center. 
(10)  Two number six diameter smooth dowel bars that are 24 inches in length shall be placed across the curb expansion and contraction joints. All bars shall be coated with asphalt or grease. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2(d); Code 1995, § 102-89) 
Sec. 94-101. - Streets in mobile home and travel trailer parks. 
    All streets in mobile home and travel trailer parks shall conform to the paving specifications in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 22-2(e); Code 1995, § 102-90) 
Secs. 94-102-94-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PARADES, STREET MEETINGS, AND CELEBRATIONS 

Sec. 94-131. - Permit for processions and parades. 
    No procession or parade containing 200 or more persons or 50 or more vehicles, except the military forces of the United States and the military forces of this state, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street, except in accordance with a permit issued by the person designated by the city manager. 
(Code 1975, § 24-14; Code 1995, § 102-111) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate processions, 47 O.S. § 15-102(A)(3). 
Sec. 94-132. - Application for permit. 
    At least 48 hours before any person conducts a parade, street meeting or celebration on the streets, highways, bridges or alleys of the city, written application for a permit therefor shall be filed with the city manager, and the application shall be accompanied by a written statement giving the route, date and time of the parade, or location of the area to be occupied for the requested public meeting or celebration, and stating the nature and purpose thereof. If city personnel are necessary to assist in any listed function, application must be made 15 days prior to the beginning date. 
(Code 1975, § 12-81; Code 1995, § 102-112) 
Sec. 94-133. - Investigation. 
    The city manager shall, upon receipt of such application, make such investigation and inquiry as he deems necessary to determine whether any regular municipal service will be hampered, obstructed or delayed and the probable extent of extra policing, traffic-control or other protective service of the city reasonably occasioned thereby. If such interruption of municipal service or extent of extra service is found to be unreasonable or detrimental to the interest of the public, he shall endorse such findings on such application and decline to grant the same. 
(Code 1975, § 12-82; Code 1995, § 102-113) 
Sec. 94-134. - Police and fire department approval required. 
    Before any permit shall be issued under this article, the time, date and route of the parade and location of the proposed public celebration shall be approved by the chief of police and the fire chief for the city. 
(Code 1975, § 12-83; Code 1995, § 102-114) 
Sec. 94-135. - Permit revocable. 
    Any permit granted by the city manager under this article shall be revocable at any time by the city manager or chief of police when, in their discretion, it is determined that the parade, meeting, or celebration has or will unduly hamper or interfere with any regular municipal service, general traffic or public convenience or welfare. 
(Code 1975, § 12-84; Code 1995, § 102-115) 
Secs. 94-136-94-153. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Railroads generally, 66 O.S. § 1 et seq.; authority of city to regulate railroads, 11 O.S. § 22-119. 

Sec. 94-154. - General duties with respect to street improvements. 
(a)  When a railway company occupies any portion of a street with its tracks running in a general direction of such street, either on or adjacent thereto, the railway company shall improve the space between its tracks and two feet on either side thereof in the same manner that the remainder of the street is to be, or has been, improved, or with such other satisfactory material as the council, by motion or resolution, may approve. In case any railway company shall occupy an alley with its tracks, such company shall improve, gutter, drain and grade such alley, and shall surface or pave it with the same material which is to be, or has been, used on the alley, or with such other satisfactory material as the council, by motion or resolution, may approve. 
(b)  When the tracks of any railroad company cross any street that is being or has been paved, the company shall pave as much of the street as is occupied by its tracks, and two feet on each side thereof, using the same material as is to be, or has been, used on the street, or such other satisfactory material as the council, by motion or resolution, may approve. When more than one track crosses a street within a distance of 100 feet, measuring from inside rail to inside rail, the railroad company shall grade, gutter, drain and curb the street area between its tracks and surface or pave it with the same material which the city is to use, or has used, on the street. 
(c)  Railroad companies shall keep all improvements made by them pursuant to this section in a good state of repair at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 19-1; Code 1995, § 110-396) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 66 O.S. § 12. 
Sec. 94-155. - Duty to construct and maintain sidewalks. 
    Railway companies shall construct sidewalks crossing their rights-of-way, using the same material as is used in adjacent sidewalks, insofar as practicable under the circumstances. They shall construct sidewalks on both sides of the streets, when both sides are used by pedestrians. The company shall keep such sidewalks in a good state of repair at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 19-2; Code 1995, § 110-397) 
Sec. 94-156. - Boarding or clinging to moving trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to climb upon, hold to or in any manner attach himself to any railway train, locomotive or car, while such is in motion within the city, unless such person is acting in the line of duty. 
(Code 1975, § 19-5; Code 1995, § 110-398)

Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 98-19-98-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL SALES TAX 

Sec. 98-40. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known and may be cited as the city sales tax ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 23-11; Code 1995, § 106-26) 
Sec. 98-41. - Effective date. 
    This division shall become and be effective on and after December 1, 1966, subject to approval of a majority of the registered voters of the city voting on same in the manner prescribed by 11 O.S. § 16-112. 
(Code 1975, § 23-12; Code 1995, § 106-27) 
Sec. 98-42. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The definitions of words, terms and phrases contained in the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1352, are adopted by reference and made a part of this division. 
    Tax collector means the department of the city government or the official agency of the state duly designated according to law or contract authorized by law to administer the collection of the tax levied. 
(Code 1975, § 23-14; Code 1995, § 106-28) 
Sec. 98-43. - Purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this division to provide revenues for the support of the functions of the municipal government of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 23-13; Code 1995, § 106-29) 
State Law reference- Tax ordinances to be approved by voters, 68 O.S. § 2705. 
Sec. 98-44. - Amendments to division. 
    The people of the city, by their approval of this division at the election provided for in section 98-41, thereby authorize the city council, by ordinances duly enacted, to make such administrative and technical changes or additions in the method and manner of administration and enforcing this division as may be necessary or proper for efficiency and fairness, except that the rate of the tax provided for in this division shall not be changed without approval of the qualified electors of the city as provided by law. 
(Code 1975, § 23-30; Code 1995, § 106-30) 
Sec. 98-45. - Division cumulative. 
    This division shall be cumulative and in addition to any and all other sections of this Code or other city ordinances pertaining to taxes. 
(Code 1975, § 23-31; Code 1995, § 106-31) 
Sec. 98-46. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    For the purpose of this division, the classification of taxpayers under this division shall be as prescribed by state law for purposes of the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 1975, § 23-16; Code 1995, § 106-32) 
State Law reference- Classification of vendors, 68 O.S. § 1363. 
Sec. 98-47. - Subsisting state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the state tax commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., are, for the purpose of this division, ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 23-15; Code 1995, § 106-33) 
State Law reference- State permits, 68 O.S. § 1364. 
Sec. 98-48. - Levy. 
    There is levied an excise tax of two percent upon the gross receipts derived from all sales taxable under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 1975, § 23-17; Code 1995, § 106-34) 
State Law reference- Sales subject to tax, 68 O.S. §§ 1354, 1357(6); authority of city to levy and collect sales taxes for a general or special purpose, 68 O.S. § 2701. 
Sec. 98-49. - Exemptions. 
    There is specifically exempted from the tax levied by this division the gross receipts or gross proceeds and the transfers of tangible personal property exempted from the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 1975, §§ 23-18, 23-19; Code 1995, § 106-35) 
State Law reference- Exemptions from state sales tax, 68 O.S. §§ 1355-1360. 
Sec. 98-50. - Due date; manner of payment. 
    The tax levied under this division shall be due and payable at the time and in the manner and form prescribed for payment of the state sales tax under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 1975, § 23-21; Code 1995, § 106-37) 
State Law reference- Due date of state tax, 68 O.S. § 1365. 
Sec. 98-51. - Collection by vendor. 
(a)  The tax levied under this division shall be paid by the consumer or user to the vendor, and it shall be the duty of each and every vendor in this city to collect from the consumer or user the full amount of the tax levied by this division or an amount equal as nearly as possible or practicable to the average equivalent thereof. 
(b)  Vendors shall add the tax imposed under this division or the average equivalent thereof to the sales price or charge, and when added, such tax shall constitute a part of such price or charge, shall be a debt from the consumer or user to the vendor until paid and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. 
(c)  A vendor who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to collect the full amount of the tax levied or who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to comply with this division or who remits or rebates to a consumer or user, either directly or indirectly and by whatsoever means, all or any part of the tax levied in this division or who makes, in any form of advertising, verbally or otherwise, any statement which infers that he is absorbing the tax or paying the tax for the consumer or user by any adjustment of prices or at a price including the tax or in any manner whatsoever shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 23-23; Code 1995, § 106-38) 
State Law reference- Consumer to pay, vendor to collect tax, 68 O.S. § 1361. 
Sec. 98-52. - Bracket system for collection. 
(a)  The tax levied in this division shall be paid to the tax collector at the time in form and manner provided for payment of state sales tax under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(b)  The bracket system for the collection of the two percent city sales tax by the tax collector shall be as the system is adopted by the agreement of the city and the tax collector, in the collection of both the city sales tax and the state sales tax. 
(Code 1975, § 23-22; Code 1995, § 106-39) 
State Law reference- Remittance of tax, 68 O.S. § 1362. 
Sec. 98-53. - Tax constitutes debt. 
    The tax, penalty and interest due under this division shall at all times constitute a prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured creditors and may be collected by suit as any other debt. 
(Code 1975, § 23-27; Code 1995, § 106-40) 
Sec. 98-54. - Returns and remittances; discounts. 
    Returns and remittances of the tax levied and collected in this division shall be made to the tax collector at the time and in the manner, form and amount as prescribed for returns and remittances required by the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., and remittances of the tax collected under this division shall be subject to the same discount as may be allowed by such code for collection of state sales taxes. 
(Code 1975, § 23-24; Code 1995, § 106-41) 
State Law reference- Reports or returns by taxpayers, 68 O.S. § 221; date due, 68 O.S. § 1365; deduction, 68 O.S. § 1367.1. 
Sec. 98-55. - Interest and penalties; delinquency. 
    68 O.S. § 217 is adopted and made a part of this division, and interest and penalties at the rates and in amounts as therein specified are levied and shall be applicable in cases of delinquency in reporting and paying the tax levied by this division. The failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make and transmit the reports and remittances of the tax in the time and manner required by this division shall cause such tax to be delinquent. In addition, if such delinquency continues for a period of five days, the taxpayer shall forfeit his claim to any discount allowed under this division. 
(Code 1975, § 23-25; Code 1995, § 106-42) 
State Law reference- Interest and penalties generally, 68 O.S. § 217; bad checks, 68 O.S. § 218 et seq.; fines and imprisonments, felonies, 68 O.S. § 1361(D)-(F). 
Sec. 98-56. - Waiver of interest and penalties. 
    The interest or penalty or any portion thereof accruing because of a taxpayer's failure to pay the tax levied in this division may be waived or remitted in the manner as provided for in 68 O.S. § 220, and to accomplish the purposes of this section the applicable portions of 68 O.S. § 220 are adopted by reference and made a part of this division. 
(Code 1995, § 106-43) 
Sec. 98-57. - Erroneous payments; claim for refund. 
    Refund of erroneous payment of the city sales tax levied in this division may be made to any taxpayer making such erroneous payment in the same manner and procedure and under the same limitations of time as provided for administration of the state sales tax as set forth in 68 O.S. § 227, and to accomplish the purposes of this section, the applicable portions of 68 O.S. § 227 are adopted by reference and made a part of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 23-28; Code 1995, § 106-44) 
State Law reference- Erroneous payments, claims for refund, demand for hearing, 68 O.S. § 227. 
Sec. 98-58. - Fraudulent returns. 
    In addition to all civil penalties provided by this division, the willful failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make reports and remittances required or the making of any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this division shall be an offense. 
(Code 1975, § 23-26; Code 1995, § 106-45) 
State Law reference- False or fraudulent return, reports, 68 O.S. §§ 240.1, 241; false entries or omissions, 68 O.S. § 242. 
Sec. 98-59. - Records confidential.
