(b)  A person responsible for a child who is six years of age or younger, or a caretaker of a vulnerable adult as defined by 43 O.S. § 10-103 shall not leave that child or vulnerable adult unattended in a motor vehicle if the conditions, including, but not limited to, extreme weather, inadequate ventilation, or hazardous or malfunctioning components within the vehicle present a risk to the health or safety of the unattended child or vulnerable adult. 
(c)  It shall not be considered a violation of this section if the child or vulnerable adult is accompanied in the motor vehicle by a person at least 12 years of age who is not mentally incompetent as defined by 43 O.S. § 10-103. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1119. 
Sec. 110-482. - Identification of vehicles in funeral procession. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display, upon the outside of each vehicle, of a pennant or other identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the police department. 
(Code 1975, § 24-15; Code 1995, § 110-16) 
Sec. 110-483. - Loud sound amplification systems prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to operate or occupy a motor vehicle on a street, highway, alley, parking lot, or driveway and operate or permit the operation of any sound amplification system from within the vehicle so that the sound is plainly audible at a distance of 50 or more feet from the vehicle. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plainly audible means any sound produced by a sound amplification system from within the vehicle which clearly can be heard at a distance of 50 feet or more. Measurement standards shall be by the auditory senses, based upon direct line of sight. Words or phrases may not be discernible and base reverberations are included. The motor vehicle may be stopped, standing, parked, or moving on a street, highway, alley, parking lot or driveway. 
    Sound amplification system means any radio, tape player, compact disk player, loud speaker, or other electric device used for the amplification of the human voice. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  The emission of sound to request medical or vehicular assistance or to warn of a hazardous road condition; 
(2)  The emission of sound from an emergency or public safety vehicle; 
(3)  The emission of sound from a vehicle owned and operated by the city, or public or private utility company; 
(4)  The emission of sound from a vehicle used in an authorized public activity, such as parades, fireworks, sporting events or other activities, which have been approved by the city council or city manager. 
(5)  Any person who violates any provision of this section, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $100.00. 
(Code 1995, § 110-17; Ord. No. 937, 2-6-1996) 
Sec. 110-484. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive upon a sidewalk or within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1975, § 24-75; Code 1995, § 110-162) 
Sec. 110-485. - Obstructing intersection or crosswalk. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1975, § 24-76; Code 1995, § 110-163) 
Sec. 110-486. - Play streets, designation and marking. 
    The city manager, subject to any directions which the council may give by motion or resolution, shall have authority to declare any street or part thereof a play street and to have placed appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof, except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1975, §§ 24-68, 24-69; Code 1995, §§ 110-13, 110-203) 
Sec. 110-487. - Operation of motor-driven two- and three-wheeled recreational machines. 
(a)  No person shall operate any motorcycle, minibike, motor scooter, moped, go-cart, ATV or other motor-driven two- or three-wheeled recreational machines upon, over or across any city park, public school ground, drainage facility, or upon any other public right-of-way or property owned by the city, other than the public streets where permitted to do so by law. 
(b)  No person shall operate any motorcycle, minibike, motor scooter, moped, go-cart, ATV or other motor-driven two- or three-wheeled recreational machines within 1,000 feet of property zoned and occupied for residential usage, except in the following situations: 
(1)  Upon roadways as defined by law. 
(2)  Upon a parking lot or driveway where the operation involves ingress, egress, parking or storage of the vehicle. 
(3)  Upon property properly zoned for the usage of such vehicles. 
(4)  Upon property owned by the rider or a member of his family 
(c)  No person shall operate any motorcycle, minibike, motor scooter, moped, go-cart, ATV or other motor-driven two- or three-wheeled recreational machines on private property, except on his own property or when he has in his possession the written permission from the owner of such property. 
(Code 1975, § 24-162; Code 1995, § 110-345) 
Secs. 110-488-110-512. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - OPERATION OF BICYCLES AND PLAY VEHICLES[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Operation of bicycles and play vehicles, 47 O.S. § 11-1201 et seq. 

Sec. 110-513. - Parental responsibility; territorial applicability. 
(a)  The parent or legal guardian of any child or the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided, the provisions of this division shall apply whenever a bicycle or motorized scooter is operated upon any highway or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles or motorized scooters. 
(Code 1975, § 24-172; Code 1995, § 110-421) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1201. 
Sec. 110-514. - Application of traffic regulations to riders. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of the state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of the city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this division and except as to those provisions of laws and/ordinances which, by their nature, can have no application. 
(Code 1975, § 24-173; Code 1995, § 110-422) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1202. 
Sec. 110-515. - Use of permanent seat required; carrying excess persons. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle or motorized scooter shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1975, § 24-175; Code 1995, § 110-424) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1203. 
Sec. 110-516. - Riders to obey traffic-control devices. 
(a)  Any person operating a bicycle shall obey the instructions of official traffic-control signals, signs and other control devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or U-turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1975, § 24-174; Code 1995, § 110-423) 
Sec. 110-517. - Clinging to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 24-18; Code 1995, § 110-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1204. 
Sec. 110-518. - Driving on highway; required use of paths. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle or motorized scooter upon a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall ride as close as is safe to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway, except under any of the following situations: 
(1)  When overtaking and passing another vehicle proceeding in the same direction; 
(2)  When preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway; 
(3)  When reasonably necessary to avoid conditions and while exercising due care, including, but not limited to: 
a.  Fixed or moving objects; 
b.  Parked or moving vehicles; 
c.  Pedestrians or animal; 
d.  Surface hazards; 
e.  Any time it is unsafe to continue along the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway; and 
(4)  When riding in the right-turn-only lane. 
(b)  Any person riding a bicycle or motorized scooter upon a one-way street or highway with two or more marked lanes of travel may ride as close as is safe to the left-hand curb or edge of the street or highway. 
(c)  No person operating a bicycle or motorized scooter shall pass other vehicles between lanes of traffic traveling in the same direction. 
(d)  Persons riding bicycles or motorized scooters upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles or motorized scooters. Persons riding two abreast shall not impede the normal and reasonable flow of traffic and, on a laned roadway, shall ride within a single lane. 
(Code 1975, §§ 24-180, 24-181; Code 1995, §§ 110-428, 110-429) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1205. 
Sec. 110-519. - Riders carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1975, § 24-176; Code 1995, § 110-425) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1206. 
Sec. 110-520. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing. 
(Code 1975, § 24-182; Code 1995, § 110-430) 
Sec. 110-521. - Overtaking and passing bicycle. 
    When overtaking and passing a bicycle proceeding in the same direction, a person driving a motor vehicle shall exercise due care by leaving a safe distance between the motor vehicle and the bicycle of not less than three feet until the motor vehicle is safely past the overtaken bicycle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1208. 
Sec. 110-522. - Emerging from alley, driveway or building. 
    The operator of a bicycle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall, upon approaching a sidewalk or the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway, yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the sidewalk or sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 24-183; Code 1995, § 110-431) 
Sec. 110-523. - Riding on sidewalks generally. 
(a)  No person, except law enforcement officers, shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk within the business district. 
(b)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1975, § 24-184; Code 1995, § 110-432; Ord. No. 914, §§ 1, 2, 8-1-1995) 
Sec. 110-524. - Sign prohibiting riding on sidewalks or roadways. 
    The city manager is authorized to have erected signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person. When such signs are in place, no person shall disobey the same. 
(Code 1975, § 24-185; Code 1995, § 110-433) 
Sec. 110-525. - Parking. 
    No person, except law enforcement officers, shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1975, § 24-186; Code 1995, § 110-434; Ord. No. 915, § 1, 8-1-1995) 
Sec. 110-526. - Helmets. 
    Every person under the age of 18 years shall wear a helmet at all times when operating or riding a bicycle. Helmets shall have been approved by Snell or ANSI. 
(Code 1995, § 110-435; Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 6-4-2013) 
Sec. 110-527. - Light and reflector. 
(a)  Every bicycle in use at the times described in 47 O.S. § 12-201(B) shall be equipped with a lamp on the front emitting a white light visible from a distance of at least 1,000 feet to the front. This section shall not apply to a street or highway with a speed limit of 25 miles per hour or less. 
(b)  Every bicycle in use at the times described in 47 O.S. § 12-201(B) shall be equipped with a lamp on the rear emitting a red light visible from a distance of at least 1,000 feet to the rear. This section shall not apply to a street or highway with a speed limit of 25 miles per hour or less. 
(c)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a red reflector which shall be visible for 600 feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(d)  Every bicycle when in use at the times described in 47 O.S. § 12-201(B) shall be equipped with reflective material of sufficient size and reflectivity to be visible from both sides for 600 feet when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. 
(e)  A bicycle or its rider may be equipped with lights or reflectors in addition to those required by the foregoing sections; provided, such lights or reflectors shall comply with the provisions and limitations of state law. 
(Code 1975, § 24-177; Code 1995, § 110-426) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. §§ 12-702-12-704, 12-706, 12-707. 
Sec. 110-528. - Brake. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with brakes which will enable its driver to stop the bicycle within 25 feet from a speed of ten miles per hour on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Code 1975, § 24-179; Code 1995, § 110-427) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-708. 
Sec. 110-529. - Use of coasters, roller skates, etc., on roadways. 
    No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device shall go upon any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk; and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-20; Code 1995, § 110-14) 
Secs. 110-530-110-551. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - MAINTENANCE, CONSTRUCTION AND SAFETY ZONES[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Maintenance, construction and safety zones, 47 O.S. § 11-1301 et seq. 

Sec. 110-552. - Fines for traffic violations in construction or maintenance areas. 
    Where any street shall be under construction or repair or a detour shall have been designated by reason of construction or repairs in progress and a speed limit has been posted, no person shall drive any vehicle upon that portion of the road or upon the detour at a speed in excess of the speed so determined and posted. Violation of the posted speed limit in the maintenance or construction zone shall result in the doubling of the appropriate fine as allowed by state statute. For the purposes of this section, the term "maintenance or construction zone" means any location where maintenance or construction work is actually in progress. 
(Code 1995, § 110-238; Ord. No. 995, 8-5-1997; Ord. No. 1314, § 1, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 110-553. - Driving through safety zone prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall at any time be driven through or within a safety zone or island. 
(Code 1975, § 24-73; Code 1995, § 110-161) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1301. 
Sec. 110-554. - Maintenance and construction zones. 
(a)  City personnel or contractors, while repairing or improving the streets of the city, and city personnel and utility companies, when installing, improving or repairing lines or other public facilities in the streets, are hereby authorized as necessary, subject to control by the city manager, to close any street or section thereof to traffic during such repair, maintenance or construction, and in exercising such authority, shall erect or cause to be erected proper control devices and barricades to warn and notify the public that the street has been closed to traffic. Whenever construction, repair or maintenance of any street or utility line or facility is being performed and the street is not closed to traffic in accord with this section, the city personnel, contractor or utility company concerned shall erect, or cause to be erected, traffic-control devices to warn and guide the public, and every person using such street shall obey all signs, signals, markings, flagmen or other traffic-control devices which are placed to regulate, control and guide traffic through the construction or maintenance area. 
(b)  When any highway has been closed to traffic while the highway is flooded or under repair, maintenance or construction and traffic-control devices or barricades have been erected, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle through, under, over, or around the traffic-control devices or barricades, or otherwise to enter the closed area. The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons while engaged in the construction, maintenance and repair of the highway or to persons entering therein for the protection of lives or property; provided, that persons having their places of residence or places of business within the closed area may travel, when possible to do so, through the area at their own risk. 
(c)  Whenever any traffic-control device requires traffic to merge due to the closure of a section or lane of highway, the merge shall be completed: 
(1)  As soon as practicable after passing the traffic-control device; and 
(2)  Without passing any other traffic proceeding in the same direction. 
(d)  No person shall remove, change, modify, deface or alter any traffic-control device or barricade which has been erected on any highway under the provisions of this section. 
(e)  When any section of a highway, turnpike, county road or city street has been closed to traffic due to flooding that is ongoing and traffic-control devices or barricades have been erected by law enforcement or other government officials with authority over traffic-control, it shall be unlawful for any person to tear down, damage or remove any traffic-control devices or barricades or drive any vehicle through, under, over or around the traffic-control devices or barricades, or otherwise to enter the closed area. 
(Code 1975, § 24-26; Code 1995, § 110-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1302. 
Secs. 110-555-110-571. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VEHICLE CONDITION AND EQUIPMENT; VEHICLE SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD[14] 
Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Vehicle equipment, 47 O.S. § 12-101 et seq.; vehicle size, weight and load, 47 O.S. § 14-101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-572. - Vehicles injurious to streets. 
    No vehicle or object which injures or is likely to injure the surface of a street shall be driven or moved on any street. 
(Code 1975, § 24-12; Code 1995, § 110-8) 
Sec. 110-573. - Prohibition on the use of dynamic braking devices. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle with a dynamic braking device engaged within the city limits except for the purpose of avoiding imminent danger or in case of wheel brake failure. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a dynamic braking device (commonly referred to as Jake brakes, Jacobs brake, engine brake, or compression brake) means a device on a motor vehicle, primarily on trucks, for the conversion of the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1995, § 110-171; Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 7-2-2013) 
Sec. 110-574. - Truck routes. 
    The city manager, subject to any directions which the council may make by motion or resolution, may prescribe routes through the city for the use of trucks in general or trucks of particular kinds and/or other vehicles which are not ordinary private passenger vehicles, passing through the city. The city manager shall see that appropriate and adequate signs are placed along such routes so that drivers of such vehicles may follow the routes. When such signs are so erected and in place, the driver of a truck or other vehicle for which a route has been prescribed as herein provided, while passing through the city, shall keep on such route and shall not deviate therefrom except in case of emergency. Drivers of such vehicles shall follow such routes so far as practicable also when driving within the city and not merely through the city. 
(Code 1975, § 24-88; Code 1995, § 110-316) 
Sec. 110-575. - Unlawful to operate motor vehicle passing through city with laden weight in excess of 40,000 pounds on Cornwell Avenue between Tenth Street and Main Street. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in excess of 40,000 pounds laden weight while passing through the city on Cornwell Avenue between Tenth Street and Main Street except in the case of an emergency. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate subsection (a) of this section, shall be guilty of an offense and the city shall assess such person a fine within the limits prescribed by section 1-7. 
(Code 1995, § 110-317; Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 4-6-1999) 
Secs. 110-576-110-598. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOTORCYCLES 

Sec. 110-599. - Required equipment. 
(a)  In addition to other requirements, all motorcycles, except when operated on actual trail rides conducted outside of public roads and highways, shall be equipped with: 
(1)  Two rearview mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than three inches in diameter, mounted one on each side of the motorcycle and positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway to the rear of the vehicle 
(2)  A windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect the operator from foreign objects, except that in lieu of such windshield, the operator shall wear goggles or other protective eyewear which meets American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Standard Z87.1 and provides positive retention, or a face shield of material and design to protect the operator from foreign objects; 
(3)  A properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least the maximum legal speed limit for that motorcycle; 
(4)  A fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type provided by the manufacturer; 
(5)  A horn which shall comply with the requirements of 47 O.S. § 12-401; and 
(6)  A muffler or other effective noise-suppressing system which shall comply with the requirements of 47 O.S. § 12-402. 
(b)  No person under 18 years of age shall operate or ride upon any motorcycle unless such person is properly wearing a crash helmet of a type which complies with standards established by 49 CFR 571.218. 
(c)  Handlebars on motorcycles shall not be higher than eye level of the operator. 
(Code 1975, §§ 24-150-24-153, 24-157, 24-158; Code 1995, §§ 110-333-110-336, 110-340, 110-341) 
State Law reference- 11 O.S. § 12-609. 
Sec. 110-600. - Brakes on motorcycles. 
    The brake system on any motorcycle shall comply with performance ability standard set forth in 49 CFR 571.121, and shall be adequate to control the movement of the motorcycle and to stop and hold the motorcycle, including two separate means of applying the brakes. One means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel, and one means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheels. 
(Code 1975, § 24-154; Code 1995, § 110-337) 
State Law reference- 11 O.S. § 12-608. 
Sec. 110-601. - Lights and reflectors. 
(a)  Older motorcycles and definitions. 
(1)  Every motorcycle of the model year 1978 or later operating upon a highway within the state shall display at all times: 
a.  A lighted headlamp; and 
b.  Any other illuminating devices, if manufactured to be displayed at all times. 
This subsection (a)(1) shall not apply to motorcycles used in official law enforcement capacities. 
(2)  The provisions 47 O.S. § 12-201(A), (C) and (D) shall apply to motorcycles; provided, however, notwithstanding the provisions of 47 O.S. § 12-201, a motorcycle may be equipped with a motorcycle headlamp modulation system as authorized by 49 CFR 571.108, S7.9.4. 
(3)  As used in provisions in this chapter pertaining to motorcycles, the term "motorcycle" shall include, unless otherwise specifically indicated, motorcycles and motor-driven cycles as those terms are defined by law. 
(b)  Headlights required. 
(1)  Every motorcycle shall be equipped with at least one headlamp emitting a white light which shall comply with the applicable requirements and limitations of subsection (c) of this section and 47 O.S. §§ 12-203, 12-224, 12-225, 12-227 and 12-228. 
(2)  Every headlamp upon every motorcycle shall be located at a height of not more than 54 inches nor less than 22 inches to be measured as set forth in 47 O.S. § 12-202(B). 
(3)  For purposes of this subsection (b): 
a.  The term "headlamp" shall not include passing lamp. 
b.  The term "passing lamp" shall mean an auxiliary front low-beam lamp which emits a white light. 
(c)  Minimum headlight requirements. Every headlamp upon every motorcycle shall meet the requirements set forth in 47 O.S. § 12-203(C). 
(d)  Tail lamps. 
(1)  Every motorcycle shall be equipped with at least one tail lamp mounted on the rear on the vertical center line of the motorcycle which shall emit a red light plainly visible from a distance of 1,000 feet to the rear, provided that in the case of a combination of vehicles only the tail lamp on the rearmost vehicle need actually be seen from the distance specified. 
(2)  Every tail lamp shall be located at a height of not more than 60 inches nor less than 15 inches. 
(3)  Either a tail lamp or a separate lamp with a white light shall be so constructed and placed as to illuminate the rear license plate and render it clearly legible from a distance of 50 feet to the rear. Any tail lamp, together with any separate lamp for illuminating the rear license plate, shall be lighted whenever the headlamp or driving lamp is lighted. The operation of a motorcycle upon which the license plate is surrounded or framed, partially or in whole, by any additional lamps or otherwise lighted by any additional lamps, shall be a violation of this subsection. 
(e)  Reflectors. Every motorcycle shall be equipped with and display at least one reflector meeting the requirements of this subsection. Every such reflector shall be mounted on the motorcycle at a height not less than 15 inches nor more than 60 inches measured as set forth in 47 O.S. § 12-202(B), and shall be of such size and characteristics and so mounted as to be visible at night from all distances within 600 feet to 100 feet from the motorcycle when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps. 
(f)  Stop lamps. Every motorcycle shall be equipped with at least one stop lamp meeting the requirements of this subsection. The stop lamp required by this subsection: 
(1)  Shall be mounted on the rear of the motorcycle; 
(2)  Shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than 500 feet to the rear in normal sunlight; and 
(3)  Shall be actuated upon application of the brakes. 
(g)  Turn signal lamps. Every motorcycle of model year 2005 and later shall be equipped with electric flashing turn signal lamps meeting the requirements of this subsection. The flashing turn signal lamps required by this subsection: 
(1)  Shall show to the front and rear of the motorcycle; 
(2)  Shall be located on the same level and as widely spaced laterally as practicable on the front of the motorcycle and when in use shall display a white or amber light, or any shade of color between white and amber, visible from a distance of not less than 500 feet to the front in normal sunlight; 
(3)  Shall be located at the same level and as widely spaced laterally as practicable on the rear of the motorcycle and when in use shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than 500 feet to the rear in normal sunlight; and 
(4)  Shall indicate when actuated the intended direction of turning by flashing the lights showing to the front and rear on the side toward which the turn is made. 
(Code 1975, §§ 24-155, 24-156; Code 1995, §§ 110-338, 110-339) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. §§ 12-601-12-606. 
Chapter 114 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to acquire, maintain, etc., utilities generally, 11 O.S. §§ 22-104, 35-101 et seq.; authority to enter lands for the purpose of establishing, constructing, etc., public utilities or works, 11 O.S. § 22-114. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 114-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Utility means any person who is engaged in the sale, generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water, gas, sewer, telephone or other public services. 
    Utility service means the furnishing, sale, generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water, gas, sewer, telephone or other public service by a utility. 
(Code 1975, § 12-60(a); Code 1995, § 114-1) 
Sec. 114-2. - Damaging, defacing, etc., property. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of any utility operating in the city. 
(Code 1975, § 26-6; Code 1995, § 114-2) 
Sec. 114-3. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Alter, tamper with, injure or knowingly allow the altering, tampering with or injuring of any pipeline, line, wire, conduit, conductor, meter, meter seal or lock, transformer or other equipment used by a utility to deliver or register service. 
(2)  Prevent any installed metering device from registering correctly the quantity of service passing through such metering device. 
(3)  Make or cause to be made any connection between any pipeline, lines, wires, conduits, conductors, meters, transformers or other equipment in such manner as to prevent the correct registration of service by any metering device, or to otherwise use the utility service without the consent of the utility. 
(4)  Supply or cause to be supplied any utility service to any person without such service first passing through the metering device provided by the utility for measuring and registering the quantity of service. 
(5)  Knowingly use any utility meter or utility service that has been cut off, locked or disconnected by the utility. 
(6)  Evade payment for utility service in any other way. 
(b)  Any person who is convicted of violating the provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than the maximum set forth in section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 12-60(b); Code 1995, § 114-3; Ord. No. 1161, § 1, 1-3-2005) 
Sec. 114-4. - Maintenance bond for contractors. 
    All general contractors who lay and install water and sewer lines in the city shall be required to furnish a two-year maintenance bond to the city. Each year of such bond shall provide for 100 percent coverage of such contract. 
(Code 1975, § 26-2(a); Code 1995, § 114-4) 
Sec. 114-5. - Technical code requirements for connections. 
    No new connection to or extension of either the water or sanitary sewer system of the city shall be made within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of furnishing water or sewer service to any building or premises located outside the city limits, but within one-half mile thereof, unless the buildings or structures intended to be furnished with such service have been constructed in accordance with all of the provisions of the building code and all other ordinances of the city. No such connection or extension hereafter made shall be further connected to or further extended unless the buildings and structures intended to be served by such further connection or extension shall be so constructed. All of the permits, plans, inspections and fees applicable to construction within the city limits shall be applicable to such buildings and structures, and no permit to connect such buildings or structures to either the water or sewer system of the city, or extension thereof, shall be issued until there has been compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 26-2(b); Code 1995, § 114-5) 
State Law reference- Authority outside corporate limits, 11 O.S. § 35-101. 
Sec. 114-6. - Telephone towers. 
    A conditional use permit shall be obtained from the city for the construction or erection of any telephone tower. 
(Code 1995, § 114-6; Ord. No. 989, 7-1-1997) 
Secs. 114-7-114-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Enforcement of water charges authorized, 11 O.S. § 37-109; utility deposits generally, 11 O.S. § 35-107. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-31. - Deposit required. 
(a)  Before water use is permitted or water service is initiated, the city clerk shall collect a deposit for each separate dwelling unit in single-family and multifamily units or trailer parks using a master meter. Such deposit shall be carried in a special fund, and unless applied to the payment of a water bill or other sum due the city, shall be refunded by the city clerk to the depositor when the service is canceled or otherwise discontinued. All such deposit fees shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(b)  A deposit made under this section to guarantee payment of water bills may also be applied to any delinquent or defaulting sewer or garbage service charges of the user who made the deposit. 
(Code 1975, § 26-100; Code 1995, § 114-31; Ord. No. 903, 11-1-1994; Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 6-18-2013) 
Sec. 114-32. - Connection fees; service transfers; deposit transfers. 
(a)  For any new utility service, there shall be a connection fee of $25.00 added to the account to initiate the service and establish the account. 
(b)  There shall be a $25.00 charge whenever service is transferred from one residence or business location to another address. 
(c)  There shall be a $20.00 charge when a new account is established by transferring the deposit of an existing account to that of a new account. 
(d)  Effective March 31, 2016, there shall be a $15.00 per month charge for each meter to help compensate for the purchase of water from Oklahoma City, and effective March 31, 2017, the charge for each meter to help compensate for the purchase of water from Oklahoma City shall be $20.00 per month. 
(Code 1975, § 26-103(d), (e); Code 1995, § 114-32; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 11-1-2005; Ord. No. 1215, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 1241, § 1, 12-19-2009; Ord. No. 1334, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 114-33. - Unpaid previous bills to be paid prior to commencing new service. 
    Should any water or sewer customer cease to be a customer by reason of moving or leaving the district where the city has jurisdiction, or service is transferred from one residence to another residence within the city, and be indebted to the city for water or sewer service in any amount, such customer may not receive service again, should he so apply, until all amounts due the city for previous service are paid. 
(Code 1975, § 26-104; Code 1995, § 114-33; Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 3-21-2001) 
Sec. 114-34. - Rates established for water service. 
(a)  The city shall furnish water to private consumers who have installed connections with the water mains, as in this chapter provided, at a meter rate payable monthly on the 15th day of each month, as follows: 
(1)  For 0 to 2,000 gallons per month: $14.45 
(2)  Next 10,000 gallons per month, per 1,000 gallons: $4.05 
(3)  All over 12,000 gallons per month, per 1,000 gallons: $4.77 
(b)  Provided, however, that the above rates shall not apply if the city, in the interest of public service, shall determine to enter into any special contract with any consumer. 
(Code 1975, § 26-98; Code 1995, § 114-34; Ord. No. 1016, § 1, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 1116, § 1, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 1216, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 1280, § 1, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 1335, § 1, 4-5-2016; Ord. No. 1367 , § 1, 10-16-2018) 
Sec. 114-35. - Sewer use charge and industrial cost recovery system. 
(a)  User and sewer service charge. For the purpose of providing funds for the maintenance of the sanitary sewage system of the city and for other purposes, there is hereby fixed and established a monthly charge for each connection to the sanitary sewage system of the city for the use of such system to be levied against each user thereof within and without the city. For the purpose of providing funds for the operation and maintenance of the sanitary sewage system of the city and for other purposes, there are hereby fixed and established minimum charges for the use of the sanitary sewage system to be levied against each respective user thereof within the city at a meter rate payable monthly on the first day of each month, as follows. Beginning the first billing period after April 1, 2016: 
(1)  For the first 4,000 gallons per month of metered water usage, the rate shall be $10.00. 
(2)  For 4,001 to 12,000 gallons per month in metered water usage, the rate shall be $4.50 per each 1,000 gallons. 
(3)  For 12,001 to 20,000 gallons per month in metered water usage, the rate shall be $4.75 per each 1,000 gallons. 
(4)  For 20,001 to 50,000 gallons per month in metered water usage, the rate shall be $5.00 per each 1,000 gallons. 
(5)  For over 50,001 gallons per month in metered water usage, the rate shall be $5.25 per each 1,000 gallons. 
(6)  Each living unit in each multiple unit dwelling shall be charged: 
a.  For the first 4,000 gallons of metered water usage per unit, per month; $10.00. 
b.  The balance of the meter reading, if any, after the 4,000 gallons per living unit is deducted shall be divided equally among the number of living units in such dwelling, and each living unit in such dwelling shall be charged at the same rate as a single-family residence using more than 4,000 gallons of metered water usage per month. 
(b)  Industrial cost recovery system. There shall be no industrial waste discharged into the city's sewerage system until an industrial user charge is adopted in accordance with all applicable rules and regulations published pursuant to title 11 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 (P.L. 92-500, 33 USC 1251 et seq.) or later revisions. 
(Code 1975, § 26-99; Code 1995, § 114-35; Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 8-4-1998; Ord. No. 1117, § 1, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 1214, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. No. 1279, § 1, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 1328, § 1, 10-20-2015; Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 3-29-2016) 
Sec. 114-36. - Charge for water when meter fails to register. 
    If a water meter fails to register during any period, the customer shall be charged for that period on an estimate made by the city clerk based upon the average bill for the preceding three months that the meter was registering properly, or from any other information available which would provide a more equitable basis for such charge. 
(Code 1975, § 26-101; Code 1995, § 114-36) 
Sec. 114-37. - Refunding or prorating sewer charge. 
    Where sewer service is terminated during the month and after the payment of the service charge for such month, there shall be no refund, but the successor user of the sanitary sewerage system shall not be billed for the sewer service until the first day of the month following the termination of the service by his predecessor. Where sewer service is commenced prior to the 15th day of any month, the regular sewer service charge shall be made for that month, and no charge shall be made for the month if the service is commenced after the 15th day thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 26-105; Code 1995, § 114-37) 
Sec. 114-38. - Adjustment to water and sewer bill in event of water leakage. 
(a)  Any customer who has experienced an increase in water usage due to a water leak occurring in the piping, connections or other property belonging to the customer shall be entitled to an adjustment to their water and sewer bill. The amount of adjustment shall be a credit of 100 percent of the water and sewer bill in excess of the customer's average monthly water and sewer bill for the preceding three months, or from any other information available which would provide a more equitable basis for such charge. 
(b)  In order to qualify for the adjustment, the customer must provide the city with a plumber's statement or other proof that the necessary repairs have been made. The city may also request an inspection of the repairs and the customer's premises. Any customer who refuses to allow the inspection shall not be entitled to an adjustment. In addition, no adjustments shall be made until the following or a subsequent water and sewer bill is received which indicates that water consumption has returned to normal levels. In no event shall the adjustment be for a period of more than 90 days. 
(Code 1975, § 26-106; Code 1995, § 114-38; Ord. No. 916, §§ 1, 2, 8-1-1995; Ord. No. 1070, § 1, 11-7-2000) 
Secs. 114-39-114-64. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BILLS, TERMINATION OF SERVICE 

Sec. 114-65. - Billing generally. 
    Charges for water, sewer and garbage service shall be rendered on the same bill and shall be due and payable, at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 26-102; Code 1995, § 114-51) 
Sec. 114-66. - When due, delinquency. 
(a)  Payment for services must be received in the office of the city clerk by the 15th day of the month following the month that the service was provided, or the next business day following the 15th if the 15th falls on a weekend or holiday. If the bill is not paid when due and has a balance of at least $5.00, it shall become delinquent and subject to a delinquent charge for residential service of $10.00 and, for commercial service, an amount equal to ten percent of the outstanding balance. 
(b)  The clerk shall not accept payment for one service to the exclusion of any other utility service charged on the same bill. 
(Code 1975, § 26-103(a); Code 1995, § 114-52; Ord. No. 1110, § 1, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 114-67. - Termination of services. 
(a)  The city may terminate utility services of customers for nonpayment of such services. 
(b)  If utility bills are delinquent on the 16th day of each month, a notice shall be sent to any delinquent customer on the 18th of the month or the nearest workday to that date. The notice shall state that the bill is due and that such delinquent customer has until the 25th of the month in which to respond by paying the bill in full or requesting a hearing. The notice shall include the balance due, including any late charges, the cutoff date if the bill is not paid and a notice that the customer has a right to a hearing. The notice shall state that the utility representative conducting the hearing shall have the authority to resolve any dispute or adjust the bill. 
(c)  A written record shall be made of the final result of all hearings and signed by the customer and the utility representative. 
(d)  In cases of extreme hardship, the city manager or his designee may enter into a written agreement with the person responsible for payment for services providing for an equitable resolution. If payment for utility services is not made or agreed upon, the utility services will be cut off immediately following the 25th day of the month. A reading at the time of cut off will be recorded. The meter will be removed if someone other than a city employee tampers with the meter. Use of any utility meter or utility service that has been turned off, locked or disconnected by the city is prohibited, as set forth in section 114-3(a)(5). 
(e)  Utility cutoff will be made during regular business hours between 10:00 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. Such cutoff will be made Monday through Thursday, but not on the day before a holiday. 
(f)  Service shall not be terminated unless the owner or occupant liable for the bill has been given notice that the service will be terminated. A notice shall be placed on the door of the address where utility service is terminated and will include information about service restoration. 
(Code 1975, § 26-9; Code 1995, § 114-53; Ord. No. 1110, § 2, 12-17-2002) 
Sec. 114-68. - Service restoration. 
(a)  Utility service will be restored only during regular working hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, and only after full payment of the delinquent amount, plus fees, is received. A turn off fee of $25.00 will be added to a customer's bill when service is terminated for the first time due to nonpayment. A $50.00 turn off fee shall be added to the customer's bill for each subsequent time service is interrupted for nonpayment. In addition, any consumer not maintaining a security deposit whose utility service is terminated for nonpayment shall be required to make and maintain a security deposit in the amount required by section 114-31 before service shall be re-established. 
(b)  There shall be no charge for restoring utility service if service was disconnected due to city error. 
(c)  An additional $10.00 fee will be added to the customer's bill if the meter had been pulled for the first time at the address. A fee of $20.00 will be added to the customer's bill for each subsequent time the meter is pulled due to nonpayment. 
(Code 1975, § 26-103(b), (c); Code 1995, § 114-54; Ord. No. 1110, § 3, 12-17-2002) 
Secs. 114-69-114-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal waterworks systems generally, 11 O.S. § 37-101 et seq. 

Sec. 114-95. - Application and contract for service. 
(a)  All applications for water service must be made in writing on forms furnished by the city clerk before service will be provided. Such application shall contain a description of the premises where such water is to be used and such other reasonable information as the city clerk may require. 
(b)  The application form for water service shall constitute a contract on the part of the person making the application. Such contract shall provide for the use of water in accordance with the ordinances, rules and requirements of the city and as a guarantee for the return in good condition of the water meter set and in use at the premises, and as a guarantee for payment of all required bills. 
(Code 1975, § 26-17; Code 1995, § 114-76) 
Sec. 114-96. - Setting and connecting meters. 
(a)  The purchase price for water meters of all sizes shall be established from time to time at actual cost by the city manager, and a schedule of such charges shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  All water meters up to and including two inches shall be set and connected to the city mains by the city's water distribution department. 
(c)  All water meters over two inches shall be purchased from the city by an approved contractor who shall then make all necessary service line connections and set the meter. 
(d)  All water services must conform to the city design criteria, standards and requirements for construction of water services, including any boring or the removal and replacement of pavement. 
(e)  No meter will be set in a location other than a designated public easement abutting the property to be serviced; provided, however, in residential, office, commercial and industrial condominium developments, common areas may be used for utility service lines when so designated by easement with said easement being filed in the office of the county clerk. The city engineer shall have the right to the location of easements requiring abutment to the property. At no time shall a meter be set in a driveway, street or parking lot. If a service line has already been connected to the water main prior to the building construction, the city shall not be responsible if the building waterline is installed in another location. 
(f)  If water service has been connected to the city water main to service a particular lot and there are subsequent lot splits and the installed service pipe does not meet the requirements of the new lot boundary, the developer for the lot or lots shall be responsible for providing proper service line connections to the designated lot or lots. 
(g)  Prior to any connection to the city water system, the city shall inspect the meter setup and installation. All inspection fees shall be paid prior to inspection. 
(h)  The inspection fee for all water meter installations over two inches in size shall be $20.00. 
(Code 1975, § 26-18; Code 1995, § 114-77; Ord. No. 1071, § 1, 2-20-2001) 
Sec. 114-97. - Meters and services become property of city. 
    All water meters and services connected to the city water system shall become the property of the city and shall remain in place at the premises where set, unless the department of public works shall deem it necessary to remove the meter, if the premises becomes abandoned. 
(Code 1975, § 26-19; Code 1995, § 114-78) 
Sec. 114-98. - Separate service required; exception. 
    Every building and every portion of a block or row of buildings that is capable of independent ownership shall have its own separate water service line and meter connected directly to the city main. Apartment houses, flats, office buildings, and similar structures under a single roof may be served by a single service line and meter, or the different portions of such buildings separately metered, provided a separate service stop valve is provided for each separate portion of the building. 
(Code 1975, § 26-20; Code 1995, § 114-79) 
Sec. 114-99. - Stop and waste valve required on customer's service. 
    Every customer's water service installed or changed, remodeled or renewed shall have installed, between the meter and the service hydrants for the premises, at a suitable and convenient location, a stop and waste valve for the customer's use in making repairs to piping on the customer's property. 
(Code 1975, § 26-21; Code 1995, § 114-80) 
Sec. 114-100. - Turn on, off at curb stop valve by authorized persons only. 
    Only the authorized employees of the department of public works shall turn off or turn on the water to any premises at the curb stop valve. For the purpose of testing or repairing pipes, valves and fittings, or a customer's piping and plumbing, licensed plumbers may secure permission from the department of public works to turn off and turn on water; but in each such instance, the curb stop must be left in the same position as it was found. 
(Code 1975, § 26-22; Code 1995, § 114-81) 
Sec. 114-101. - Service line maintenance and specifications. 
    All water service lines between the city main and the water meter shall be maintained by and at the expense of the city. The balance of any such lines shall be maintained by and at the expense of the consumer or owner of the property being served. All persons connecting to a city service or laying their own private water lines shall be required to use only type K soft copper pipe or PVC (polyvinyl chloride) pipe conforming to Schedule 40 (ASTM D-1785) or PV-200 (SDR 21) (ASTM D-2241), latest revised edition; provided all pipe has a minimum pressure rating of 200 psi. The pipe shall be so marked at five-foot intervals and shall also be marked with the NSF seal of approval. Joints shall be solvent weld and fittings shall be of a quality not less than that of the pipe; and further provided that type K copper pipe is used for the gooseneck at the main and at least three feet of slack loop at the meter. 
(Code 1975, § 26-23; Code 1995, § 114-82) 
Sec. 114-102. - Reading, inspecting and testing meters. 
(a)  The department of public works, by its authorized personnel, shall have the right, at any reasonable time, to read, inspect, remove or test any water meter, and temporarily disconnect water service for such purpose. If any customer doubts the accuracy or correctness of the meter measuring his service, he may, upon application, have the meter tested. The meter shall be tested in the shops of the department by means of apparatus there provided, in the presence of the customer, if he desires to be present. If the test discloses an error against the customer of more than three percent in the meter's registry, the excess of the consumption in the three previous months' readings shall be credited to the customer's account, and the city shall bear the cost of the test. If no such error in registry is found, the person who has requested the test shall pay a charge fixed for such test. Before making the test of any meter, the person requesting the test shall make a deposit with the city clerk of the amount charged for such test as follows: 
(1)  Five-eighths by three-fourths-inch meter, $50.00. 
(2)  One inch or larger, $100.00 or the actual cost, as charged by an independent testing company, whichever is larger. 
Provided, however, that the city manager may, if he sees fit or has reason to believe that a meter is out of order, cause such meter to be tested by the department of public works at the expense of the city. 
(b)  After having been read, at the written request of a customer, a water meter shall be read a second or subsequent time. The amount charged for each such second or subsequent reading shall be $10.00 and shall be paid to the city at the time the request is made. 
(Code 1975, § 26-26; Code 1995, § 114-83; Ord. No. 1229, § 1, 9-16-2008) 
Sec. 114-103. - Customer's liability for expense of repairing or replacing damaged, lost, etc., property of system. 
    In all cases where meters, boxes, curb stop valves or other appurtenances of the city's water system are lost, injured or destroyed by willful action or as a result of carelessness or negligence on the part of owner or occupant of the premises, they shall be replaced or repaired at the expense of the owner or occupant. In case of nonpayment of such charge, the water shall be cut off, and will not be turned on until such charges are paid. 
(Code 1975, § 26-26; Code 1995, § 114-84) 
Sec. 114-104. - Use restrictions during water shortage; penalty. 
(a)  In case of emergency caused by a shortage of water in the city water system, it shall be the duty of the city manager to immediately give notice, by publication, to the water customers not to use water from the system for any purpose other than for strictly domestic use and such other use as he may designate, so long as the water shortage lasts. Until the city manager proclaims the emergency at an end, it shall be unlawful for any person to use water obtained from the city water system for the purpose of watering or sprinkling a lawn, flowerbed, park, hedge or garden, or to use such water for any purpose other than domestic use or such other uses as the city manager may have designated. 
(b)  Any person who engages in any activity prohibited by this section is guilty of an offense against the city, and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than the maximum set forth in section 1-7. 
(Code 1975, § 26-27; Code 1995, § 114-85; Ord. No. 1014, § 1, 7-21-1998) 
Sec. 114-105. - City's right to interrupt service. 
    The city reserves the right, at any time and without notice, to shut off the water supply for any emergencies, repairs, extensions or maintenance on city water lines. The city shall not be responsible for any damages which might result from stopping or interrupting water service. 
(Code 1975, § 26-28; Code 1995, § 114-86) 
Sec. 114-106. - Sale of surplus water. 
(a)  Sale of water in discretion of city. The city may sell, in its sole discretion, surplus water, so long as the same is available, to applicants outside the city limits under the terms and conditions set forth in this section. 
(b)  Application; required information. Each applicant shall make a written application to the chief inspector setting forth the following information and whatever additional information the city may require from time to time hereafter: 
(1)  The description of the type of residence, business or institution making the application for surplus water. 
(2)  A sworn affidavit that the use will be for potable water and for no other use and that the applicant understands that the sale of water may be curtailed or completely eliminated upon 24 hours' verbal notice in the sole discretion of the city manager that there is no longer surplus water available for sale for use outside the city limits. 
(3)  That the sale of surplus water will be for one year only and at the end of such year the application must be renewed and is again dependent upon surplus water being available for sale by the city. 
(4)  The application must show the number and type of taps and fixtures to be used by the applicant. 
(5)  The application must include an estimate of the total gallonage to be used on a yearly basis. 
(6)  The application must show the size of meter needed to service the applicant. 
(7)  The application is subject to written approval of the City of Oklahoma City being received by the City of Yukon that Oklahoma City concurs in the sale of surplus water to the applicant. 
(8)  The application will bear an initial fee in the sum established by resolution and such fee shall not be refunded if the application is denied; and a yearly renewal fee of established by resolution will be charged which shall also not be refunded if the application is denied. 
(9)  The application must state that all expense of installation to furnish water, including any street boring, shall be the sole expense of the applicant. 
(10)  The application shall show that the rate to be charged to the applicant will be twice the rate charged to residents of the city for similar usage. 
(11)  The application shall state that the applicant will comply with all ordinances and regulations of the city pertaining to plumbing, water lines and the use of water. 
(c)  Approval by city council. All applications, upon receiving staff approval, will be brought before the city council for approval or denial in the sole discretion of the city council. 
(d)  Tap fee and meter charge. The applicant shall pay tap fees in the sum of $100.00 and a meter charge in the sum of $175.00 for a three-quarter-inch meter or the cost of a larger meter. 
(Code 1975, § 26-29; Code 1995, § 114-87) 
Sec. 114-107. - Mandatory water connections. 
(a)  The owners of all houses, buildings or properties for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public water line, is required to install water lines tying in to the city water supply, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided such public line is within 250 feet of the property line. 
(b)  All costs and expenses incident of the installation and connection of a building water line shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building water line. 
(Code 1995, § 114-88; Ord. No. 977, 3-4-1997) 
Sec. 114-108. - Hydrant flush meter/construction meter. 
(a)  Issuance of meter with permit. Upon issuance of a permit issued by the city, each permit holder will be issued a hydrant flush meter/construction meter to measure the amount of water taken through the hydrant connection. All such meters shall be owned exclusively by the city. No person issued such a permit shall take or use water from the hydrant without properly connecting and engaging the meter. 
(b)  Reading meters. The meter issued to a permit holder shall be returned to the city on or before the expiration date of the permit. Upon return to the city, the meter shall be read and the permit holder shall pay for the water used at the rates previously set out. However, as one of the conditions of the permit, the city may require the permit holder to periodically present the meter issued to him during the life of his permit to the city for inspection and reading. Billings for the water used shall be rendered at the time the meter is read and shall become due as provided for regular water bills elsewhere in this chapter. The permit holder may be required to phone in meter readings periodically. 
(c)  Security deposit. In order to guarantee payment of water used, and in order to insure return of meters and the timely reading of said meters, each permit holder shall be required to make a cash deposit in the amount of $1,500.00. A written receipt shall be issued as evidence of the deposit. The deposit will be applied, without interest, to the final bill upon return of the meter in good condition and the payment of all charges for water used. Any credit balance will be refunded to the permit holder. 
(d)  Failure to return meter. In the event the holder of a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this section fails to return the hydrant flush meter within ten days after the expiration date of his permit, the security deposit shall be deemed forfeited to the city, and shall be applied to pay the cost of replacing said meter and to satisfy nonpayment of city water used. In addition, a penalty charge equal to the charge for 100,000 gallons of water shall be assessed if the meter remains in the permit holder's possession after the expiration date. No subsequent permit shall be issued and all existing permits shall be canceled to any person who has violated any other provisions of this section, or its indebtedness to the city for water use or damage to hydrants or flush meters is delinquent. 
(e)  Usage regulation. Every person authorized by permit to open fire hydrants at the location specified on said permit shall replace the caps on the outlets when such are not in use and shall keep hose connections in good repair. Failure to perform these duties shall be sufficient cause to prohibit further use of hydrants and sufficient grounds to deny subsequent permits. 
(Code 1995, § 114-89; Ord. No. 1095, § 1, 2-6-2002) 
Sec. 114-109. - Installation and use of individual water wells. 
(a)  Where an approved water supply is not available as described in Section 114-107, the subdivision, institution, commercial or industrial structure or single-family dwelling may be served by individual water wells upon the express approval of the city engineer, the planning commission and the city council. Individual water wells must meet federal and state drinking water standards. 
(b)  Water wells shall be located on the premises where the well is intended to be used and there shall be no interconnection of any kind between such well with any other water source. 
(c)  No person shall drill or enlarge any domestic water well or subsequently use from such well, except upon making application on forms provided by development services and paying such fees as approved by resolution of the city council. 
(d)  Individual water wells shall meet all state health design standards and construction specifications and shall provide adequate capacity to meet the domestic demand. 
(e)  Individual water wells shall have a minimum capacity of five gallons per minute. If soil and geological data indicates a possible groundwater deficiency, the applicant must demonstrate, at his expense that the water is available in adequate quantity and quality and will not overly reduce or damage the aquifer. The owner shall provide water samples to the Oklahoma Department of Health for monthly testing to assure proper water quality. 
(f)  Wells may be located anywhere on the property; however, any well located outside of the rear yard of the property may have only the wellhead exposed with no other accompanying structure, pursuant to the zoning code of the city. No well may be drilled on any easement or right-of-way. 
(g)  All drilling mud must be removed manually and under no circumstance may the drilling mud escape the property. 
(h)  As a fire protection measure, a minimum distance of 50 feet separation between residential structures shall be maintained in any residential district utilizing private water wells as the main source of water. 
(Ord. No. 1322, § 4, 7-21-2015; Ord. No. 1379 , § 1, 12-4-2018) 
Sec. 114-110. - Drilling commercial water wells. 
(a)  Any person or organization wanting to drill a commercial water well inside the corporate city limits shall file an application with the director of community developmental services and pay the approved fee for the expense of inspections and monitoring. Said fees to be established by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  The applicant shall comply with all federal and state laws as well as the rules and regulations of the Oklahoma Water Resources Board and the Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality. 
(c)  The application shall contain the name and address of the requesting party, the purpose of the well, the location of the well and a study prepared by a licensed, bonded hydrologist reflecting the volume and availability of fresh water. The study shall show the area the water will be drawn from and the size of the aquifer. The study shall have detail maps as to the location and surrounding property, the depth of the well, the water bearing sand including thickness, the casing type, casing thickness and depth, the geography area of the water bearing sands, the maximum rate of flow, the maximum rate of usage that would cause no damage or reduction in levels of the water bearing sands, description of material used to secure the casing, pumping devise and power source. The applicate shall provide monthly samples of the water to the Oklahoma Department of Heath to assure the safety of the water. 
(d)  This section shall apply to all proposed water wells and there shall be no distinction made as to the proposed use of the water. 
(e)  Notice shall be given to adjacent property owners within 1,000 feet of the proposed well location. 
(f)  Should there be any objections filed within 30 days, the mater shall be heard by the Yukon city council. 
(g)  If the permit is approved, the permit will issue upon the posting of a $5,000.00 bond. 
(Ord. No. 1379 , § 2, 12-4-2018) 
Secs. 114-111-114-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWER SERVICE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority regarding sewers generally, 11 O.S. § 37-201 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-132. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Best management practices means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, installation of equipment, and other management practices to control and limit the introduction of prohibited or objectionable discharges, including FOG, into sewer facilities. 
    Fats, oils, and grease or FOG means any substance such as a vegetable or animal product that is used in, or is a by-product of, the cooking or food preparation process, and that turns or may turn viscous or solidifies with a change in temperature or other conditions. 
    Food service establishment or FSE means: 
(1)  Facilities within the boundaries of the city, operating in a permanently constructed structure such as a room, building, or place, or portion thereof, maintained, used, or operated for the purpose of storing, preparing, serving, or manufacturing, packaging, or otherwise handling food for sale to other entities, or for consumption by the public, its members, or employees, and which has any process or device that uses or produces FOG. 
(2)  Multiple-family dwelling where more than ten units utilize the same service connection to the sewer system. 
    Grease interceptor or interceptor means a multi-compartment device that is constructed in different sizes and is generally required to be located, according to the International Plumbing Code, underground between a food service establishment and the connection to the sewer system. These devices primarily use gravity to separate FOG from the wastewater as it moves from one compartment to the next. These devices shall have at least one accessible inspection hatch and must be cleaned, maintained, and have the FOG removed and disposed of in a proper manner on regular intervals to ensure effective and efficient operation. 
    Manifest means that receipt which is retained by the generator of wastes for disposing recyclable wastes or liquid wastes as required by the city. 
    Sanitary sewer overflow (SSO ) means anytime that raw or untreated sewage is spilled outside the sewer system. 
    Sewer facility or system means any property belonging to the city or other public agency used in the treatment, reclamation, reuse, transportation, or disposal of wastewater. 
(Code 1995, § 114-110; Ord. No. 1272, § 1, 2-7-2010) 
Sec. 114-133. - Mandatory sewer connections. 
(a)  The owners of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is required to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided such public sewer is within 150 feet of the property line. 
(b)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of a building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Code 1975, §§ 26-4, 26-40; Code 1995, § 114-111) 
Sec. 114-134. - Every building to have separate sewer; exception. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building, except that, where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building. 
(Code 1975, § 26-41; Code 1995, § 114-112) 
Sec. 114-135. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the director of public works, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 26-42; Code 1995, § 114-113) 
Sec. 114-136. - Barricades and lights at excavations; restoration of public property. 
    All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1975, § 26-48; Code 1995, § 114-114) 
Secs. 114-137-114-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 114-156. - Construction of new sewerage facilities. 
(a)  No person shall let a contract for, or commence the construction of, any sanitary sewerage system, extensions or sewage facilities, either in whole or in part, or place or permit to be placed or discharged or permit to flow into the existing city sanitary system any sewage, unless such person has first obtained a written permit signed by the director. The application for permission to connect to the city sewerage facilities shall be made by written request to the director and shall be supplemented by complete plans, specifications, engineering reports and other information as deemed necessary by the director and the state department of health. Two or more copies of the plans, specifications, engineering reports and other pertinent information shall be forwarded by the city to the state department of health for review, approval and the issuance of a permit for construction as required by state law. 
(b)  Plans and specifications forwarded to the state department of health shall be accompanied by an application for a permit to construct (state health department for number 534), properly executed and signed by the responsible city official, where the city plans to accept the new sewerage facilities upon completion of construction. In the event the city does not plan to accept responsibility for the facilities after construction has been completed, the application for a permit to construct must be signed by the party who will be responsible for the upkeep and maintenance of the proposed sewerage facilities. 
(c)  A permit to connect any new sanitary sewerage system, extensions or sewerage facilities to existing city sewerage facilities shall not become effective until the new installation is completed to the satisfaction of the city, and is in accordance with the requirements of the state department of health. The director shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction, and in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the director when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. 
(Code 1975, § 26-3; Code 1995, § 114-126) 
Sec. 114-157. - Specifications for PVC sewer pipe. 
(a)  Polyvinyl chloride pipe, referred to hereinafter as PVC plastic, shall conform to the requirements of ASTM Standard 3034-7a and any subsequent revisions thereof, together with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  These specifications cover PVC plastic sewer pipe intended to be used for the conveyance of sewage, industrial wastes and stormwater. 
(c)  PVC plastic sewer pipe shall be embedded in accordance with the provisions of the standard recommended practice for underground installation of flexible thermoplastic pipe. To assure compliance, all PVC plastic pipe shall be inspected for deflection by pulling a sphere, cylinder or other acceptable measuring device through the pipe. The maximum allowable pipe deflection for completely backfilled nonrigid sewer pipe shall not exceed five percent of the nominal internal diameter. 
(Code 1975, § 26-7; Code 1995, § 114-127) 
Sec. 114-158. - Video inspection of sanitary sewer lines and systems. 
    Any contractor who constructs and installs sanitary sewer lines and systems shall perform a video inspection of such lines in accordance with the technical specifications adopted by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 26-8; Code 1995, § 114-128) 
Secs. 114-159-114-184. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 114-185. - General specifications. 
(a)  The building sewer shall consist of all sewer lines of a structure up to the connection with the public sewer and shall be centrifugally spun cast-iron soil pipe ASTM Specification A-74-1966; vitrified clay sewer pipe ASTM Specification C13-44T; or Schedule 40 DWV-PVC or Schedule 40 DWV-ABS plastic pipe and fittings. Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of either cast-iron soil pipe or Schedule 40 DWV-PVC or Schedule 40 DWV-ABS. Schedule 40 DWV-PVC and Schedule 40 DWV-ABS pipe shall be sand bedded. If installed in filled or unstable ground, however, the building sewer shall be of cast-iron soil pipe or Schedule 40 DWV-PVC or Schedule 40 DWV-ABS and laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle approved by the public works superintendent. 
(b)  All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Cast-iron pipe joints shall be flexible rubber gaskets. All joints in vitrified clay pipe shall be equivalent to ASTM Specification C-425 or between such pipe and cast-iron or Schedule 40 DWV-PVC or Schedule 40 DWV-ABS joints shall be made with approved adaptors and flexible rubber gaskets. Joints for Schedule 40 DWV-PVC or Schedule 40 DWV-ABS used as underground piping under a building structure or used under or within concrete or other slab floors which are in contact with earth shall be no hub pipe. Only solvent cements and epoxy adhesives supplied by the pipe manufacturer and approved by the National Sanitation Foundation may be used in making joints. The label on the container of the solvent or adhesive shall have the manufacturer's name and address, type of plastic, such as PE, PVC, ABS, etc., the solvent or adhesive may be used to join. The manufacturer's recommendations shall be specifically followed in the use of these cements and adhesives. Other jointing materials and methods may be used only by approval of the public works superintendent. 
(Code 1975, § 26-43; Code 1995, § 114-141) 
Sec. 114-186. - Size and slope. 
    The size and slope of a building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the director of public works, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth inch per foot. 
(Code 1975, § 26-44; Code 1995, § 114-142) 
Sec. 114-187. - Location; depth; grade; changes in direction. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment, insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. All buildings three stories or more in height shall have appropriate restraining fittings or expansion joints used at each floor level. 
(Code 1975, § 26-45; Code 1995, § 114-143)
