(8)  Parking is permitted only if the motor home or travel trailer, while parked in this zone, is: 
a.  Not used for dwelling purposes, except one motor home or travel trailer may be used by the owner or tenant of the premises, friends, relatives or guests for dwelling purposes for a maximum of 21 days in any calendar year, and a maximum of 14 days at any one time on any given lot; provided that such motor home or travel trailer shall not be connected to any utility, other than temporary electrical hookups; and provided further that the host person shall receive no compensation for such occupancy or use; provided no such motor home or travel trailer shall discharge any litter, sewage, effluent or other matter, except into sanitary facilities designed to dispose of such material; 
b.  Not permanently connected to sewer lines, water lines, or electricity. The motor home or travel trailer may only be connected to electricity temporarily for charging batteries. Hookup facilities shall comply with applicable state law and the National Electrical Code; and 
c.  Not used for storage of goods, materials or equipment other than those items considered to be part of the motor home or travel trailer or essential for its immediate use. 
(b)  No commercial vehicle which exceeds 14,500 pounds gross vehicle weight and in no case a commercial vehicle used for hauling explosives, gasoline or liquefied petroleum products shall be permitted. 
(c)  Commercial vehicles not otherwise prohibited, motor homes, boats, boat and trailer, boat trailers, camper shells not attached to a vehicle, cargo hauling, utility, and travel trailers may be parked anywhere on the premises during active loading or unloading for a period not to exceed 72 hours; provided: 
(1)  No electricity or propane fuel is used, except when necessary to prepare the commercial vehicle, motor home, boats, boat and trailer, boat trailers, camper shells not attached to a vehicle, cargo hauling, utility, and travel trailer for use; 
(2)  No part of the commercial vehicle, motor home, boats, boat and trailer, boat trailers, camper shells not attached to a vehicle, cargo hauling, utility, and travel trailer extends over the public sidewalk or within six feet of the face of the curb, or if there is no curb, then six feet from the edge of the pavement; and 
(3)  No sight triangle as required by ordinance is violated. 
(d)  Prior to a motor home or travel trailer being used for temporary dwelling purposes as permitted in subsection (a)(8)a of this section, a permit shall be obtained from the city police department. A permit fee established by resolution shall be paid by the person making application for the permit. Payment of the required fee and compliance with all the provisions of this chapter shall entitle the applicant to a permit. The police department shall establish procedures to identify vehicles for which a permit has been obtained. 
(Code 1975, § 13-7; Code 1995, § 66-7; Ord. No. 993, 8-5-1997) 
Secs. 210-8-210-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FREESTANDING MOBILE HOMES AND TRAVEL TRAILERS USED FOR OFFICE PURPOSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 210-33. - Application of and compliance with article. 
    This article shall apply to freestanding mobile homes and travel trailers and other temporary buildings used for office purposes and any person desiring to so use such a mobile home, travel trailer or other temporary building shall comply with the terms, conditions and requirements of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 13-17; Code 1995, § 66-31) 
Sec. 210-34. - Location restricted. 
    A mobile home, travel trailer or temporary building governed by this article shall be located only in an industrial or commercial zoning district and shall be consistent with the surrounding and adjoining land uses and structures. 
(Code 1975, § 13-18; Code 1995, § 66-32) 
Sec. 210-35. - Required modifications and equipment; to be used as office only. 
    A mobile home, travel trailer or temporary building governed by this article shall be sufficiently modified to preclude all living room and bedroom furniture and fixtures, and be equipped with normal office furnishings and equipment, and shall be used as an office and for no other purpose, except that the occupancy of a mobile home or travel trailer is permitted for a full-time salaried night watchman and his family. 
(Code 1975, § 13-19; Code 1995, § 66-33) 
Sec. 210-36. - Connection to city utilities. 
    A mobile home, travel trailer or temporary building governed by this article shall be connected to the city utilities, provided such utilities are within 150 feet of the property line of the property upon which the structure is located. 
(Code 1975, § 13-20; Code 1995, § 66-34) 
Secs. 210-37-210-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TEMPORARY USE PERMIT 

Sec. 210-61. - Required. 
    No person shall use any freestanding mobile home or travel trailer or any other temporary building for office purposes, unless he has a currently valid temporary use permit issued in accord with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1975, § 13-26; Code 1995, § 66-46) 
Sec. 210-62. - Application. 
    Application for a permit under this division shall be submitted to the city council. Such application shall set forth the kind of business to be conducted and all necessary information that may be required for the proper consideration of the application. The city council, in its discretion, may approve or reject the application, and its decision shall be final. 
(Code 1975, § 13-27; Code 1995, § 66-47) 
Sec. 210-63. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
    The city council may impose such conditions, restrictions and requirements upon the applicant, as a prerequisite to the issuance of a permit applied for under this division, as the city council shall deem necessary. 
(Code 1975, § 13-28; Code 1995, § 66-48) 
Sec. 210-64. - Issuance procedure; fee; contents. 
    Upon the approval of an application by the city council, the applicant shall obtain a temporary use permit required by this division from the city clerk, by paying a permit fee established by resolution. Such permit shall set forth its expiration date and the terms and conditions under which the same is issued, as ordered and directed by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 13-29; Code 1995, § 66-49) 
Sec. 210-65. - Term. 
    A permit issued under this division shall be valid for such period of time, not exceeding one year, as if fixed by the city council, unless sooner revoked. 
(Code 1975, § 13-30; Code 1995, § 66-50) 
Sec. 210-66. - Not transferable. 
    No permit issued under the provisions of this division, or any renewal thereof, shall be transferable. 
(Code 1975, § 13-31; Code 1995, § 66-51) 
Sec. 210-67. - Renewal. 
    At the expiration date of a temporary use permit issued under this division, the original holder of such permit may make request to the city council for a renewal of the permit, by showing proof that such original permit has not been transferred; that the mobile home, travel trailer or temporary building is being used as an office and for no other purpose, except as provided in section 210-35; that the original holder of such permit is conducting the same kind of business for which the permit was issued; and that the original holder of such permit is complying with all the terms and conditions under which the original permit was issued, as ordered and directed by the city council. The city council, in its discretion, may approve or reject such request for the renewal of the permit, and the decision of the city council shall be final. No additional permit fee shall be charged for such renewal. 
(Code 1975, § 13-32; Code 1995, § 66-52) 
Sec. 210-68. - Revocation. 
    If, at any time, it shall be determined by the city council that an original temporary use permit issued under this division, or any renewal thereof, has been transferred by the original holder of such permit to any other person, or that the mobile home, travel trailer or temporary building is being used for any other purpose other than an office, except as provided in section 210-35, or that the original holder of such permit is not conducting the same kind of business for which the permit was issued, or that the holder of such permit is not complying with the terms and conditions under which the permit was issued, the permit shall be revoked by the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 13-33; Code 1995, § 66-53) 
Sec. 210-69. - Not intended for use in residential and fully developed areas of city. 
    It is the intent of the city council that temporary use permits for mobile homes and travel trailers used for night watchmen and their families shall be located only in areas not served by regular police patrols and that such use shall not be adjacent to residential areas or in fully developed areas of the city. Such uses shall be limited to areas south of I-40, west of a point which is one-half mile west of Eleventh Street from the south city limits to Main Street; north of Main Street from the west city limits to Eleventh Street; north of Ash from Eleventh Street to Cornwell; north of Wagner Road from Cornwell east to the east city limits; and an area one-quarter mile north of Main Street and south of Main Street from the east city limits to Mustang Road. 
(Code 1975, § 13-34; Code 1995, § 66-54) 
Secs. 210-70-210-96. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOME, RV AND TRAVEL TRAILER PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 210-97. - Applicability of other city ordinances. 
    All ordinances enacted by the city pertaining to traffic and vehicles, the control of pets and other animals, and the prevention of crime shall be fully effective within a park as though streets and driveways were dedicated to public use, and the consent and agreement of the owner of the park and streets and highways thereto shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of a license for the operation of the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-44; Code 1995, § 66-76) 
Sec. 210-98. - Building permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to construct a mobile home park or travel trailer park or make any additions to a mobile home park or travel trailer park shall, before commencing work thereon, secure a written permit from the building inspector so to do, and no physical improvements shall be begun and no building or structure shall be erected, altered, repaired or added to, unless a written permit therefor has been previously secured. The application for a building permit shall contain a plot plan drawn to a scale of one inch equals 100 feet. Such plot plan shall show: 
(1)  The area and dimensions of the tract of land. 
(2)  The number, location and size of all mobile home or travel trailer spaces. 
(3)  The location and width of roadways, walkways, buffer strips and recreational areas. 
(4)  The location of service buildings and other proposed structures. 
(5)  Provisions for drainage. 
(6)  The location and size of utility lines and treatment facilities. 
(7)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed or to be constructed within the park, including a detailed sketch of at least one typical trailer space. Ten copies of the plot plan shall be submitted with the application for a building permit. 
(b)  The fee for the permit provided for in this section shall be as prescribed in section 204-30. 
(Code 1975, § 13-45; Code 1995, § 66-77) 
Sec. 210-99. - Permit to construct mobile home or travel trailer space. 
    A permit issued by the building inspector shall be required for the construction of a mobile home space or a travel trailer space in a park. This section shall not be applicable to spaces authorized by the initial building permit issued for the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-46; Code 1995, § 66-78) 
Sec. 210-100. - Plumbing and electrical alterations or repairs. 
    All plumbing and electrical alterations or repairs in a park shall be made in accordance with the ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-47; Code 1995, § 66-79) 
Sec. 210-101. - Additions or alterations to exterior of mobile homes. 
    A permit issued by the building inspector shall be required before any structural addition or alteration to the exterior of a mobile home takes place in a mobile home park. No addition or alteration to the exterior of a mobile home located in a mobile home park shall be permitted, unless of the same type of construction or materials as the mobile home affected. All such additions or alterations shall be in compliance with applicable state statutes and city ordinances. No permit under this section shall be required for the addition of steps, canopies, awnings or antennas. 
(Code 1975, § 13-48; Code 1995, § 66-80) 
Sec. 210-102. - Skirting of mobile homes. 
    Skirting of mobile homes in a park is permissible, but areas enclosed by such skirting shall be maintained so as not to provide a harborage for rodents or create a fire hazard. 
(Code 1975, § 13-49; Code 1995, § 66-81) 
Sec. 210-103. - Structures other than mobile homes on mobile home spaces. 
    No structure other than a mobile home shall be permitted on a mobile home space in a park, except that one structure not to exceed 250 cubic feet may be used for storage on each such space. 
(Code 1975, § 13-50; Code 1995, § 66-82) 
Sec. 210-104. - Minimum height of power supply lines. 
    No power supply line in a park shall be suspended less than 18 feet above the ground, unless otherwise approved by the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 13-51; Code 1995, § 66-83) 
Sec. 210-105. - Exterior lighting requirements. 
    Exterior lighting shall be provided as necessary for safety and convenience of occupants of the park. Streets, areas at the entrances to buildings used by occupants at night, and walkways for use at night shall be lighted at night, when the park is occupied, with a minimum illumination of at least 0.3 footcandle. All lights shall be so located and shielded as to prevent direct illumination of sleeping areas. 
(Code 1975, § 13-52; Code 1995, § 66-84) 
Sec. 210-106. - Electrical outlets. 
    An electrical outlet supplying at least 100 amperes shall be provided for each mobile home space and travel trailer space in a park. The installation shall comply with the electrical code and all other applicable ordinances. Such electrical outlets and extension lines shall be grounded and weatherproofed. Plug receptacles shall also be grounded and weatherproofed. 
(Code 1975, § 13-53; Code 1995, § 66-85) 
Sec. 210-107. - Fuel piping. 
    All piping from outside fuel storage tanks or cylinders to mobile homes or travel trailers in a park shall be of acceptable material, as determined by the building inspector, and shall be permanently installed and securely fastened in place and shall not be located inside or beneath the mobile home or travel trailer or less than five feet from any mobile home or travel trailer exit. 
(Code 1975, § 13-54; Code 1995, § 66-86) 
Sec. 210-108. - General maintenance standards; responsibility of attendant or caretaker for violations of article. 
    The licensee, or a duly authorized attendant or caretaker, shall be in charge at all times to keep the park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition and free from any unsightly condition or condition that will be a menace to the health of any park occupant or the public. The attendant or caretaker shall be answerable, with the licensee, for the violation of any provision of this article to which the licensee is subject. 
(Code 1975, § 13-55; Code 1995, § 66-87) 
Sec. 210-109. - To be kept free of litter, rubbish and flammable materials. 
    Park areas shall be kept free of litter, rubbish and flammable materials. 
(Code 1975, § 13-56; Code 1995, § 66-88) 
Sec. 210-110. - Igniting of fires. 
    Fires in parks shall be made or ignited only in stoves and other cooking or heating equipment intended for such purposes. 
(Code 1975, § 13-57; Code 1995, § 66-89) 
Sec. 210-111. - Occupants to give owner access to premises. 
    It shall be the duty of every occupant of a park to give the owner thereof or his agents or employees access to any part of the park or his premises, at reasonable times, for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this article, or with any lawful regulations adopted hereunder, or with any lawful order issued pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 13-58; Code 1995, § 66-90) 
Sec. 210-112. - Guest register. 
(a)  Each licensee shall keep a register containing a record of all mobile home and travel trailer owners and occupants located within the park. The register shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or occupant of each mobile home and travel trailer and motor vehicle by which it is towed. 
(2)  The make, model, year and license number of each mobile home and travel trailer and motor vehicle. 
(3)  The state, territory or country issuing such license. 
(4)  The date of arrival and of departure of each mobile home and travel trailer. 
(5)  Whether or not a mobile home is a dependent or independent mobile home. 
(b)  The park shall keep the register available for inspection at all times by law enforcement officers, the building inspector, the city engineer, public health officials and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained in the register. The register record of each occupant registered shall not be destroyed for a period of one year following the date of departure of the registrant from the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-59; Code 1995, § 66-91) 
Sec. 210-113. - Inspections. 
    The building inspector and the city engineer are hereby authorized and directed to make inspections to determine the condition of mobile home and travel trailer parks located within the city, in order to perform their duty of safeguarding the health, safety and welfare of occupants of mobile home and travel trailer parks and of the general public. 
(Code 1975, § 13-60; Code 1995, § 66-92) 
Secs. 210-114-210-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT 

Sec. 210-140. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain a park within the city, without first having obtained a conditional use permit in accordance with the provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1975, § 13-66; Code 1995, § 66-106) 
Sec. 210-141. - Applicant may be required to furnish plot plan. 
    Upon request of the planning commission or the city council, the applicant for a conditional use permit for a park shall furnish a plot plan meeting the requirements of section 210-98. 
(Code 1975, § 13-67; Code 1995, § 66-107) 
Sec. 210-142. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
    The city council shall require, as a prerequisite for the issuance of a conditional use permit required by this division, the following: 
(1)  The granting of an easement for public utilities, sidewalks and street or road purposes, or to widen existing streets or roads adjoining the park; and the paving of one-half of any unpaved street or road adjacent to or adjoining the park or widening and paving the widened portion of any paved street or road adjacent to or adjoining the park. 
(2)  Where the park is adjoining or adjacent to a city street or streets, or where streets within the park are dedicated to public use, such streets, or the widening thereof, shall be in accordance with the standard street specifications of the city. Where the park is adjoining or adjacent to a city street or streets, the owner shall install sidewalks in the manner required for sidewalks in R-1 residential districts. 
(3)  The reservation of space for recreation or play areas shall constitute at least eight percent of the gross land area and should be provided in a central location. Provisions for separate adult and tot lots are encouraged. 
(4)  Suitable screening or fencing to protect adjoining property owners. 
(Code 1975, § 13-68; Code 1995, § 66-108) 
Sec. 210-143. - Failure to commence or complete construction after issuance. 
(a)  If the permittee has not commenced the construction of the park within 12 months from the date of the issuance of the conditional use permit, the city council may thereafter revoke the permit. 
(b)  If the permittee has commenced the construction of the park within 12 months from the date of granting the conditional use permit, but has not substantially completed the construction of the park in accordance with the park plans submitted to the city, the city manager shall so advise the city council and the city council may revoke the conditional use permit or may extend the time for the completion of the construction of the park, or may authorize a change in the park plan or revoke the conditional use permit as to that part of the land on which the park has not been constructed. 
(Code 1975, § 13-69; Code 1995, § 66-109) 
Sec. 210-144. - Transfer. 
    A conditional use permit for a park may not be transferred by the permittee prior to the complete construction of the park in accordance with the park plans submitted to and approved by the city. After a park is constructed, the conditional use permit shall be transferred to each subsequent owner of the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-70; Code 1995, § 66-110) 
Secs. 210-145-210-171. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE 

Sec. 210-172. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate any park within the limits of the city, unless he holds a valid license issued annually by the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 13-76; Code 1995, § 66-121) 
Sec. 210-173. - Application. 
    Application for an original park license shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the application, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The interest of the applicant in the location and legal description of the park. 
(3)  A complete plot plan of the park showing compliance with all applicable provisions of this article, the zoning ordinance of the city and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(4)  Such further information as may be requested by the building inspector or the city engineer related to the foregoing and consistent with the intent of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 13-77; Code 1995, § 66-122) 
Sec. 210-174. - Fee. 
    There shall be paid to the city clerk an annual license fee for each park, which fee shall be in an amount established by resolution. 
(Code 1975, § 13-78; Code 1995, § 66-123) 
Sec. 210-175. - Issuance. 
    A park license will be issued by the city clerk after notification by the building inspector and city engineer that minimum requirements have been complied with and that the park is permitted by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-79; Code 1995, § 66-124) 
Sec. 210-176. - Posting. 
    A park license issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted in the office or on the premises of the park at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 13-80; Code 1995, § 66-125) 
Sec. 210-177. - Transfer. 
(a)  Application for the transfer of a park license shall be made to the city clerk, who shall issue a license to the transferee, upon approval of the building inspector and upon compliance by the applicant with all pertinent provisions of this article and other ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(b)  Every person holding such a park license shall notify the city clerk, in writing, within 24 hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of his interest in or control of the licensed park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-81; Code 1995, § 66-126) 
Sec. 210-178. - Expiration and renewal. 
    A license issued under this division shall expire one year from the date of issuance and shall be renewed annually thereafter. Applications for renewals of park licenses shall be made in writing by the holder of the license and shall contain the following: 
(1)  Any change in the information submitted since the time the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted. 
(2)  Other information as may be requested by the building inspector or city engineer consistent with the intent of this article. 
(3)  Where any change in the park has been made since the time of the information submitted for the original license or the latest renewal thereof, the applicant for a renewal of such license shall furnish the information required to be submitted by section 210-98, or so much of such information as the city clerk shall require. 
(Code 1975, § 13-82; Code 1995, § 66-127) 
Sec. 210-179. - Suspension and revocation. 
(a)  Whenever the building inspector or the city engineer determines that a violation of any provision of this article or other applicable ordinances or regulations exists in a park, he shall give notice of such violation to the park licensee. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance. 
(3)  Contain an outline of remedial action, which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this article and other applicable ordinances and regulations. 
(4)  Specify a reasonable time, not to exceed 90 days, for the performance of any act it requires, and inform the licensee that his license will be suspended if such act is not completed within such time. 
(5)  Be served upon the licensee or his agent; provided that, such notice shall be deemed as properly served upon the licensee or his agent when a copy thereof has been sent by certified mail to his last known address. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of the time specified in the notice given pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the building inspector or the city engineer shall inspect the park and, if the remedial action required by such notice has not been taken or completed, he shall suspend the park license. The park licensee or his agent shall be given notice of such suspension, which notice shall be served in the manner prescribed in subsection (a)(5) of this section and shall advise the licensee that he has ten days in which to cease operation of the park or appeal to the city council. If such appeal is not taken within such time, the license shall be deemed automatically revoked and it shall be unlawful for the licensee or any other person to continue the operation of the park. 
(c)  The licensee upon whom a notice of suspension has been served pursuant to subsection (b) of this section may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the city council. Such person shall file with the building inspector a written request for such hearing, setting forth briefly the grounds for such request, within ten days after the day the notice of suspension was served. The hearing shall be held at the next city council meeting for which the agenda has not been completed, or at a later meeting, if so requested by the petitioner, should the building inspector determine sufficient cause for such delay exists. 
(d)  After the hearing provided for in subsection (c) of this section, the city council shall issue an order, in writing, sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the prior notice, which order shall be served as provided in subsection (a)(5) of this section. Upon failure to comply with such order, the building inspector shall issue an order declaring the license of the park to be revoked after ten days, which shall be provided to allow the licensee to file an appeal with the district court. Such order shall be in writing and delivered in person or by certified mail. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the above provisions of this section, whenever the building inspector or the city engineer finds that, by reason of a violation of this article or other applicable ordinance or regulation, an emergency exists in a park, which emergency requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he may deem necessary to meet the emergency, including the suspension of the park license. Such order shall be in writing and shall be effective immediately, notwithstanding any other provision of this section. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon petition to the city council, shall be afforded a hearing at the next regular meeting, even if the agenda has been completed. The provisions of subsections (c) and (d) of this section shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Code 1975, § 13-83; Code 1995, § 66-128) 
Secs. 210-180-210-196. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - GENERAL LAYOUT AND DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 210-197. - Park types designated. 
    Parks shall be of three types as follows: 
(1)  Mobile home parks. 
(2)  Travel trailer parks. 
(3)  Mixed mobile home and travel trailer parks. 
(Code 1975, § 13-90; Code 1995, § 66-141) 
Sec. 210-198. - Separation of mobile homes and travel trailers in mixed parks. 
    In a mixed park, separate areas shall be reserved for mobile homes and for travel trailers. No mobile home shall be permitted in the travel trailer sector and no travel trailer shall be permitted in the mobile home sector. 
(Code 1975, § 13-91; Code 1995, § 66-142) 
Sec. 210-199. - Site drainage. 
    All parks shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to insure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. Drainage shall not endanger any water supply, and shall conform to the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-92; Code 1995, § 66-143) 
Sec. 210-200. - Minimum area. 
    The minimum area of any park shall be five acres. 
(Code 1975, § 13-93; Code 1995, § 66-144) 
Sec. 210-201. - Intensity of development. 
    Intensity of development shall be limited to no more than eight mobile homes per gross acre for a mobile home park and no more than 15 travel trailers per gross acre for a travel trailer park; provided that, in no case, shall the intensity of the land use exceed 40 percent of the land area in any acre. Area used for sewage treatment facilities shall not be included in density computations. 
(Code 1975, § 13-94; Code 1995, § 66-145) 
Sec. 210-202. - Major means of ingress and egress. 
    Mobile home parks shall have their major means of ingress and egress on at least a secondary thoroughfare. Travel trailer parks and mixed parks shall have their major means of ingress and egress on at least a primary thoroughfare. 
(Code 1975, § 13-95; Code 1995, § 66-146) 
Sec. 210-203. - Buffer strip. 
    All parks shall have and maintain a buffer strip of a minimum of three feet in width along all park boundaries not bordering a street. Such strip shall be bordered by a sightproof fence or screen not less than six feet in height constructed on the park boundary line; provided, however, that upon the recommendation of the building inspector and the city engineer, and with the approval of the city council, some other proper and suitable form of screening may be used. 
(Code 1975, § 13-96; Code 1995, § 66-147) 
Sec. 210-204. - Streets. 
(a)  All mobile home spaces and travel trailer spaces in a park shall abut upon a street of not less than 26 feet in width. Such streets must have unobstructed access to a public street or highway. 
(b)  All streets within a park shall be constructed with a minimum of two inches of asphaltic concrete on a six-inch stabilized aggregate or four-inch hot-sand subbase with a plus 25 Hveem. Such streets shall have a curb and gutter section approved by the city engineer and all materials used shall meet the paving specifications of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-97; Code 1995, § 66-148) 
Sec. 210-205. - Mobile home and travel trailer spaces generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a mobile home or travel trailer to be located in a park, unless it is placed in a designated mobile home space or travel trailer space, respectively. 
(b)  Every mobile home space and travel trailer space in a park shall be clearly defined. 
(c)  Mobile home spaces in a park shall be at least 30 feet wide where pads are closest to streets. Travel trailer spaces shall be at least 25 feet wide where trailers are located closest to the street. 
(d)  The space or pad on which a mobile home or travel trailer is located in a park shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete driveway ribbons, a minimum of 40 feet in length, separated by no less than six feet nor more than 12 feet by an area which shall be treated to kill all vegetation. 
(Code 1975, § 13-98; Code 1995, § 66-149) 
Sec. 210-206. - Storage building and patio for mobile home spaces. 
(a)  Each mobile home space in a park shall have a storage building of no less than 90 cubic feet. 
(b)  Each mobile home space in a park shall have a hard surface patio of no less than 180 square feet. 
(Code 1975, § 13-99; Code 1995, § 66-150) 
Sec. 210-207. - Location of mobile homes and travel trailers with respect to service road, property lines, etc. 
(a)  Mobile homes and travel trailers shall be so located in a park that, at the nearest point, they are at least ten feet from the service road, 71/2 feet from all property lines and 15 feet from any other mobile home or travel trailer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to locate a mobile home or travel trailer less than 25 feet from any public street or highway right-of-way or so that any part of such mobile home or travel trailer will obstruct any roadway or walkway in the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-100; Code 1995, § 66-151) 
Sec. 210-208. - Parking spaces for motor vehicles. 
    At least two clearly defined parking spaces for motor vehicles shall be provided for each mobile home space in a park, and at least one parking space for motor vehicles shall be provided for each travel trailer space in a park. Such parking spaces shall be located either on or adjacent to the mobile home or travel trailer space. 
(Code 1975, § 13-101; Code 1995, § 66-152) 
Secs. 210-209-210-239. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SERVICE AND SANITARY FACILITIES 

Sec. 210-240. - Service buildings. 
    At least one service building shall be provided in each park accommodating travel trailers to house sanitation and laundry facilities. Service buildings shall be constructed to conform to the building code and other ordinance requirements for buildings and shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Be located no less than 25 feet and no more than 200 feet from any travel trailer space. 
(2)  Be of permanent construction and be adequately lighted. 
(3)  Be of moisture-resistant material, to permit frequent washing and cleaning. 
(4)  Have adequate heating facilities to maintain a temperature of 70 degrees Fahrenheit during cold weather, and to supply adequate hot water during peak demands. 
(5)  Have all rooms well ventilated, with all openings effectively screened. 
(Code 1975, § 13-107; Code 1995, § 66-166) 
Sec. 210-241. - Toilet and other sanitary facilities. 
(a)  Each travel trailer park and mixed mobile home and travel trailer park shall provide the following: 
(1)  Toilet facilities for males consisting of not less than two toilets and one urinal for the first ten travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof, and not less than one additional urinal and one additional toilet for every 20 additional travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof. 
(2)  Toilet facilities for females consisting of not less than two flush toilets for the first six travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof, and one additional flush toilet for every ten additional travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof. 
(3)  Each sex shall be provided with not less than two lavatories and two showers or bathtubs, with individual dressing accommodations, for the first ten travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof, and not less than one additional lavatory and one additional shower or bathtub, with individual dressing accommodations, for every ten additional travel trailer spaces, or fraction thereof. 
(b)  Each toilet for females and each shower or bathtub with individual dressing accommodations for females, as required by this section, shall be in a private compartment or stall. 
(c)  The toilet and other sanitation facilities required by this section for males and females shall either be in separate buildings or shall be separated, if in the same building, by a soundproof wall. 
(d)  In addition to the above requirements, each travel trailer park and mixed mobile home and travel trailer park shall provide, in a separate compartment, not less than one flush toilet bowl receptacle for emptying bed pans and other containers of human excreta or a slop sink with at least a three-inch trap and an adequate supply of hot running water for cleaning such bed pans or containers. 
(Code 1975, § 13-108; Code 1995, § 66-167) 
Sec. 210-242. - Laundry facilities. 
    Laundry facilities shall be provided in every park accommodating travel trailers in the ratio of one laundry unit to every 30 travel trailer spaces, and shall be in a separate soundproof room of a service building or in a separate building. A laundry unit shall consist of not less than one clothes washing machine. 
(Code 1975, § 13-109; Code 1995, § 66-168) 
Sec. 210-243. - Clothes drying facilities. 
(a)  Mobile home parks shall have at least 100 linear feet of outdoor clothes drying line or one mechanical clothes drying unit in good condition. Travel trailer parks and mixed parks shall have at least 25 linear feet of outdoor clothes drying line for each travel trailer space or one mechanical clothes drying unit for the first ten travel trailer spaces, or any fraction thereof, and an additional unit for each ten additional travel trailer spaces or any fraction thereof. 
(b)  Mechanical clothes drying units shall be located in a service building or a separate building in the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-110; Code 1995, § 66-169) 
Secs. 210-244-210-264. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 210-265. - From park buildings. 
    Waste from showers, bathtubs, flush toilets, urinals, lavatories, slop sinks and laundries in service and other buildings within a park shall be disposed of into a public sewer system controlled and operated by the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-115; Code 1995, § 66-170) 
Sec. 210-266. - From mobile homes. 
(a)  Each mobile home space in a park shall be provided with at least a three-inch sewer connection, at least four inches above the surface of the ground. The sewer connection shall be fitted with a standard ferrule and close nipple and provided with a screw cap. 
(b)  Every mobile home occupying a mobile home park space shall tie into the park sewerage system and shall dump any accumulated waste into the system. The connection between the mobile home drain and the sewer shall be watertight and self-draining. 
(Code 1975, § 13-116; Code 1995, § 66-182) 
Sec. 210-267. - From travel trailers. 
(a)  The person in charge of a travel trailer shall dump all accumulated waste into a receptacle provided in the park, upon entering and upon leaving the park. Such receptacles must be approved by the building inspector or the city engineer. Any other dump of accumulated waste within the city is prohibited. 
(b)  Sewer connections shall be made to travel trailer spaces in a park, where specified on plans. 
(Code 1975, § 13-117; Code 1995, § 66-183) 
Sec. 210-268. - Maintenance of sewer connections. 
    The park licensee shall be responsible for the maintenance, in good condition, of mobile home and travel trailer connections to the sewer system and shall see that there is no sewage leakage in the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-118; Code 1995, § 66-184) 
Secs. 210-269-210-299. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - WATER SUPPLY 

Sec. 210-300. - General requirements. 
    The following requirements shall apply to all parks: 
(1)  Plans for water supply must be submitted to and approved by the building inspector before construction is started, as required by state law. Application for construction of a water well must be submitted to the city council. The water supply must comply with all city ordinances and state regulations. 
(2)  An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in each park capable of furnishing a minimum of 250 gallons per day per mobile home space. Where a public supply of water of such quality is available within 300 feet, or becomes available within 300 feet, of the park, connection shall be made thereto and its supply shall be used exclusively. 
(3)  Where private water supplies must be developed, the building inspector or city engineer must approve the location, construction and development of both the water well and pipe system and connections. No private source other than a water well shall be used. 
(4)  No water well shall draw water from any sands reserved to or drawn from by the city for its use, except as may be otherwise permitted by ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 13-124; Code 1995, § 66-196) 
Sec. 210-301. - Required connection to buildings and mobile home and travel trailer spaces; cold water tap for mobile homes; hot water for service buildings. 
    The water system of a park shall be connected by pipes to all buildings and all mobile home spaces. Every mobile home shall be provided with a cold water tap. An adequate supply of hot water shall be provided at all times in the service buildings for all bathing, washing, cleaning and laundry facilities. Water connections shall be made to travel trailer spaces, where specified on plans. 
(Code 1975, § 13-125; Code 1995, § 66-197) 
Sec. 210-302. - Protection of connections from damage by parking of mobile homes or travel trailers. 
    Individual water-service connections which are provided in a park for direct use by mobile homes or travel trailers shall be of such construction so that they will not be damaged by the parking of such mobile homes or travel trailers. 
(Code 1975, § 13-126; Code 1995, § 66-198) 
Sec. 210-303. - Piping requirements; prohibited connections. 
    All water piping in a park shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with state statutes and city ordinances. The water piping system shall not be connected with nonpotable or questionable water supplies. There shall be no cross-connection between private water supplies for the area within the city water supply. 
(Code 1975, § 13-127; Code 1995, § 66-199) 
Sec. 210-304. - Protection from backflow and backsiphonage. 
    The water piping system in a park shall be protected against the hazards of backflow and backsiphonage. Mobile homes with fixtures from which backsiphonage may occur shall not be connected to the park's water system until the defect has been corrected. 
(Code 1975, § 13-128; Code 1995, § 66-200) 
Sec. 210-305. - Underground stop and waste cocks prohibited. 
    Underground stop and waste cocks shall not be installed on any water connections in a park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-129; Code 1995, § 66-201) 
Sec. 210-306. - Connections to be weathertight. 
    All water connections in a park shall be weathertight. 
(Code 1975, § 13-130; Code 1995, § 66-202) 
Sec. 210-307. - Maintenance of connections. 
    The park licensee shall be responsible for the maintenance, in good condition, of mobile home and travel trailer connections to the water system and shall see that there is no water leakage in the park. 
(Code 1975, § 13-131; Code 1995, § 66-203) 
Sec. 210-308. - Pressure. 
    The park water system shall be adequate to provide 20 pounds per square inch of pressure at all mobile home or travel trailer connections. 
(Code 1975, § 13-132; Code 1995, § 66-204) 
Sec. 210-309. - Pumping equipment requirements. 
    No well casing, pumps, pumping machinery or suction pipes shall be located in any pit, room or space extending below ground level, nor in any room or space above the ground which is walled in or otherwise enclosed, unless such rooms, whether above or below ground, have free drainage by gravity to the surface. All floors shall be watertight and sloped from the pump pedestal to the drain, and floors shall extend at least two feet from the well in all directions. The pedestal shall not be less than 12 inches above the floor. This shall not be construed as prohibiting submersible pumps. 
(Code 1975, § 13-133; Code 1995, § 66-205) 
Sec. 210-310. - Water risers. 
    Where the water supply system of a park does not provide at least six-inch water mains, there shall be provided a two-inch frost-protected water riser, within 300 feet of each mobile home space or building. 
(Code 1975, § 13-134; Code 1995, § 66-206) 
Sec. 210-311. - Park reservoirs. 
    All water storage reservoirs in a park shall be watertight and constructed of impervious material. All overflows and vents of such reservoirs shall be effectively screened. Open reservoirs are prohibited. Manholes shall be constructed with overlapping covers, so as to prevent the entrance of contaminated material. Overflow pipes from a reservoir shall not connect to any pipe in which sewage or polluted water may back up. 
(Code 1975, § 13-135; Code 1995, § 66-207) 
Sec. 210-312. - Supply for travel trailer reservoirs. 
    Provisions shall be made, within 150 feet of each travel trailer space in a park, to supply water for travel trailer reservoirs. 
(Code 1975, § 13-136; Code 1995, § 66-208) 
Sec. 210-313. - Drinking fountains. 
    Where drinking fountains are provided for public use in a park, they shall be of a type and in a location approved by the building inspector. 
(Code 1975, § 13-137; Code 1995, § 66-209) 
Secs. 210-314-210-344. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MANUFACTURED HOME SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 210-345. - Compliance with subdivision and zoning ordinances. 
    Mobile home subdivisions shall comply with the subdivision and zoning ordinances of the city, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 13-148; Code 1995, § 66-231) 
Sec. 210-346. - Minimum size. 
    The minimum size of any mobile home subdivision shall be ten acres. 
(Code 1975, § 13-149; Code 1995, § 66-232) 
Sec. 210-347. - Minimum lot widths and area. 
    The minimum effective lot widths in a mobile home subdivision shall be 40 feet, measured at the front building line, and minimum lot areas shall be 4,000 square feet; provided that, at least a ten-foot side yard shall be provided on each lot beyond any mobile home and addition thereto; and further provided that, in areas not serviced by a public sewer, the minimum lot area on which any mobile home may be placed shall be one acre. The effective lot width of a mobile home lot shall be determined, for interior lots, by measuring at right angles across the lot from one diagonal side line to the other, and for corner lots, the measurement shall be made at right angles from the diagonal having the greatest divergence from perpendicular to the street, through the midpoint of the rear line of the required front yard, to the opposite lot line or an extension thereof. 
(Code 1975, § 13-150; Code 1995, § 66-233) 
Sec. 210-348. - Relation of lot side lines to street lines. 
    Side lines of lots in mobile home subdivisions need not be at right angles to straight street lines or radial to curved street lines. 
(Code 1975, § 13-151; Code 1995, § 66-234) 
Sec. 210-349. - Lots to abut public street. 
    Regardless of the effective lot width, mobile home subdivision lots must abut a public street for at least 25 feet. 
(Code 1975, § 13-152; Code 1995, § 66-235) 
Sec. 210-350. - Greenbelt planting strip and landscaping. 
    All mobile home subdivisions, except those developed under residential standards, shall have a greenbelt planting strip, not less than 20 feet in width, along all boundaries of the subdivision. Appropriate landscaping, including a fence, shall be required. 
(Code 1975, § 13-153; Code 1995, § 66-236) 
Chapter 213 - SIGNS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 213-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to establish effective sign regulations which recognize the public as well as private interest and investment in our environment. This chapter is intended to promote economic and business development while protecting and reducing distractions and obstructions that may contribute to traffic accidents by prohibiting unsafe signs. Further, the purpose of this chapter is also to regulate the number, size and location of signs, cause the removal of abandoned signs, and protect the health, safety, welfare, convenience and enjoyment of the city for its residents and visitors. 
(Code 1975, § 20-1; Code 1995, § 94-1; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 3-16-2005) 
Sec. 213-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned/obsolete sign means any sign or sign structure, whether permitted or not or required to be permitted or not under this chapter, which advertises or pertains to a business, product, service, event, activity, or purpose which is no longer conducted or that has not been in use for 90 days. Any sign structure that no longer displays any sign copy or wording shall be deemed to be an obsolete or abandoned sign. 
    Accessory means subordinate or incidental to and on the same lot or within a common development as the building or use being identified or advertised. 
    Animation means any visible mechanical movement in any sign or apparent movement achieved by electrical pulsations or by other means, such as sequential light phasing. 
    Architectural projections means any projection, excluding signs, which is not intended for occupancy and which extends beyond the face of an exterior wall of a building, including, but not limited to, roof overhangings, wing walls, mansards, unenclosed exterior balconies, marquees, canopies, pilasters, fascias and awnings. 
    Awning means a movable shelter supported entirely from the exterior wall of a building and of a type which can be retracted, folded or collapsed against the face of the supporting building. 
    Billboard, including poster and panel types, means a nonaccessory sign or sign structure upon which advertising may be posted, painted or affixed and which is primarily designed for the rental or lease of the sign space for advertising not related to the use of the property upon which the sign is located. 
    Building code means the latest building code as amended and adopted by the city. 
    Canopy means a permanently roofed shelter covering a sidewalk, driveway or other similar area, which is supported by the building to which it is attached. 
    code enforcement official means the city manager is the person charged with the administration and enforcement of this chapter and he may designate certain persons as code enforcement officials to carry out such duties. 
    Copy means the wording and/or logo on a sign surface. 
    Days means consecutive working days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and recognized city legal holidays. 
    Designated mile means that distance along the centerline of a street measured between the centerlines of two section lines intersecting such street. 
    Directory signs means signs used to guide pedestrians and drivers to individual businesses within a multiple-tenant office development, or in any district developed for office uses without retail trade. Directory signs conforming to the requirements hereof shall not be deemed to be ground or wall signs. 
    Display face. See Sign side. 
    Electric sign means any sign continuing electrical wiring, but not including signs illuminated solely by exterior light sources, such as floodlights. 
    Electrical code means the electrical code adopted by the city. 
    Fence sign means signs displayed on any structure used as a fence. 
    Flare means any torch, fuse, wick or other illuminating device utilizing open flames to attract attention to an establishment. 
    Frontage, building, means the horizontal, linear dimension of that side of a building which abuts a street, a parking area, mall or other circulation area open to the general public and having either a main window display of the enterprise or a public entrance to the building. In industrial districts, a building side with an entrance open to industrial employees shall also qualify as a building frontage. Where more than one use occupies a building, each such use having a public entrance or main window display for its exclusive use shall be considered to have its own building frontage, which shall be the front width of the portion of the building occupied by that use. 
    Frontage, street, means the linear frontage or frontages of a lot or parcel abutting on a private or public street which provides principal access to, or visibility of, the premises. 
    Height means the vertical distance measured from the elevation of the nearest sidewalks (or, in the absence of a sidewalk within 35 feet, from the lowest point of finished grade on the lot on which the sign is located and within 35 feet of the sign) to the uppermost point on the sign or sign structure. 
    Illumination, direct, means any sign designed to provide artificial light either through exposed lighting in front of the face or through transparent or translucent material from a light source within the sign. 
    Illumination, indirect, means any sign which reflects light from a source intentionally directed upon it; for example, by means of floodlights, gooseneck reflectors or externally mounted fluorescent light fixtures. 
    Kiosk means a small structure, typically located within a pedestrian walkway or similar circulation area, and intended for use as a key, magazine or similar type of small shop, or for use as display space for posters, notices and exhibits. 
    Leading edge means that portion of the sign structure projecting the farthest from the building. 
    Light source includes neon lights, fluorescent lights, incandescent lights and any reflecting surface which, by reason of its construction and/or placement, becomes in effect the light source. 
    Lot means a portion or parcel of land, whether part of a platted subdivision or otherwise, occupied or intended to be occupied by a building or use and its accessories, together with such yards as are required under the provisions of the zoning ordinance. A lot must be an integral unit of land held under unified ownership in fee or in cotenancy or under legal control tantamount to such ownership. 
    Maintenance means the replacing, repairing or repainting of a sign structure made necessary by ordinary wear and tear, weather or accident. All such work shall be performed so as to conform with all applicable code provisions. 
    Marquee means a permanently roofed structure attached to and supported by a building and projecting from the building. 
    Menu board sign means a sign which is designed and utilized for the purpose of disclosing the availability and cost of products sold on the premises on which it is situated, which products are delivered directly to the stall or place where the menu board is installed or which are delivered at some point in a lane of travel in which the menu board sign is part. 
    Message sign means the wording or copy, including logo, on a sign. 
    Multiple-unit sign means a single business utilizing a single sign structure using more than one separate component to convey its advertising message. 
    Nonaccessory sign means a sign or advertising device which directs attention to an activity, service, products sold or offered elsewhere than on the premises on which the sign is located. 
    Owner means that person who owns a sign and who either owns the property on which the sign is located or is the owner of the business being conducted on the premises to which the sign pertains. 
    Political sign means all signs concerning the candidacy of an individual for public office or concerning support or opposition to any public issue. 
    Property line means the line marking the boundary between any street and the lots or property abutting thereon as determined by the legal description of the property and the records of the county clerk. Property lines abutting section line roads shall not be considered to be nearer than 50 feet from the centerline of the section line. 
    Public entrance means an entrance to a building or premises which is customarily used or intended for use by the general public. Fire exits, special employee entrances, loading dock entrances not generally used by the public, and the like shall not be considered as public entrances. 
    Roof means the cover of any building, including the eaves and similar projections. 
    Roof line means the highest point on any building where an exterior wall encloses usable floor space, including floor area for housing mechanical equipment. The term "roof line" shall also include the highest point on any parapet wall, providing said parapet wall extends around the entire perimeter of the building. 
    Setback line means a line or lines designating the yard requirements established for the particular zoning district classification of a tract, parcel or lot. 
    Shopping center means a concentration of five or more primarily retail stores and service establishments under one ownership or management, including, but not limited to, retail shops, department stores, restaurants, and other related or similar business establishments. The term "shopping center" also includes shopping malls. 
    Sight triangle means the same as defined by the zoning ordinance of the city. 
    Sign. 
(1)  The term "sign" means any writing, pictorial representation, decoration (including any material used to differentiate sign copy from its background), form, emblem or trademark, flag, stripe, color, banner or any other figure of similar character which: 
a.  Is a structure or any part thereof (including the roof or wall of a building); or 
b.  Is written, printed, projected, painted, constructed or otherwise placed or displayed upon or designed for or upon any building, board, plate, canopy, awning, vehicle or upon any material object or device whatsoever; and 
c.  Is designed to attract attention to the subject thereof or is used as a means of identification, advertisement or announcement by means of its form, color, wording, symbol, design, illumination, motion or striping. 
(2)  Signs are classified as follows: 
    Bench signs, courtesy, means any bench or seat placed for the convenience of the public and containing advertising matter. 
    Billboard sign means any existing sign or advertising device which advertises products, services or activities unrelated to the property upon which the sign or device is located, whether lawfully permitted or legally nonconforming. 
    Bulletin board sign means a sign used for the purpose of notification to the public of an event or occurrence of public interest, such as a church service, political rally, civic meeting or other similar events. 
    Canopy sign means any sign attached to or constructed in or on a canopy. 
    Changeable copy sign (manual) means a sign on which copy or sign panels may be changed manually in the field, such as boards with changeable letters or changeable pictorial panels. 
    Directional sign means a sign guiding or directing vehicular or pedestrian traffic onto or off a lot or within a lot. 
    Grand opening sign means any temporary sign which calls attention to a new business. 
    Ground signs means a sign which is supported by one or more columns, uprights, poles or braces extended from the ground or from an object on the ground or a sign which is erected on the ground; providing, that no part of the sign is attached to any part of any building structure or other sign. 
    Identification sign includes the following: 
1.  A sign which establishes the identity of a building or building complex by name or symbol only. 
2.  A sign which indicates street address or combines name plate and street address. 
3.  A sign which identifies an area in the city which, by reason of development, natural features, historical occurrences or common references, has or will become a landmark in the city. 
4.  A commemorative sign, such as a cornerstone, memorial or plaque, when such is cut into a masonry surface or constructed of bronze or other incombustible material and is made an integral part of the structure. 
    Illuminated awning sign means a frame structure with translucent, flexible, reinforced vinyl covering designed in awning form, but whose principal purpose and use is signage. Such signs are internally illuminated by fluorescent or other light sources in fixtures approved under national and local electrical codes. 
    Joint identification sign means a sign which serves as common or collective identification for two or more commercial or industrial uses on the same lot. 
    Marquee sign means a sign depicted upon, attached to or supported by a marquee. 
    Message center sign means any electronic communication display device utilizing lights, diodes or similar illumination to create letters, numerals or graphic presentations, capable of one or more of such various functions or operating modes as steady, scrolling, travelling, alternating or flashing copy. 
    Model home sign means any temporary sign which calls attention to a model home for sale or rent in a subdivision. 
    Off-premises sign means any sign, including a billboard or general outdoor advertising device, which advertises or directs attention to a business, commodity, service or activity conducted, sold or offered elsewhere than on the same lot or within the same building upon which such sign is located. 
    Open house sign means any temporary sign that calls attention to a home for sale or rent, which is temporarily open to the public. 
    Political campaign or special election signs. 
    Portable sign means a sign so designed as to be removable from one location to another and not permanently attached to the ground or to any immobile structure, whose primary function during a specific time is to advertise products or direct people to a business or activity located on the premises. 
    Portable trailer sign means a sign so designated as to be removable from one location to another and not permanently attached to the ground or to any immobile structure, whose primary function during a specific time is to advertise products or direct people to a business or activity located on the premises. 
    Projecting sign means a sign attached to a building or extending in whole or in part 15 inches or more horizontally beyond the surface of the building to which the sign is attached and where the face of the sign is not in a plane parallel to the wall to which it is attached, but not including a marquee sign. 
    Real estate sign means a sign indicating the availability for sale, rent or lease of the specific lot, building or portion of a building upon which the sign is erected or displayed. 
    Residential development entrance sign means a sign on a fence or gateway at the entrance of a residential complex or development denoting the name and/or address of the complex or development. 
    Roof sign means a sign painted on the roof of a building, supported by poles, uprights or braces extending from the roof of a building, or projecting above the roof line of a building, but not including a sign projecting from or attached to a wall as permitted by this chapter. 
    Suspended sign means a sign suspended from the ceiling of an arcade, marquee, canopy or other architectural projection. 
    Temporary sign means a sign, banner, pennant, balloon or similar device or display which is intended for a temporary period of display for the purpose of announcing a special event or construction. Such sign may be constructed of cloth, canvas or cardboard material, with or without a structural frame. 
    Time-temperature-date sign means a sign which displays the time, outdoor temperature and/or date of the month. 
    Vehicle-mounted sign means a sign displayed upon a trailer, van, truck, automobile, bus, railroad car, tractor, semitrailer or other vehicle, whether or not such vehicle is in operating condition. 
    Wall sign means a sign attached flat to any wall of an enclosed building, where the exposed face of the sign is in a plane parallel to the plane of said wall and extends not more than 15 inches horizontally from the face of such wall. A sign erected upon or against the side of a roof having an angle of 45 degrees or less from the vertical shall be considered to be a wall sign and shall be regulated as such. The term "wall sign" also means a sign painted directly on the surface of the building. 
    Wind sign means a sign consisting of one or more banners, flags, pennants, ribbons, spinners, streamers or captive balloons, or other objects or material fastened in such a manner as to move upon being subjected to pressure by wind or breeze. 
    Window sign means a sign which is painted on, applied or attached to, or located within three feet of the interior of a window, which sign can be seen through the window from the exterior of the structure. Merchandise which is included in a window display shall not be included as part of a window sign. 
    Sign, illegal nonconforming, means a sign that was in violation of any of the laws of the city governing the erection or construction of such sign at the time of its erection, and that has never been erected or displayed in conformance with all such laws, including this chapter, and which shall include signs that are pasted, nailed, painted on or otherwise unlawfully displayed upon structures, utility poles, trees, fences or other signs. 
    Sign, legal nonconforming, means any sign which was lawfully erected and maintained prior to the enactment of this chapter, and any amendments thereto, and which does not conform to all the applicable regulations and restrictions of this chapter. 
    Sign side means the surface of a sign upon, against or through which the message is displayed or illustrated. 
    Sign structure means a sign, including any supports, uprights, braces or framework of a sign. 
    Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the ground above grade, but not including poles, lines, cables or other transmission or distribution facilities of public utilities. 
    Subdivision means the same as defined in the subdivision regulations of the city, set forth in appendix B of this Code. 
    Vertical surface means that wall area of a single building elevation, which encompasses all of such elevation from ground or grade level to the top of all sides. 
    Zoning ordinance means the city zoning ordinance, together with all amendments thereto, as set forth in appendix A to this Code. 
(Code 1975, § 20-6; Code 1995, § 94-2; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 3-16-2005) 
Sec. 213-3. - Scope and application of this chapter. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the display, construction, erection, alteration, use, location and maintenance of all signs within the city, including any sign erected or constructed prior to the enactment of this chapter. 
(b)  This chapter does not regulate in any manner noncommercial holiday signs and decorations, public informational and safety signs, or signs required by local, state or federal law. 
(Code 1975, § 20-2; Code 1995, § 94-3) 
Sec. 213-4. - Exemptions. 
    Except as specifically provided, the following shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter: 
(1)  Signs which are not visible beyond the boundaries of the lot or parcel upon which they are located, or from any public right-of-way, or from any parking area, mall or other circulation area open to the general public, except that such signs shall be subject to the safety regulations of the building code and the electrical code of the city. 
(2)  Official governmental notices and notices posted by governmental officers in the performance of their duties, governmental signs to control traffic or for other regulatory purposes, or to identify streets, or to warn of danger. 
(3)  The flag, pennant or insignia of any nation, organization of nations, state, county or city; any religious, civic, fraternal organization; or any educational institution. Additionally, one corporate name or logo-bearing flag not exceeding 24 square feet in size will be permitted. 
(4)  Temporary decorations or displays, when such are clearly incidental to and are customarily and commonly associated with any national, local or religious holiday or celebration. 
(5)  Temporary or permanent signs erected by public utility companies or construction companies to warn of danger or hazardous conditions, including signs indicating the presence of underground cables, gas lines and similar devices. 
(6)  Merchandise, pictures or models of products or services which are incorporated as an integral part of a window display. 
(7)  Signs displayed on trucks, buses, trailers or other vehicles which are being operated or stored in the normal course of a business, such as signs indicating the name of the owner or business which are located on moving vans, delivery trucks, rental trucks and trailers and the like; provided that they are parked or stored in areas appropriate to their use as vehicles. 
(8)  Directional signs located in the street right-of-way; provided such signs are approved by the building inspector or his designee. 
(Code 1975, § 20-11; Code 1995, § 94-4) 
Sec. 213-5. - Provisions of chapter declared to be minimum requirements. 
    The provisions of this chapter, in their interpretation and application, shall be held to the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of public health, safety, morals or general welfare. Whenever the requirements of this chapter are at variance with the requirements of any of the lawfully adopted codes or ordinances, the most restrictive or that imposing the highest standard shall govern. 
(Code 1975, § 20-40; Code 1995, § 94-5) 
Sec. 213-6. - Violations. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to perform or order the performance of any act which is contrary to the provisions of this chapter, or to fail to perform any act which is required by the provisions of this chapter. In the case of a continuing violation, each 24-hour period in which the violation exists shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1975, § 20-4; Code 1995, § 94-6) 
Sec. 213-7. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any requirements hereof is guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-7. In addition to all other remedies for the enforcement of this chapter and its provisions, the city may institute any proper action in a court of competent jurisdiction to prevent, enjoin, restrain, abate or otherwise to correct any violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 20-41; Code 1995, § 94-7) 
Sec. 213-8. - Application of other laws. 
    If any of the provisions of this chapter are inconsistent with the provisions of any other law of the city presently existing or enacted in the future, in that the requirements regarding signs of the respective provisions differ, the provision containing the more restrictive requirements will apply. 
(Code 1975, § 20-5; Code 1995, § 94-8) 
Sec. 213-9. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all provisions of this chapter. He shall appear for and on behalf of the city in all matters regarding the interpretation and application of this chapter, and shall resist and oppose any deviations from the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Upon presentation of proper credentials, the city manager or his authorized representative may enter at reasonable times the public areas of any building, structure or premises in the city to perform any duty imposed upon him by this chapter. 
(Code 1975, § 20-3; Code 1995, § 94-9) 
Sec. 213-10. - Temporary signs, time limits. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to allow to remain or fail to remove, from property under his care, custody or control, any temporary sign after 60 days. 
(Code 1995, § 94-10) 
Sec. 213-11. - Standards for billboards and similar nonaccessory type signs. 
    The regulations of this section shall not be applied to billboards when constructed on premises as accessory signs according to the accessory sign regulations of this chapter. In such cases, location, size, number, and all other relevant standards for accessory signs shall be applied. 
(1)  General nonaccessory signs shall be permitted as follows: 
a.  With a conditional use permit in zoning districts A, C5, I-1, and I-2 which lie within 100 feet of the I-40 right-of-way. 
b.  Such signs must be located as near to the interstate highway as practicable and must be oriented for interstate traffic. 
(2)  Sign size. 
a.  The display surface area shall not exceed 672 square feet per sign face, except for a 20 percent allowance for extensions and cutouts. 
b.  The maximum width of a sign shall be 60 feet. 
(3)  Height. 
a.  The maximum height of the highest point of the structure shall be 35 feet above road grade; however, where the sign is adjacent to an elevated roadway the maximum height shall be 35 feet above the elevated road grade. 
b.  All billboards shall maintain a minimum clearance of 12 feet when measured from the ground level at the base of the sign to the bottom of the sign face or to the bottom of the deck, whichever is lower. 
(4)  Location. 
a.  The location shall comply with all established building lines and required setbacks as outlined in this chapter and all other ordinances of the city. 
b.  Where there is no building setback line established by ordinance or subdivision plat, such signs shall be set back from the front lot line not less than 25 feet. 
c.  Where a railroad right-of-way crosses a public right-of-way, required setbacks or established building lines on adjacent properties are extended through or across the railroad right-of-way. 
d.  Billboards which are erected or painted on a roof and billboards which extend above the roofline of any building on which a sign is erected are prohibited. 
(5)  Spacing. Regardless of the applicable zoning, no sign displayed to be read from a divided, limited access roadway with four or more traffic lanes, shall be constructed, erected, placed, or replaced closer than 1,000 feet to another nonaccessory sign facing in the same direction and on the same side of the roadway from which the sign is intended to be read. 
(6)  Spacing from residentially zoned property. No nonaccessory sign shall be constructed, erected, placed, or replaced closer than 300 feet to the nearest residentially zoned property. 
(7)  Design and construction standards. No billboards shall be constructed with more than two steel posts or columns. Wood posts are specifically prohibited. 
(8)  Lighting. Nonaccessory signs may be illuminated which that are in compliance with the following conditions and any other applicable ordinances. 
a.  Signs shall not be erected which contain any of the following: flashing, intermittent, revolving, or moving light. 
b.  No sign shall be illuminated so that interferes with the effectiveness, obscures, imitates or may be confused with any such official traffic sign, device, or signal. No sign shall be permitted to have beams or rays directed at any portion of the traveled ways and/or such intensity or brilliance to cause glare or impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle or otherwise interferes with any driver's operation of a motor vehicle. 
(9)  Electronic messaging displays (EMDs). Electronic messaging display signs shall be subject to the following limitations. 
a.  Such signs shall display static images for a period of at least eight seconds before transitioning to another static image. 
b.  Transitions from one static image to the next may display frame effects so long as the use of animation and/or flashing as defined in this chapter are prohibited. 
c.  No such sign, if the illuminated portion of such sign is visible from an R zoning district other than street, highway or freeway right-of-way, or if the illuminated portion of such sign is visible from a designated residential development area, shall be located within 300 feet of such district or area. The 300 feet shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest visible illuminated point on a sign structure to the nearest point of an R zoning district or Residential development area boundary line. 
d.  No sign shall exceed a brightness of 0.3 foot candles above ambient light as measured using a foot candle (Lux) meter at a preset distance depending on sign area. The measurement distance shall be calculated with the following formula: The square root of the product of the sign area and 100. 
1.  Example using a 12 square foot sign: Measurement Distance = v(12 Sq. Ft. x 100) = 34.6 
2.  The standard for brightness adjustment as ambient light intensity declines shall be a maximum increase in light intensity from the digital sign of 0.3 foot candles over ambient levels as measured using a foot candle meter at a pre-set distance in accordance with the following procedure: 
3.  At least 30 minutes past sunset, record the ambient light using a foot candle meter for the area while the sign is off or displaying all black copy, with the meter located directly in front of and aimed directly at the sign at the appropriate distance. 
4.  Turn on the sign to display all white and take another measurement in accordance with the same procedure. 
5.  If the difference between the measurements is 0.3 foot candles or less, the brightness is properly adjusted, otherwise the sign must be adjusted to comply with the brightness adjustment standard set forth above. 
(i)  No such sign shall display an illuminative brightness of such intensity or brilliance that it impairs the vision or endangers the safety and welfare of any pedestrian, cyclist, or person operating a motor vehicle. 
(ii)  No such sign shall resemble or simulate any warning or danger signal, or any official traffic control device, sign, signal or light. 
e.  The display area of the sign shall utilize dimming technology which automatically adjusts the brightness of the sign based on ambient light conditions. A certificate signed by the sign contractor that the electronic message display (EMD) sign will be so equipped. 
f.  The display area of the sign is not allowed to resemble or simulate any warning or danger signal or any official traffic control device, sign, signal or light or to cause a driver to mistake the sign for a warning or danger sign. 
g.  The display area of the sign is not allowed to operate unless it is equipped with a default mechanism that shall freeze the sign in one position of static message if a malfunction occurs or shall be manually turned off within six hours of a reported malfunction. 
h.  Use of sound is prohibited in all zoning areas.
